text: Person1: Did you hear the news? Two of our major suppliers, Murphy Music and U-Tunes are merging! If they are conglomerated into one company into one company, it would have some serious affects on our market strategy. Person2: Are you sure? Who told you that? I highly doubt that they would take the step to merge into one company. . . They're supposed to be bitter enemies, the strictest of competitors. It must be a rumor. It can't be true. Person1: I read it myself on the financial page. They're really going to join together. U-Tunes was bought out by Murphy's, they will take over the company as of next month. Person2: The competition must have been too stiff for U-Tunes. Otherwise why would they allow themselves to be taken over by their sworn enemy? Person1: I guess they must have figured it would be easier to merge than to keep up the cutthroat competition. If you can't beat'em, join'em.

I believe that this is one of Elizabeth Montgomery's best performances in a movie, and I have seen most of her movies. I saw this for the first time on television when I was around fourteen, and I was so scared. I watch this movie every now and then, and I still enjoy it very much. I know that these days that this movie would probably not scare people too much. That just goes to show that the public movie and television audience has seen too much graphic violence in the last thirty years or so. I love movies that do not show the graphic details, you let your imagination do the work for you. This particular movie is a suspenseful thriller that keeps you on the edge of your seat throughout its entire duration. Elizabeth Montgomery truly shines in her portrayal of a woman caught in a web of deception and fear. Her ability to show vulnerability, strength, and emotional depth in her performance is a testament to her outstanding acting skills. The plot is well-conceived and executed, with twists and turns that keep you guessing up until the very end. The supporting cast is equally impressive, with each actor bringing their own unique touch to their respective character. The cinematography is excellent, with many atmospheric and visually striking scenes that add to the overall atmosphere of dread and tension. One of the aspects I appreciate most about this movie is its subtlety. It doesn't rely on cheap jump scares or excessive gore to get its point across. Instead, it skillfully builds tension and anticipation through its storytelling, character development, and chilling atmosphere. This is a true testament to the power of good filmmaking and storytelling, and a reminder that sometimes less can be more when it comes to creating genuine suspense and fear. In conclusion, I highly recommend this movie to anyone who appreciates a well-crafted suspenseful thriller. Elizabeth Montgomery's incredible performance alone makes it worth watching, but the captivating plot and overall craftsmanship of the movie make it a truly enjoyable and memorable experience. With its timeless approach to creating fear and suspense, this movie is a classic that stands the test of time and serves as a reminder of what makes an excellent thriller.

Harry Kane should not go to the Under-21 European Championship with England this summer, instead saving himself for Roy Hodgson's first team, according to Kenny Dalglish. Kane won his first senior caps for England last week, but is still eligible for Gareth Southgate's Young Lions. But Dalglish believes he has proven himself capable of making the step up, and should be kept fresh for the full European Championships in 2016. Harry Kane celebrates after scoring his first England goal, just moments after coming off the bench . Kane showed against Italy that he can cope with playing against some of the world's best defenders . Kane is ready to be a permanent member of the full squad, rather than the Under-21s, says Kenny Dalglish . 'Harry Kane doesn't need to go back to playing Under-21 football,' said Dalglish in The Mirror. 'He proved that the other night against a defence which included two players from Italy's best team, Juventus - he didn't look bad, did he?' 'Playing Under-21 football this summer won't help him. It will just tire him out.' The former Liverpool and Blackburn boss claimed that the Young Lions have done their job if they produce a player ready for the first team, and neither Kane, nor the other eligible players, should be bounced between the two squads. 'I don't think the Under-21s is there to win tournaments - although it's nice if you do, and you don't want to encourage someone that losing is good. 'But it is more important you look at the individual, and if Roy Hodgson thinks Kane is going to be part of his squad for Euro 2016, then that is what they should be gearing towards.' Kane is elligible to play for the Young Lions at this summer's tournament, but Dalglish says he shouldn't go . Tottenham will be hopeful that their star striker doesn't tire himself out playing for both England teams .

Las Vegas, NV - Unbeaten light welterweight champion Danny Garcia is set to go toe-to-toe with Lamont Peterson at the MGM Grand in Las Vegas this Saturday night. Garcia, who has an impressive 30-0 record, will be looking to continue his winning streak and defend his title against Peterson. In 2012, Garcia defeated British star Amir Khan and has since built a reputation as one of the most formidable fighters in the world. The US fighter was asked during the pre-match press conference about his fighting technique and he revealed a surprising secret to his success: an extra toe on one foot. According to Garcia, the extra toe helps him maintain balance and stay on his feet, making it difficult for his opponents to knock him down. He attributes his speed, agility, and dexterity in large part to this unique physical feature. Although his unusual trait has been reported in the past, it's a rare acknowledgement from Garcia, who took the opportunity to educate the public on the importance of resilience and dedication in the ring. "Having an extra toe might give me an edge, but it's not the only reason I've been successful. My hard work and dedication to the sport has gotten me to where I am today," said Garcia. This monumental matchup between Garcia and Peterson has boxing fans from around the world excited to see if Garcia's unbeaten record will hold strong. Both fighters have demonstrated their skill and determination throughout their respective careers, making this bout one of the most anticipated in recent memory. Lamont Peterson, who has a solid career record of 33-3-1, expressed his admiration for Garcia while also emphasizing his desire to dethrone the champion. "Danny's a great fighter, and I respect him. But this is my chance to show the world that I belong at the top," said Peterson. As millions of fans prepare to tune in, the city of Las Vegas is buzzing with anticipation for Saturday's fight. While both fighters bring their impressive skills and records to the ring, only one will come out on top.

Person1: Good afternoon, what can I do for you? Person2: Yes, please. I would like to know something about the driving courses. Person1: Well, We have short full time courses during the summer. Are you interested in them? Person2: No, I am free only at weekends. Person1: Then there are weekend courses. The course starts at 8:00 every Saturday and Sunday morning. Person2: Sounds fine. What about the coaches? Person1: We have very excellent coaches here and some of them have been teaching for 20 years. Person2: Good. How many hours of training should I have each day? Person1: 3 hours in the morning and 2 in the afternoon. It ends at 6:00 PM. Person2: Then how many people share a training car? Person1: Usually 3 and we have 2 coaches for each car. Person2: Very good. I will have more chances to get trained. Thank you. Person1: You are welcome.

First of all, this movie is gross to the point of nauseating, and my advice is to avoid it at all costs if you ever want to eat ice cream again. "Lactose Lunacy" takes the concept of horror-comedy to an extreme that is both unpalatable and stomach-churning, making for a truly miserable cinematic experience. The plot follows a group of friends as they take a job working at a seemingly innocuous ice cream factory, only to discover a nightmarish secret lurking beneath the surface. The filmmakers go to great lengths to introduce and exploit every disgusting possibility within the premise, and as a result, the film never strays from its horribly off-putting subject matter. The viewer is left enduring scene after scene of grotesque, borderline-torturous imagery, accompanied by a barrage of lowbrow and distasteful humor. While the cast, led by the admittedly charismatic Casey St. Clair, does their best to bring life to their paper-thin characters, they are ultimately hampered by the nauseating visuals and crass dialogue. The script constantly more focused on evoking disgust than allowing any of the cast to showcase their abilities, giving them little room for even the slightest bit of depth. "Lactose Lunacy" attempts to mix horror, comedy, and gross-out gore into a twisted treat, but it ultimately serves up a repugnant smorgasbord that leaves a bad taste in your mouth. If you value your enjoyment of ice cream and a good night's sleep, I recommend steering far away from this unpalatable disaster. Overall, this is a sad excuse for a movie; one that leaves the viewer feeling removed rather than entertained.

Kurt Zouma Steals the Spotlight in Chelsea's Win Against Manchester United Sunday's Premier League match-up featured Chelsea and Manchester United battling it out, with Chelsea securing a win with a 1-0 victory. A key factor in Chelsea's triumph was the outstanding performance of French defender, Kurt Zouma. The 20-year-old played as a defensive midfielder, focusing his efforts on keeping Marouane Fellaini out of the game. Chelsea boss, Jose Mourinho, was particularly impressed with Zouma's form during his first season with the club, and had confidence in his ability to control Fellaini's performance. Zouma's excellent show of skill and determination in the match has proven Mourinho's critics wrong. As he continues to perform at a high level, Zouma is solidifying his position as an essential player for Chelsea's ongoing success in the Premier League. Chelsea supporters can only hope to see more of Zouma's agility and finesse in upcoming games. With the coach's support and Mourinho's proven expertise in getting the job done, there is no doubt that Zouma will continue to make a significant impact on the team's gameplay this season.

In Caco-2TC7 cells, insulin action diminished the transepithelial transfer of sugar and reduced BBM and basolateral membrane (BLM) GLUT2 levels, demonstrating that insulin can target sugar absorption by controlling the membrane localization of GLUT2 in enterocytes. Similarly, in hyperinsulinemic-euglycemic clamp experiments in sensitive mice, insulin abolished GLUT2 (i.e., the cytochalasin B-sensitive component of fructose absorption), decreased BBM GLUT2, and concomitantly increased intracellular GLUT2. Acute insulin treatment before sugar intake prevented the insertion of GLUT2 into the BBM. Insulin resistance in mice provoked a loss of GLUT2 trafficking, and GLUT2 levels remained permanently high in the BBM and low in the BLM. We propose that, in addition to its peripheral effects, insulin inhibits intestinal sugar absorption to prevent excessive blood glucose excursion after a sugar meal. This protective mechanism is lost in the insulin-resistant state induced by high-fat or high-fructose feeding.

With great expectations I went to see this film, Spain's contribution to the Oscar-race this year. Part from being completely pointless, banal, pathetic, badly written, edited, acted and directed, the movie is too long. It fails in delivering the "message" it tries to give, fails in its storytelling, clumsy historical settings and above all in its rhythm. There are some so extreme misfires I haven't seen in a movie in a long time (the story of Lucas whose dead sister lives in his head, the divine revelations, all that lizard nonsense). The Spanish-speaking audience around me was yawning and rapidly losing patience, and some of the commentaries I overheard was whether the members of the Spanish Academy had taken drugs before choosing the film for the Oscar contest.

Yes, a 22-mer primer can enhance the discriminatory power of AP-PCR fingerprinting technique in the characterization of leptospires. AP-PCR (Arbitrarily Primed PCR) fingerprinting is a molecular typing method that helps differentiate between different strains of a microorganism, in this case, Leptospira. The discriminatory power of AP-PCR fingerprinting is influenced by the choice of the primer, which is an essential component of the PCR process. A 22-mer primer refers to a primer that consists of 22 nucleotide bases. Longer primers, like a 22-mer, can increase the specificity of the PCR reaction, leading to the amplification of more specific DNA fragments and improving the ability to differentiate between different strains of Leptospira. Using a 22-mer primer can essentially produce more diverse and distinct DNA fingerprints that are more easily compared, leading to a higher resolution in the characterization of the leptospires. However, the optimization of PCR conditions and primer selection should be carefully considered for the best results in the fingerprinting technique.

Snakes on a Plane was such a well hyped film that it was both inevitable and a little crazy to try to release another movie with almost the same title in the same year let alone the same week. Reading the other comments here I see the results. A lot of people are mad. Mad because it doesn't have the best special effects. Mad because it doesn't have a star cast. Mad because they wanted to see Samuel Jackson say "I'm sick of these M-Er F Ing Snakes on this M-Er F Ing Train"! Well, this sure ain't the Samuel Jackson version. And maybe that's good.Snakes on a Plane was lost between cop film and horror, a family action film and a bloody gory movie of death. Saturday Night Live performers got laughs while Jackson swore enough to make a grandmother cover her ears, and as far as kids go, they would be traumatized by the violence.Snakes on a Train however knew exactly what it was. This was a cheaply made horror movie on a train. Sure it had snakes and sure many of them were scientifically harmless garden snakes with fake rattler sound effects. But never once did it miss a step in its plot or intention where as the "on a Plane" version was tripping all over itself from the first scene on.I did enjoy the over the top fun that Snakes on a Plane had to offer and I admit that the ..."on a Train" version was a little dry. But hey, in trade, it was a cool and unexpected story. This little horror film could have gone way more wrong than it did.For this it gets a 7 out of 10.

I am not afraid of bad movies. In fact, sometimes I find them oddly entertaining. But what I encountered in "Attack of the 50ft Plot Holes" was beyond my wildest nightmares. It was not just a bad movie; it was an abomination that left me questioning the very existence of good taste and cinematic artistry. From the very first frame, the terrible CGI work assaulted my senses, making me instantly aware that I was in for a rough ride. The characters were painfully one-dimensional, their dialogue stiff and forced, like a high school theater production with minimal rehearsal time. The plot revolved around the sudden emergence of gigantic plot holes that swallowed cities and people wholea concept that seemed almost too self-aware, as if the director somehow knew just how many plot inconsistencies his own movie was devouring. Acting-wise, the performances went from wooden to over-the-top, with not a single actor managing to find the sweet spot in between. It felt as if everyone was aware of the disaster unfolding before them but had no idea how to save it, floundering desperately as the movie spiraled into chaos. And then there was the editing. Scenes seemed to be stitched together at random, with transitions so abrupt that I found myself wondering if my seat had become a time machine that thrust me forward every few minutes. The sound mix was a disaster, with explosive effects drowning out crucial dialogue and music cues that appeared entirely unrelated to the on-screen action. At the end of it all, I emerged from the theater dazed and bewildered, feeling as if I had just gone through some sort of horrendous cinematic torture. "Attack of the 50ft Plot Holes" is not just a bad movie; it's a disaster of epic proportions that should never have been unleashed upon unsuspecting audiences. If you value your sanity and your love for the art of filmmaking, I urge you to stay far, far away from this monstrosity.

Police in Surrey are hunting two raiders who stripped off their tops during the hottest day of the year before holding up an Esso petrol station. The men, who were both in their 20s, . These bare-chested men had stripped off before raiding a petrol station on the hottest day of the years so far and were caught on camera. Police in Surrey have released CCTV of the two raiders who stripped-off their shirts before attempting to rob the Esso filling station in Town End Caterham, Surrey early last Wednesday evening . The men forced their way into the manager's office of the filling station in Caterham, pictured, looking for cash . Police released these images of the men which they hope will lead to calls from the public, identifying them. The two men were among three who burst into the Esso petrol station in Town End, Caterham, Surrey, last Wednesday. They forced their way into the manager's office and were ransacking the room, looking for cash, when they were disturbed by a member of the garage staff and fled. A spokesman for Surrey Police said: 'Officers were called to the Esso petrol station after three men entered the store, forced entry into the manager's office and whilst ransacking the room were disturbed by staff. They left with a mobile phone belonging to a member of staff. 'No-one was injured during the incident which occurred at around 7.45pm.' Police constable Natalie Pearce said: 'Since the incident we have made a number of inquiries into the burglary including viewing CCTV. We believe the men captured on camera will be able to assist us with our investigation. 'If you are one of the men in the images we are releasing or if you recognise the men, please contact Surrey Police.' She added that a third man, aged in his 20s, had been arrested and released on police bail while the investigation continued.

Person2: No, I feel good. Person1: Excellent. Now let's check your blood pressure. Please extend your left arm. . . Alright, just relax...Perfect, your blood pressure is normal. Lastly, I'm going to use the stethoscope to listen to your heart and lungs. Please breathe normally. . . Okay, everything sounds good. Person2: That's a relief. Thank you. Person1: You're welcome. P63 protein expression is indeed relatively rare in prostate adenocarcinoma, and its presence may have implications for cancer diagnosis and the study of carcinogenesis. P63 is a member of the p53 family of proteins, which are involved in various cellular processes, such as cell-cycle regulation, apoptosis, and DNA repair. In the case of prostate adenocarcinoma, p63 protein is frequently absent or expressed at very low levels, which is in contrast to other prostate pathologies, such as benign prostatic hyperplasia or prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PIN), where p63 expression is often found at higher levels. One of the reasons for the rarity of p63 expression in prostate adenocarcinoma is that the cells which give rise to this cancer type are typically p63-negative. In addition, mutations and deletions in p63 can contribute to the development and progression of prostate adenocarcinoma. The relative absence of p63 protein expression in prostate adenocarcinoma can be useful for diagnostic purposes. Immunohistochemical analysis of p63 protein expression can help pathologists differentiate prostate adenocarcinoma from benign prostatic hyperplasia or other prostate lesions, as the latter usually show positive p63 staining. However, there are some limitations to this approach, as some cases of prostate adenocarcinoma may show focal p63 expression. Therefore, it is crucial to consider other diagnostic markers, clinical history, and imaging studies for a definitive cancer diagnosis. As for carcinogenesis, the low expression of p63 in prostate adenocarcinoma cells suggests that it might play a role in the development andor progression of this cancer type. P63 has been shown to have both tumor-suppressive and oncogenic functions, depending on the particular isoform and cellular context. Therefore, gaining a better understanding of the molecular mechanisms underlying the regulation and function of p63 in prostate adenocarcinoma may provide insights into the biology of this cancer type and potentially reveal new therapeutic targets. In conclusion, the rarity of p63 protein expression in prostate adenocarcinoma holds diagnostic significance and may provide valuable insights into the study of carcinogenesis. Further research on p63's role in prostate cancer development and progression could aid in the development of better diagnostic tools and treatment options for patients.

Distal femoral condyle is internally rotated to the patellar tendon at 90 of flexion in normal knees. When the symmetric femoral component is aligned perpendicular to the femoral mechanical axis, the patellar tendon would be possibly more twisted than the condition in normal knees, and the deviation of the PF contact force on the patellar component might be caused. The configuration and alignment of the distal condyle of the femoral component can affect the PF joint congruity in knee flexion. In this respect, our results provide important information in considering designs and alignment in the distal femur of TKA and the PF joint congruity in knee flexion.

Well, I saw that yesterday and it was much better than the other making-of from VH1. Too bad that this one is pretty outdated, but you get to see all the staff who make South Park - very interesting stuff. It's also funny that this documentary portrays Trey and Matt like selfish, greedy snobs who don't work and spend all their time having fun or relaxing (which is kinda ironic because they work pretty hard on the show). It also shows all the animation processes to make a South Park episode, interviews with the actors who bring characters' voices to life, and much more. If you're a fan of South Park, I highly recommend you check this out. It may be a bit dated, but it's definitely an entertaining and informative look behind the scenes of this iconic show.

The COMT ValMet polymorphism may modulate the effects of tDCS on response inhibition, but more research is needed to provide a definitive answer. This is due to the fact that the relationship between the COMT ValMet polymorphism, tDCS, and response inhibition is complex and involves multiple brain networks. The COMT ValMet polymorphism is a genetic variant that affects the activity of catechol-O-methyltransferase (COMT), an enzyme involved in the breakdown of dopamine in the brain. The Val (valine) allele is associated with higher COMT activity, which leads to lower dopamine levels, while the Met (methionine) allele is associated with lower COMT activity and higher dopamine levels. Dopamine plays a crucial role in the regulation of cognitive functions, such as attention, working memory, and response inhibition. tDCS (transcranial direct current stimulation) is a noninvasive brain stimulation technique that modulates neuronal excitability, with potential effects on cognitive functions. While there is evidence that tDCS can improve cognitive performance in some individuals, its effects on response inhibition remain inconclusive. There are some studies suggesting that the COMT ValMet polymorphism can modulate the effects of tDCS on cognitive performance, but these studies are mostly focused on working memory or other cognitive domains. It is plausible that the COMT ValMet polymorphism might also influence the effects of tDCS on response inhibition, considering the importance of dopamine in this cognitive function. However, further research is needed to specifically investigate the interaction between the COMT ValMet polymorphism, tDCS, and response inhibition. This research should ideally include large sample sizes, controlled study designs, and standardized measures of response inhibition to establish more reliable and conclusive evidence.

This is one of the best Czech movies I have ever seen. The director did excellent work, there is great camera and the actors are really great. I like war movies so I really liked this one. I would recommend it to anyone who wants to know something about Czech pilots during 2nd World War and their life after the war, in communism.

Yes, in healthy mice, insulin can internalize and regulate the amount of GLUT2 present on the cell membrane of enterocytes, leading to an increase in glucose uptake. However, in insulin-resistant mice, this regulatory function is impaired. Less GLUT2 is translocated to the cell membrane in response to insulin, leading to reduced glucose uptake and contributing to the overall problem of insulin resistance. To clarify, enterocytes are the cells that line the small intestine and play a crucial role in the absorption of nutrients, including glucose. GLUT2 is a glucose transporter protein that facilitates the transport of glucose across the cell membrane. Insulin is a hormone that helps regulate blood glucose levels. In healthy conditions, insulin causes an increase in GLUT2 on the cell membrane of enterocytes, leading to more efficient glucose uptake. Insulin resistance disrupts this process, contributing to impaired glucose homeostasis.

And I've tried going to bed early, but I just can't fall asleep. Person1: That sounds rough. Have you considered talking to a doctor about your sleep trouble or seeking help at a sleep clinic? Person2: I haven't thought about that, to be honest. Maybe I should give it a try if things don't improve. Person1: It might be worth it. In the meantime, perhaps you could try some relaxing activities before bed like reading, meditation, or taking a warm bath to help you fall asleep. Person2: Thanks for the suggestions, I'll definitely try those. I just hope I can get better sleep soon. Person1: I hope so too. Remember to take care of yourself and don't hesitate to seek professional help if needed. Sleep is crucial for our overall well-being.

NBA Star Jeff Green Transforms Surgical Experience into Giving Back By [Author] [date] In 2011, NBA player Jeff Green faced one of the biggest challenges of his life off the court: open heart surgery to repair an aortic aneurysm. The diagnosis pulled Green away from the game for the entire 2011-2012 basketball season, but transformed his life in the process. Today, nearly a decade after his surgery, Green continues to pour his heart out in a different way - donating his time to young cardiovascular patients. Green's journey began in late 2011 when a routine physical examination led to the discovery of an aortic aneurysm. An aortic aneurysm is a dangerous condition, in which the heart's aorta weakens and bulges, increasing the risk of rupture. For the then 25-year-old athlete, this news came as a shock, but it forced him to prioritize his health over his passion for basketball. After a successful surgery, Green was adamant about making the most of his experience and using it to inspire others. "I'm very blessed to be here. Every day that I step on the floor, it's a reminder of what I went through and what the process was to get back," he said. Today, Green is a strong advocate for heart health and dedicates his time to helping young cardiovascular patients at various hospitals and organizations. As a mentor, he shares his story with affected children, inspiring them to remain resilient and tenacious to face their challenges. Additionally, the NBA star actively raises awareness for cardiovascular research and campaigns, which aid in finding new treatments and therapies. Green's remarkable recovery not only allowed him to resume his roaring basketball career but also serves as a beacon of hope for those battling similar health issues. His continued commitment to help raise awareness and funds for heart health research, while also providing emotional support to those going through similar trials, highlights Green's dedication and ability to turn this life-changing event into a powerful and impactful movement. In 2021, Green will mark the 10-year anniversary of his surgery. Since returning to the court, he has become a crucial player for various NBA teams, including the Boston Celtics and the Houston Rockets. Currently playing for the Brooklyn Nets, Green's journey has undoubtedly created a lasting impact on the lives of countless young cardiovascular patients and will continue to inspire others for years to come.

One of the biggest fixtures on the German footballing calendar takes place this weekend, although some of the usual gloss has been taken off a game recently baptised Der Klassiker. Borussia Dortmund and Bayern Munich have shared the last five Bundesliga titles between them and Bayern are set to continue their domestic domination this term. This time, however, the two giant antagonists of the German game meet with 31 points and nine positions separating them in the standings, but that does not mean the stakes are not as high as they always are when these two clubs meet. Jurgen Klopp (centre) celebrates with hisBorussia Dortmund players after their victory against Hannover . Dortmund are now only five points from the top six having climbed their way from the foot of the table at the midway stage of the season to 10th, although their coach Jurgen Klopp insists their league position after the Klassiker is not his biggest concern. 'We've got to try to beat Bayern and where that can take us in the league is secondary,' Klopp said. 'Although we're 10th, and although there's a huge points gap between us, and although a lot is different compared to the past, it's still a Borussia Dortmund home game. 'I don't recall us gifting any of these games in the past. Dortmund'sJakub Blaszczykowski (right) challenges Hannover centre backChristian Schulz . 'Gladbach have shown us how it's done. Wolfsburg have also beaten them, but it's not all that easy.' Victory would nevertheless be important for Dortmund if they are to close the gap on the top six and qualify for Europe next season, while a second consecutive defeat for Bayern is almost unheard of and it would allow Wolfsburg to reduce the deficit at the top to seven points. The Wolves host bottom-placed Stuttgart on Saturday while third-placed Borussia Monchengladbach can strengthen their grip on a place in the Champions League with a win at Hoffenheim. The battle at the bottom of the table is intensifying with all of the bottom eight sides separated by just seven points and still in danger. Xabi Alonso cuts a cool figure during Bayern Munich's training session on Thursday . Hamburg reacted to their slide into the bottom three by appointing Peter Knabel as their new coach during the international break and his first game is a daunting trip to fourth-placed Bayer Leverkusen. The northern Germany side therefore risk coming out the other side of the weekend inside the bottom two with Paderborn travelling to Hertha Berlin on Sunday. Freiburg and Cologne are also involved in that scrap and they meet on Saturday with Mainz travelling to Werder Bremen. Elsewhere, Augsburg host Schalke on Sunday and Eintracht Frankfurt welcome Hannover and their under-fire coach Tayfun Korkut to the Waldstadion.

"Love is a Many-Splendored Thing" is set in Hong Kong in 1949-50, and tells the story of the relationship between Mark Elliott, a white American journalist, and Han Suyin, a half-Chinese half-European doctor. Directed by Henry King, this romantic drama is an emotional journey that showcases the challenges of love across cultural and racial boundaries amid a tumultuous historical backdrop. The film is beautifully shot, with stunning visuals of Hong Kong that adds authenticity and a sense of nostalgia to the narrative. The wide shots of the cityscape and countryside, along with the impressive cinematography, create a visually rich and captivating experience for the audience. William Holden and Jennifer Jones deliver powerful performances as Mark and Han, showcasing the emotional range required to portray two individuals who are caught in the crossfire of societal pressures and expectations. Their chemistry is undeniable and adds depth to the heartfelt love story being brought to life on the screen. "Love is a Many-Splendored Thing" offers compelling insight into the complexities of cross-cultural relationships during a time where society was less accepting of their existence. The film holds a mirror to the prejudices and limitations of society, while proving that love, in its various forms, can transform hearts and minds. The beautiful and nostalgic score by Alfred Newman complements the film's theme of love transcending boundaries, and adds a sense of melancholy that increases the emotional impact of the story. In conclusion, "Love is a Many-Splendored Thing" is a classic romantic drama worth watching for its compelling love story, powerful performances, stunning visuals, and evocative score. It is a moving portrayal of love defying societal expectations, proving that love, in all its forms, is indeed a many-splendored thing.

Wow, where to begin with this one. Well, if you enjoy laughing at the utter failures of filmmakers, then this one is for you. I bought this movie for 5 bucks because I never pass up an opportunity to laugh at B-movie God Casper Van Dien's blunders, and boy was this one of them. It may have been enough that this movie contains the single most lame movie monster ever. This thing, which is supposed to be an Indian ghost, looks more like a plastic candy bowl skeleton that you put on your front porch on Halloween. He dons a cape that is clearly a garbage bag, complete with what appears to be a bucket-shaped bonnet over his head. At some points this is a man in costume, at others it is clearly a plastic prop placed on top of a horse. This monster has the uncanny ability to see with "predator" vision, a clear rip-off, and can miraculously appear after throwing his spear. Sometimes the spear cuts people, sometimes it doesn't. This thing also manages to down a helicopter with a single arrow. Wow, this makes a much sense as when the kid blows up a spaceship with a firecracker at the end of "Critters." This creature is impervious to bullets, but somehow dies at the end of the movie. At the end of his killing spree, which we never really find out why he is on, he gets blown up. This is an incredible feat, for we had already seen this thing blow up 3 times in the film. But, I guess this last time was the charm. And don't even get me started on the lameness of the other characters. First of all, what Delta Force unit employs women? Last I checked the military still disallows women into combat situations. Also, this unit is "undercover." Why? What possible reason would they have to be undercover? And they're not even good at it, I guess no one would realize that they were military if they didn't have on uniforms, BUT THEY WERE ALL CARRYING MACHINE GUNS (which incidentally change sound effects throughout the film, at some points sounding like air rifle BB guns, and at others, canons). There is one part when the Skeleton Man throws some construction workers from a catwalk, and you can clearly see the pad that they fall onto. At another point. Michael Rooker falls down a hill that is clearly flat ground. They tilted the camera slightly to give the appearance of an incline, but he is clearly pushing himself along in this looooooonnnnnggggggg fall scene. Then when he is helped back up the hill, the rope is flat, and when it shows the woman at the "top" of the "hill" the rope goes upward from her grip, not the way it would look if she was pulling someone up a hill. Rooker actually has a line that says, "I'm not going after him, I going after it." What? That is quite possibly the dumbest thing I have ever heard, and I watch these bad movies as a hobby. The saddest part about this quote is that you can tell that everyone involved in the writingproduction of this film thought that it was so bad-ass. Believe it or not, compared to the rest of the dialog, this is good. The acting, bad. The makeup, really bad. These characters either had scars or wounds that liked to change sides of their face. Maybe these are alien scars that like to run around on your face. Yeah, I think I'll make a movie about that, "Attack of the Alien Scars that Move Around on Your Face." That villain would be more intimidating than the Skeleton Man, and the film would probably be scarier.

Yes, iKKCHUK (inhibitor of nuclear factor kappa-B kinase subunit alpha) may regulate extracellular matrix (ECM) remodeling independently of its kinase activity to facilitate articular chondrocyte differentiation. A study published in the journal Nature Communications in 2018 revealed that iKKCHUK non-canonically binds to YAPTAZ (Yes-associated protein and PDZ-binding motif) in the cytoplasm, consequently promoting the nuclear translocation of YAPTAZ for transcriptional regulation of ECM remodeling genes. This process facilitates the maturation and differentiation of articular chondrocytes and highlights the potential relevance of iKKCHUK in cartilage biology and the regulation of ECM remodeling independent of its kinase activity. However, more studies need to be conducted to discern the full extent of iKKCHUK on ECM remodeling and articular chondrocyte differentiation with a focus on its kinase-independent functions.

101-Year-Old Woman Stays Fit with Strength Exercises and Step Classes, Defying Age Stereotypes Sydney, Australia - At the sprightly age of 101, Salvina Formosa is defying stereotypes and breaking barriers by staying fit and active. Every week, she engages in weight exercises and sit-to-stand routines, in addition to participating in step classes to improve her overall fitness levels. The centenarian, who celebrated her 101st birthday on March 16, shows no signs of slowing down. In fact, her dedication to maintaining her physical health was evident when she recently tripped over an uneven footpath and decided to work on her balance and strength by joining step classes. Her fitness journey has not only improved her endurance, but it has also provided her with a sense of empowerment and independence. As the Sydney mother continues to pursue her fitness goals, she serves as an inspiration to many, demonstrating that age is just a number and that it is never too late to start working on one's health and well-being. Family, friends, and fellow gym-goers have all been amazed by Formosa's energy and dedication, as she never misses a workout session and always brings a positive attitude. Her passion for staying active and fit has been passed down to her children, grandchildren, and great-grandchildren, proving that her impact extends beyond just herself. Fitness trainers and doctors alike have praised Formosa for her commitment and perseverance, which has undoubtedly contributed to her longevity and quality of life. By embracing a healthy lifestyle and staying motivated, she has been able to retain her strength and vitality despite her age. Many studies have shown that engaging in regular physical activity can lead to numerous health benefits for older adults, including improving overall strength, maintaining a healthy weight, and reducing the risk of chronic diseases. Formosa's story is a testament to these findings, as she remarkably maintains her fitness and well-being at 101 years old. Salvina Formosa's dedication to leading a healthy and active lifestyle is a shining example for individuals of all ages. As she stays committed to her fitness journey, there is no doubt that she will continue to inspire and motivate others to challenge themselves and ensure their own well-being.

Amir Khan has gone face to face with Adrien Broner ahead of a possible summer fight against the former lightweight world champion. Khan is expected to announce his next opponent imminently, with British rival Kell Brook set to feature on his agenda for a Wembley blockbuster next year. Amir Khan appears on the screen as Adrien Broner urges him to make their fight happen on FaceTime . Broner says, 'Let's get this money', in the short video of their conversation posted on Instagram . Khan hasn't fought since his win over Devon Alexander in December and has struggled to find an opponent . Broner has been relentless in his calling out of Khan since his comfortable win over John Molina Jr . But in the shorter term, the Bolton fighter has held talks with American Broner, who tweeted a video of himself and Khan talking via video. He included the hashtag BronervsKhan. In the video, Broner tells Khan: 'Hey, tell them to make the fight, man, let's get this money.' It's by no means certain that the fight will go ahead, with Broner seemingly more keen than Khan. However, the Brit has previously encouraged talk of a bout against a man whose brash manner has made him a big draw in his homeland. Khan is targeting a fight at the end of May before breaking for Ramadan in mid-June, with a distant hope of facing the winner of Floyd Mayweather's May 2 showdown with Manny Pacquiao. Brook remains the money-spinning fight on the agenda, with Khan having said on Tuesday that he wants to fight the IBF welterweight world champion at Wembley within 12 months. Broner posts a cheeky artist's impression of what he believes would happen should he fight Khan . Khan has said he would love to fight Broner in lieu of not being able to get in the ring with Floyd Mayweather . Khan says he has given his word to his next opponent and will be making an announcement 'very soon' Brook was due to fight in July but revealed he has brought forward his plans following his demolition of Jo Jo Dan last Saturday. He said: 'I have told Eddie Hearn to get me out as soon as possible and I want to fight twice before the end of the summer, starting at the end of May.'

Person1: Hey, Susan. Have you got a sec? I have some questions about my paycheck. Person2: You bet, Emily. Pull up a chair. Person1: Well, this is my first paycheck here in the States and there are a few things I don't understand. First of all, what is this FICA, and SUI Y tax, and why are there deductions both for Medicare and for my health insurance plan? Person2: OK, let's start from the top of your pay stub. This number here represents your gross pay. Then here we have a series of deductions. First off are the federal ones. FICA stands for Federal Insurance Contribution Act, or something like that. It's your federal income tax. And then there's Social Security and Medicare, which are both federal programs to help you out after you retire or if you were unable to work. Person1: All right, I see. So the Medicare isn't actually a health insurance I can use now. Person2: That's right. Below the federal deductions are the state deductions. There's the state income tax, and then this SUISDI tax you were asking about is paying into an unemployment and disability fund that our state has set up, but you can see it's a pretty small quantity that they take. Person1: Yeah, I don't mind giving them a dollar fifty for that. So there are two separate income taxes,one at a state level and one at a federal level? Person2: That's right. Not all states have an income tax. Some use higher property taxes or sales taxes instead. Person1: I see. All right, well I think everything else I can figure out on my own. The deductions for health insurance and my 401 (K) are pretty self-explanatory. Thanks for your help, Susan. Person2: No problem! All those deductions do add up, and nobody's net pay is as high as they'd like. I can understand why you'd want some explanation. Person1: Yeah, I guess it's the same in the UK, I just never paid much attention. See you later!

A Coast Guard cutter arrived in San Diego on Thursday with more than 14 tons of cocaine, part of what authorities has described as a surge of seizures near Central and South America. The cocaine, valued by the Coast Guard at 424 million, was seized by U.S. and Canadian forces in 19 separate incidents in the eastern Pacific Ocean near Central and South America. It included a 10-ton bust from a coastal freighter, the largest maritime drug interdiction in that area since 2009. A crewman from the Coast Guard Cutter Boutwell guards some of more than 28,000 pounds of cocaine, seized at sea and offloaded at Naval Base San Diego on Thursday . The cocaine was seized by U.S. and Canadian forces in 19 separate incidents in the eastern Pacific Ocean near Central and South America . The U.S. Navy and Coast Guard and Royal Canadian Navy ships have seized more than 28 tons of cocaine valued at 848 million in the eastern Pacific region near Central and South America in the last six months, resulting in 101 arrests. That's more than the 12-month period that ended in September, and U.S. authorities have called it the most successful run for drug seizures in the area since 2009. Suspicious vessels in international waters were tracked by military or law enforcement aircraft or vessels. Coast Guard personnel operating from Coast Guard cutters and Royal Canadian Navy vessels boarded the ships to seize the drugs. Thursday's arrival marked the second time that the Cutter Boutwell has returned home with a huge load of drugs. In October, its crew turned over more than 14 tons of cocaine to the U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration. Four-time world champion Adrien Broner has publicly called out Amir Khan for a showdown in his next fight. Following a close win over Jessie Vargas, "The Problem" posted a video of his FaceTime conversation with the British professional boxer. In the video, the American made it clear that he was hungry for a fight with Khan, saying, "You know I want to fight you." Khan, a former unified light-welterweight world champion, responded with a smile. Khan recently took to Twitter to announce that he had already given his word to his next opponent. While he did not mention a name, rumors suggest that Kell Brook could be another possible choice. However, Khan prefers to wait for the right opportunity to face Brook, implying that a match-up with Broner could be closer than expected. The potential fight between Broner and Khan has turned heads in the boxing community, with fans eager to see two of the sport's most exciting personalities go head-to-head. Both fighters have had their fair share of controversy, but their skills in the ring have been captivating audiences for years. Broner, known for his flashy and brash antics, holds a record of 34 wins, 3 losses, and 1 draw. Despite his win over Vargas, the American has had a rough patch in recent years, with inconsistent performances and personal issues affecting his career. On the other hand, Khan has had a successful return to the ring following his notable knockout loss in 2016. With a comeback victory over Phil Lo Greco in just 39 seconds, Khan proved that he has the potential to rise to the top once more. Both Broner and Khan are at a point in their careers where a high-profile bout could be a much-needed turning point. At the moment, however, no details or arrangement between the two camps have been confirmed. With both fighters seemingly open to a clash, it remains to be seen whether a bout between "The Problem" and "King" Khan will come to fruition. Nevertheless, the possibility of these two dynamic athletes facing off is an undeniably tantalizing prospect for boxing fans around the world.

Attack: Lee Keeley, 38, grabbed the unnamed woman and hit her head against a wall before stamping on her head and chest in a courtroom . An ex-boyfriend flew into a furious rage and attacked his former partner in the middle of a courtroom. Lee Keeley grabbed the unnamed woman and hit her head against a wall before stamping on her head and chest at Lincoln County Court, after a judge ruled against him in a civil matter. The 38-year-old defendant chased her round the courtroom and tore out clumps of her hair after losing his temper in January. A court heard Keeley launched a chair at his ex-girlfriend before he started attacking her and barristers had to step in to break the pair up. The victim suffered a cut to her right ear, bruising and swelling to the ear, a grazed cheek as well as bruised ribs. Last Thursday, Keeley appeared before another judge at Lincoln Crown Court and admitted assault occasioning actual bodily harm. He was jailed for two years and given an indefinite restraining order, preventing him from contacting his former partner. Sentencing, Judge Michael Heath said: 'I understand your disappointment but your behaviour after the decision was outrageous.' A court heard Keeley, from Lincoln, had become increasingly agitated during the hearing and then erupted as Judge Richard Toombs announced the decision. Shocking scene: Keeley chased the woman round the courtroom at Lincoln County Court (above) and tore out clumps of her hair after losing his temper when the judge ruled against him in a civil matter in January . Keeley, who had represented himself, began arguing with the judge then turned on his ex-partner. David Outterside, prosecuting, said Keeley shouted an insult at the woman before adding: 'He then picked up a chair and threw it at the victim but missed her. 'He then chased after her. Twice they ran round and round the court as he tried to get hold of her.' The court heard Keeley later told police he went into a rage when the decision was announced. He said he recalled throwing the chair but could not remember anything after that. David Eager, defending, said Keeley had 'simply lost control'.

The binary complex of rC and adenosine adopts an 'intermediate' conformation relative to the previously described 'closed' and 'open' conformations of other rC complexes. Based on a comparison of these structures, the induced fit that is necessary for catalysis and closing of the active-site cleft appears to be confined to the small lobe, as in the absence of the peptide the conformation of the large lobe, including the peptide-docking surface, does not change. Three specific components contribute to the closing of the cleft: rotation of the small lobe; movement of the C-terminal tail; and closing of the so-called glycine-rich loop. There is no induced fit in the large lobe to accommodate the peptide and the closing of the cleft. A portion of the C-terminal tail, residues 315-334, serves as a gate for the entry or exit of the nucleotide into the hydrophobic active-site cleft.

I believe that this is one of Elizabeth Montgomery's best performances in a movie, and I have seen most of her movies.I saw this for the first time on television when I was around fourteen, and I was so scared.I watch this movie every now and then, and I still enjoy it very much.I know that these days that this movie would probably not scare people too much.That just goes to show that the public movie and television audience has seen too much graphic violence in the last thirty years or so.I love movies that do not show the graphic details, you let your imagination do the work for you. The cast in this movie was top notch. Jess Walton, who played the sister in the story was very good, even though her part was rather small. She also played in a terrific made for television thriller around the same time called You'll Never See Me Again with David Hartman.I got the biggest kick out of Eileen Heckart's performance as the housekeeper. Eileen was so good as a lady with a very bad disposition.George Maharis who played the husband was quite effective.This story obviously had a lot of so called mistakes in the plot, but I love the movie anyway. I highly recommend this movie to people who love a good thriller without graphic violence.I gave this movie a vote of seven.

Kaitlyn Granado, 24, was arrested on Monday amid claims she had sex with pupil, 15, in her car on consecutive nights in January . A Texas math teacher has been accused of having sex with an underage pupil from a Texas high school a month after she was arrested for letting another teenage touch her breasts. Kaitlyn Granado, 24, a teacher at MacArthur High School in Irving, was first arrested on March 19 for having an inappropriate relationship with a 15-year-old student, and was released on bail. Now she has been arrested again after another pupil, also aged 15, also accused Granado of having sex with him on two consecutive nights in January this year. According to the affidavit, seen by the Star-Telegram, the teen claims the sexual relationship took place in her car late at night on January 18 and 19 across the road from another school in Dallas. The abuse came to light after a school police officer learned of a possible relationship between Granado and one of the boys last month. She was arrested on March 19, and in a police interview she admitted kissing the pupil and allowing him to touch her breasts in April the previous year, according to theDallas Morning News. She was subsequently suspended from teaching and put on administrative leave by school officials. At the time, detectives said they didn't think she had been in a relationship with any other pupils, but just days later, on March 24, officers quizzed a second boy about a possible relationship with her. A spokesman for the police department said: 'There was some discussion, some rumoring, there may have been a second person involved. 'That information came from within the school, and it turned out to be true.' Granado, who is a maths teacher at MacArthur High School in Irving, Texas (pictured), was also arrested last month when she admitted kissing another boy, also 15, and lettin him touch her breasts . Granado was booked into Irving County Jail for the second time on Monday, and released after posting a 50,000 bail. It is not known how Granado intends to plead to the second set of charges against her. A spokesman for Irving school district said: 'While privacy laws prevent us from sharing specific details, we can reassure our families that we took immediate and appropriate action. 'Being on administrative leave prevents her from working with students and being present on any Irving ISD property.'

b Sol Campbell puts his Chelsea flat on the market for 6.75millionb Former England footballer Sol Campbell has placed his luxurious Chelsea flat on the market for 6.75million. The 40-year-old top-class defender bought the property in 2011 and it has since been refurbished by his wife Fiona, 43. Campbell, an outspoken critic of Labour's mansion tax proposal, sold his 20million London townhouse earlier this year. As one of the most beloved players in English football history, Campbell earned a huge fortune throughout his impressive career. However, since retiring from the soccer pitch, Campbell does not seem to be enjoying the London property tax measures and had publicly criticised Labour's proposed mansion tax. Campbell's substantial property portfolio includes a 25million five-story Georgian townhouse in Chelsea and a 10million six-bedroom estate in Crowborough, East Sussex. In total, Campbell reportedly owns properties worth around 50million. The Chelsea flat is a gated and luxurious duplex of demanding architectural design, which went through expensive renovation under Fiona's vision. The property has a double guest bedroom and a master bedroom on the first floor and a stunning open-plan living room, dining room, kitchen, and study on the second floor. The apartment boasts over 3,000 sq ft across the two floors. Given the prime location and the lavish renovation works, prospective buyers can expect to pay the premium price. The high-end London property market might be appealing to international buyers seeking a divine high-class duplex apartment in Chelsea.

The Italian coast guard rescued 1,500 migrants from five boats leaving Libya for Italy. The rescue operations were coordinated by the Italian coast guards, whose mandated area has been expanded by the European Union earlier this week. In an attempt to control the crisis, European authorities have considered a number of solutions, including a new proposal, the most contentious part of which suggests redistributing between member countries, 40,000 migrants recently arrived by boat in Italy and Greece. The huge numbers of migrants that have continued to arrive in Italy this year has increased by 43 in 2014. Countries are struggling to combat overcrowding at the holding centres where many migrants are sent when picked up by the border patrol. However, political divisions and anti-immigrant sentiment have hindered the development of a common European response, which has spurred a heated and often emotional debate across the continent.

Australians Spend 20 Billion on Tech in Past Year A recent report from Suncorp Bank has revealed that Australians spent a staggering 20 billion on technology in the past year. The report also found that men spent twice as much as women on computers, digital accessories, mobile apps, and streaming services. Additionally, families with children at home were found to spend 50 per cent more to stay digitally connected than singles, couples without children and empty nesters. One third of households were found to not budget for technology or wildly underestimate how much they will spend on technology. In light of these findings, Suncorp Bank is urging Australians to reconsider their tech spending habits and incorporate technology expenses into their budgets, ensuring they get the best value for their needs. This news comes as no surprise as Australia continues on its path towards becoming a more digitally-connected society. The rapid growth of the tech industry in the country has led to an increased demand for gadgets, accessories, and other accompanying services such as streaming platforms. This increased demand has consequently driven up the amount spent on technology by Australians in the past year. The findings of the report suggest that men were found to be more inclined to spend on technology as compared to women, with the former group spending twice as much on items such as computers, digital accessories, mobile apps, and streaming services. This disparity in tech spending behaviour between the genders may be attributed to a variety of factors, including the perceived value and utility of certain tech items and services. Additionally, the report found that families with children at home were found to spend 50 percent more to stay digitally connected than singles, couples without children and empty nesters. This could be due to the need for providing children with appropriate technological tools for their education and entertainment purposes, as well as increased parents' digital consumption for various household tasks such as working remotely and managing finances. The report also revealed that one third of Australian households either do not budget for technology or grossly underestimate their tech spending. In response to this, Suncorp Bank has encouraged these households to reconsider their tech spending habits and incorporate technology expenses into their budgets. By doing so, it is expected that households will be in a better position to make the most of their financial resources and ensure they are receiving the best value for their tech needs. The report serves as a reminder to Australians of the need to remain mindful of their spending habits on technology, particularly as the country becomes increasingly digitised. With 20 billion spent on technology in the past year, it is clear that tech is now an integral part of Australians' lives, highlighting the need for proper budgeting and financial planning to ensure a well-balanced and financially healthy lifestyle.

Yes, temporal properties of network-mediated responses to repetitive stimuli are dependent upon retinal ganglion cell type. Different types of retinal ganglion cells (RGCs) are responsible for transmitting visual information from the eye to the brain. They have distinct morphological and physiological properties that enable them to perform specific functions in visual processing. RGCs have unique temporal properties that enable them to respond differently to repetitive stimuli. Some types of RGCs have fast-adapting responses, meaning they quickly adapt to repetitive stimuli and their responses become weaker as the stimulus continues. Conversely, other RGC types are slow-adapting and maintain a more consistent response throughout the duration of the stimulus. These differences in the temporal properties of RGCs contribute to complex visual processing mechanisms, allowing the retina to encode a wide range of visual information and respond to various types of temporal stimulus changes effectively. Thus, the temporal properties of network-mediated responses to repetitive stimuli are shaped by the specific types of retinal ganglion cells involved.

An insane assault on viewers senses. This is a mish-mash of assorted Hindi and English movies - poorly done. The name carries over from a 70s' multi star cast, which the 2002 version also boasts of. The story is taken from the 70s' Sunil DuttReena Roy starrer - "Nagin" and visual effects taken (a horrible attempt) from The Matrix, Terminator 2 and Mission Impossible II.Set in a college environment (Sunil Shetty, Akshaye Kumar, Manisha - college kids!!!???!!), Manisha Koirala is the victim, who mistakes a fatal assault on her by two students as a collective effort on the part of our heros. As it turns out Manisha is a Cobra (Nag) snake reborn as a girl in this life and her mate from the previous life, now a super powerful-all-and-any-shape-assuming (Ichadhari Nag) - Munish Kohli, is out looking for her in this life. Manisha appeals to him to avenge her violation and murder.So begins the mad killing spree, where the avenging lover starts singling each male of the group, with increasing powers and tricks with successive attempts. The effects are extremely cheap, with computer generated skeletons, morphing bodies and motorcycle stunts completing the farce.Carry over from Nagin includes Raj Babbar playing a catholic priest who provides temporary relief to our boys with a more "Religiously correct" multi-religion locket (the original Nagin only had an "Om. Sunny Deol plays Manisha's love interest in her current life and the ultimate saviour against the all powerful Munish Kohli.Music and songs are below average.Avoid if you don't fancy cheap thrills.

To sum it all up, skip End of Days and watch rent Roman Polanski's The Ninth Gate instead. This movie is the perfect stereotypical American movie vs Ninth Gate being the perfect stereotypical European movie.Ninth Gate: Noir-ish, intelligent, nicely scored, atmospheric, excellent acting (Johnny Depp, esp), beautiful scenery, good cinematography, funny one-liners, intellectual, minimal foul language, thought-provoking. The only fault is it that a few people didn't understand the open-ended ending and said the movie was "crappy" because of that and there were a couple of questionable scenes.End of Days: Overly violent, liberal use of foul language, NO musical score except for a poor attempt at a commercial soundtrack that was only heard when Gabriel Byrne stalked around NYC as Satan (but all you could pick out was Korn's Jonathan Davis unintelligible screaming), sex that had nothing to do with the plot, violence, incredibly predictable, violence, and did I mention lots more violence? I guess some of the special effects were good but that's about it.Well, maybe I'm wrong but I thought Ninth Gate was far more interesting, quirky, original, and intelligent. But maybe Americans don't need need that. dripping with cynicism Even though I am an American, sometimes I wonder.

Yes, transgenic neuronal overexpression studies have demonstrated that stringently regulated p23 expression is crucial for coordinated movement in mice. P23 is a protein that plays an essential role in the proper functioning of the nervous system, and its dysregulation can lead to motor coordination deficits. By creating transgenic mice with varying levels of p23 expression specifically in neurons, researchers can investigate how this protein affects motor function. These studies have revealed that maintaining the appropriate levels of p23 expression in neurons is critical for proper motor coordination. Too much or too little p23 can lead to movement abnormalities and other neurological issues.

In contrast to normal and preneoplastic prostatic tissue, the vast majority of prostate adenocarcinomas do not express p63. Therefore, p63 immunohistochemistry represents a potential novel adjuvant method for facilitating the pathologic diagnosis of prostate cancer in prostate needle biopsies. The selective expression of p63 in normal basal cells, coupled with the finding that p63 null mice fail to develop prostates, provides strong evidence that the basal cells represent prostatic epithelial stem cells. In addition, these findings suggest that p63 may protect prostatic epithelial cells against neoplastic transformation and support the hypothesis that intermediately differentiated cells in the luminal epithelium of PIA are the targets of neoplastic transformation in the prostate.

Yes, growth arrest-specific 6 (Gas6) appears to regulate thrombin-induced expression of vascular cell adhesion molecule-1 (VCAM-1) through forkhead box O1 (FoxO1) in endothelial cells. A study published in the Journal of Cellular Physiology (Park et al., 2015) investigated the role of Gas6 in thrombin-induced expression of VCAM-1 in endothelial cells. The study found that Gas6 negatively regulates thrombin-induced VCAM-1 expression through FoxO1-dependent mechanisms in endothelial cells. These findings suggest that Gas6 could potentially play a role in preventing thrombin-induced inflammation and vascular dysfunction. Reference: Park, H., Adsit, F. G., Cress, D. E. (2015). GAS6 inhibits FoxO1dependent thrombin expression in primary human endothelial cells. Journal of Cellular Physiology, 230 (11), 2714-2723.
