Dominic Solanke scores twice as Chelsea U19s defeat Roma in UEFA Youth League semi-final Chelsea's youth team advanced to the UEFA Youth League final last night after putting on an impressive display against Roma, winning 4-0. Adi Viveash's side is now just one victory away from achieving the back-to-back European titles as they prepare to face Shakhtar Donetsk in the final match of the UEFA Youth League. The star of the night was Dominic Solanke, the 18-year-old Chelsea youth striker who scored two fantastic goals and showcased his immense talent in front of an ecstatic crowd at the Cobham Training Centre. The strong line-up of Chelsea players included Mason Mount, Kyle Scott, Jay Dasilva, and Dujon Sterling, who all contributed immensely to the victory. Chelsea controlled the game from the outset, with their first clear opportunity in the 12th minute when a shot from Solanke was saved by the goalkeeper, only for his follow-up attempt to balloon over the bar. However, it didn't take long for the young Englishman to find the net, as he broke the deadlock in the 23rd minute with a powerful header from a brilliant cross by Charlie Wakefield. Solanke notched his second goal just eight minutes later when he calmly rounded Roma goalkeeper Stefano Greco and cleared the ball into an open net. Further goals came from Fikayo Tomori in the 50th minute and Charlie Colkett in the 63rd which left Roma without any hope of coming back into the tie. Chelsea's manager, Adi Viveash, praised the team's performance: "It was an outstanding display. We dominated the game from start to finish and didn't allow Roma much of a chance to get close to us. We knew we had the quality to go all the way in this competition, and today we showed it." Shakhtar Donetsk will be a tough opponent in the final, having reached the final stages of this competition last season too. Their semi-final victory over Anderlecht was impressive, coming back from 3-1 down to win 4-3, so Chelsea U19s have a challenging task ahead of them. However, with talented youngsters like Dominic Solanke leading the team, Chelsea fans have every reason to be optimistic about their chances of lifting the UEFA Youth League trophy for the second year running.

Although the SFU grading system is considered the predominant grading system for HN, its application in clinical practice has been inconsistent. While this may be due to the grading system itself, it is possible that deficient training and confidence are the root causes. Our data supports this by demonstrating that most clinicians receive only casual training and accordingly, report low confidence in their knowledge and ability to grade HN. Therefore, we conclude that there exists a strong need to improve the teaching of the SFU grading system. e-Learning has been shown to be effective in teaching difficult topics and skills. We demonstrate that e-Learning with CEVL is effective in increasing both the confidence and accuracy of SFU grading of pediatric HN. Limitations of our study include a small sample size, low response rate, and discrepant participation. Furthermore, we did not assess the extent to which the CEVL module was used or include a control group learning through traditional means. Therefore, we were unable to evaluate the efficiency of learning or be certain that the improvements seen were derived exclusively from CEVL.

Yes, deregulation of the phosphatase PP2A is a common event in breast cancer, and it has been observed to predict sensitivity to FTY720. FTY720, also known as Fingolimod, is an immunosuppressive drug used to treat multiple sclerosis and shows potential as a breast cancer therapy. Research has found that PP2A is often deregulated in breast cancer and its reactivation can lead to tumor suppression. FTY720 can reactivate PP2A signaling and has shown to have an inhibitory effect on breast cancer cells. In multiple studies, breast cancer cells with deregulated PP2A are observed to be more sensitive to FTY720 treatment. Therefore, deregulation of PP2A can be considered a predictive factor for sensitivity to FTY720 in breast cancer therapy.

A plane passenger got the shock of his life when he assaulted a man who was a former corrections officer. Chad Hurst of Salt Lake City, Utah, says he pulled the young man aside after their flight from Denver, Colorado had landed on Sunday, and had a word with him about the foul language he had been using on the plane. That is when the young man, who was carrying a skateboard, sucker punched Hurst. Scroll down for video . Good Samaritan: Chad Hurst (right in hat) spoke to a young man about his foul language during their flight when they landed in Salt Lake City on Sunday . Lashing out: The young man then sucker punched Hurst in the stomach (above) Hurst then calmly proceeded to grab the young man by the shoulder, bring him to the ground, put his hands behind his back and get on top of him until police arrived on the scene. CBS Denver reports the young man was then charged withassault and public intoxication. 'In a former life I was a corrections officer about 10 years ago and my training was to never punch back. It was to control the situation and to take the person down,' said Hurst. That is just what Hurst did too, with the entire incident lasting just a few seconds before the young man was on the ground. Taking him down: Hurst, a former corrections officer, then grabbed the young man (above) and took him down . Taken in: The young man, who has still not been named by police, was charged with assault and public intoxication . As for what prompted the young man to hit him, Hurst later explained on Twitter; 'I asked him kindly to stop being vulgar.' The young man has yet to be named by police.

There is evidence to suggest that nerve growth factor (NGF) can play a role in the innervation of perivascular nerves in tumor-derived neovasculature in the mouse cornea. NGF is a well-known player in the development, survival, and function of neurons. Studies have shown that NGF can promote angiogenesis, or the formation of new blood vessels, and that it may be involved in the innervation of newly formed blood vessels. In the context of tumor-derived neovasculature, it is possible that NGF could facilitate the growth of perivascular nerves. A study published in 1998 by Cohen et al. investigated the role of NGF in the innervation of blood vessels in the mouse cornea. This study used an in vivo model in which they implanted a pellet containing NGF into the cornea of mice and observed its effects on the growth of blood vessels and nerves. They found that NGF promoted the formation of new blood vessels, known as neovasculature, and that there was a significant increase in the innervation of these new vessels by perivascular nerves when compared to a control group. This research supports the idea that NGF could facilitate the innervation of perivascular nerves in tumor-derived neovasculature in the mouse cornea. However, more research would be needed to confirm the role of NGF in specifically tumor-derived neovasculature, as opposed to neovasculature that is formed in response to other stimuli. Additionally, it is important to consider the many complex factors involved in the formation of blood vessels and nerves and to investigate the roles of other growth factors and signaling pathways in this process.

There is some evidence to suggest that resistance to Echinostoma caproni secondary infections in mice may be related to ileal protein production, particularly in the production of specific immune proteins. Echinostoma caproni is a parasitic trematode that infects the small intestines of rodents, causing echinostomiasis. Mice can develop resistance to secondary infections due to the immune response generated during the primary infection. This resistance is often attributed to the production of specific immune proteins such as cytokines, chemokines, and antibodies involved in the host's defense against parasites. One study (Cortes et al., 2017) showed that during the primary infection of mice with Echinostoma caproni, there was an upregulation of several cytokines and immune mediators, which led to a reduction of worm burden in secondary infections. In addition, other research has demonstrated that production of certain cytokines, like interleukin-13 (IL-13), can cause an increased mucus production, smooth muscle contraction, and increased epithelial cell turnover, which may contribute to the expulsion of parasites from the gut (Dawson et al., 2005). Overall, while there is evidence to suggest a relationship between ileal protein production and resistance to Echinostoma caproni secondary infections in mice, more research is needed to fully understand the mechanisms behind this resistance. References: Cortes, A., Munoz-Antoli, C., Esteban, J. G., Toledo, R. (2017). Th2 and Th1 responses: clear and hidden sides of immunity against intestinal helminths. Trends in parasitology, 33 (8), 678-693. Dawson, H. D., Beshah, E., Nishi, S., Solano-agama, C., Morimoto, M., Zhao, A., ... Urban, J. F. (2005). Localized multigene expression patterns support an evolving Th1Th2-like paradigm in response to infections with Toxoplasma gondii and Ascaris suum. Infection and immunity, 73 (2), .

This film isn't supposed to be funny, but it made me laugh.It isn't designed to be sad, but my heart felt heavy through a number of the vignettes.It isn't written as action adventure, but my pulse raced more than once.Just like life, this movie doesn't manipulate your emotions and tell you how to feel. It simply is, and you react.If you don't find it funny or sad or moving, I suspect that says more about you than the film.It amazing and refreshing to see a director so wholeheartedly celebrate that we are all human, and embrace that we are all trapped here, doing this "life" thing, over and over for as long as we must.Tomorrow is another day.

Even though some unrealistic things happen at the end (i.e. a cop shooting a gun into a crowded merry-go-round where any number of innocent could be killed), this still was an intense, enjoyable thriller, one of Alfred Hitchcock's better films. Robert Walker is excellent as the chilling nutcase, really convincing giving a fascinating performance that is almost too creepy at times. His co-star in here, Farley Granger, is okay but is no match for Walker, either in acting or in the characters they play. It's the typical Hitchcock film with some strange camera angles, immoral themes, innocent man gets in trouble, etc. Unlike a lot of his other films, I thought this one was a fast-moving story with a very few dull spots. Being an ex-tennis player, I enjoyed his footage of some excellent old net matches that featured some good rallies. Hitchcock's real-life daughter Patricia has an interesting and unique minor character role in here. She didn't just get the job because of her dad; she can act. Also of note: the DVD has both the British and American versions and there were some differences in the story. This is a classic film that is still referred to in modern-day films, even comedies such as "Throw Momma Off The Train."

The body of an autistic 20-year-old who left his home 44 days ago and never returned has been found floating in a creek near a golf course. Eagle Scout Brian Gewirtz told his family he was going for a walk near his Brooklyn, New York, home on February 17, but didn't come back. His family started a frantic search in the local community, warning people of his disability which made it hard for him to understand spoken language. Eagle Scout Brian Gewirtz told his family he was going for a walk near is Brooklyn, New York, home on February 17, but didn't come back . But police said Friday his body had been discovered at Marine Park Golf Club, just two miles from his home. Laura Rivera, Brian's godmother, told ABC 7: 'He was so thoughtful, and if you were sad he would sit with you for hours just hugging you and saying I love you. 'He was over 18 yes, but he had the mind of a very much younger person because of his disability, and lots of people didn't understand that and there really needs to be a law just like an amber alert. Police suspect he wandered into Marine Park back in mid-February and got disoriented. The freezing temperatures at the time mean hypothermia could also have contributed to his death. A worker in the pro shop told The New York Postthe body was found near the eight hole and came up with the tide. Gewirtz's family and friends offered a 5,000 reward if he was found alive. His family started a frantic search in the local community, warning people of his disability which made it hard for him to understand spoken language . Police said his body had been discovered at Marine Park Golf Club (pictured), just two miles from his home .

This film has the language, the style, and the attitude down... plus great rides from Occy (a world champ) and the great Jerry Lopez. "Surf's Up Supreme" is an exhilarating ride that takes viewers on an adrenaline-pumping journey to catch the perfect wave. The film not only delivers awe-inspiring surfing performances, but also offers an inside look at the sport's culture, camaraderie, and competitive spirit. The cinematography is breathtaking, capturing the raw power of the ocean, the grace of the surfers, and the stunning landscapes of exotic surf destinations. The soundtrack compliments this visual feast with a perfect blend of classic surf tunes and adrenaline-pumping rock music that creates a nostalgic, yet modern ambiance. What really sets "Surf's Up Supreme" apart from other surf films is its engaging narrative. The director skillfully weaves together the personal stories of the featured surfers, exploring their motivations, fears, and the brotherhood that bonds them. Occy and Jerry Lopez's presence adds an authentic touch, as they share their wisdom and insights into the world of professional surfing. Moreover, the movie does not shy away from addressing critical issues like environmental concerns and the commercialization of the sport. It encourages viewers to reflect on their relationship with nature while appreciating the ocean's beauty and power. All in all, "Surf's Up Supreme" is a thrilling and visually stunning tribute to the surf culture of past and present. It is a must-see for anyone who appreciates the skill, dedication, and passion of these incredible athletes and the mesmerizing world of surfing. With its seamless blend of storytelling, sports action, and vibrant cinematography, this film will leave you craving more waves and adventures. Surf's up!

There is limited research available on the specific impact of completing review questions on American Board of Surgery In-Training Exam (ABSITE) scores. However, a combination of effective study habits, including completing review questions, does have a positive impact on academic performance. A study by Kim et al. (2017), titled "Surgery Resident Learning Styles and Academic Achievement," found that incorporating a variety of study strategies, addressing different learning styles, resulted in higher ABSITE scores. Another study by Goudreau et al. (2018), titled "Factors Associated with General Surgery Residents' Operative Experience and Absite Performance," found that residents scoring above the median on the ABSITE had a mean of 3.6 study resources compared to those below the median, who used a mean of 1.8 resources. While there is no concrete evidence focusing exclusively on completing review questions, these studies indicate that using multiple study methods, including review questions, can lead to higher ABSITE scores.

2001: A Space Odyssey - Is it a sermon? In many ways, this masterpiece by acclaimed director Stanley Kubrick can be seen as a thought-provoking and spiritual journey through the vastness of space and time. Originally released in 1968, the film's themes and messages still resonate with audiences today. Visually, 2001: A Space Odyssey is simply stunning. The use of practical effects, models, and pioneering filmmaking techniques sets the film apart from its contemporaries. The meticulous attention to detail and realism, combined with the hypnotic soundtrack, only serves to enhance the feeling of solitude and wonder that space exploration naturally invokes. The film's story and pacing, though slow and methodical, are purposeful and thought-provoking. As the plot unfolds, viewers are taken on a journey through the cosmos that challenges them to consider humanity's place in the universe, the nature of intelligence, and the consequences of relying too heavily on technology. The main antagonist, the HAL 9000 computer, serves as a cautionary tale, reminding viewers that unchecked progress may come at a heavy cost. 2001: A Space Odyssey also poses a spiritual aspect, most notably with the mysterious monoliths. These towering, enigmatic black slabs appear to catalyze evolutionary changes and advancement in the species they encounter. This narrative thread can be interpreted as a divine intervention of sorts, guiding the human race through critical stages in their development. Aside from its philosophical themes, the film has left a significant impact on popular culture and the science fiction genre as a whole. Many subsequent films and television shows have paid homage, or even directly referenced, the narrative and iconic imagery of 2001: A Space Odyssey. In conclusion, 2001: A Space Odyssey can indeed be considered a sermon of sorts - a film dedicated to exploring the vast, unknown reaches of space, as well as the inward journey of self-discovery and evolution that is intrinsic to the human experience. So, sit back, relax, and surrender yourself to the magnificent sights, sounds, and thought-provoking ideas of this timeless classic.

Seriously, I had the best cinematic experience in years after watching "Timeless Tales." The movie is a stunning masterpiece that transports the audience to a new world filled with captivating stories, vibrant colors, and top-notch visuals. The uniquely interconnected stories are phenomenal, skillfully written, and leave the viewer with a longing to learn more about each character's journey. The fantastic ensemble of actors breathes life into each role, creating an emotional connection between themselves and the viewers. The film's visuals are breathtaking, showcasing gorgeous landscapes and fantastical elements that blend seamlessly with the live-action performances. The directors successfully guide the audience through various environments, making the experience both immersive and enchanting. Musically, "Timeless Tales" delivers a rich and whimsical score. It perfectly complements the visuals and enhances the overall atmosphere of the movie. The songs are catchy and, by the end of the film, will have audience members unconsciously humming the tunes. In conclusion, "Timeless Tales" is a phenomenal film, a must-watch for moviegoers who enjoy creative storytelling and compelling visuals. It's a captivating cinematic masterpiece that leaves viewers mesmerized and thirsty for more.

The origin of life is a highly debated topic with various theories and hypotheses, one of which is the idea of a spatially localized stochastic transition. This concept suggests that the formation of life emerged in a particular location, essentially by chance, as a result of specific environmental conditions and molecular interactions. In this view, life's emergence is seen as a stochastic event, meaning that it is the outcome of random processes and the probability of it occurring could be very low. This perspective on the origin of life does not necessarily point to a single, universally agreed-upon mechanism but recognizes that particular spatial conditions and molecular interactions might have played a significant role in the development of living organisms. However, there are alternative theories for the origin of life, such as those involving extraterrestrial delivery of organic materials, deep-sea hydrothermal vent environments, or other non-stochastic chemical processes. The complex nature of life and the extensive timescales that preceded it makes this question challenging to answer definitively. Nonetheless, the idea of a spatially localized stochastic transition is one possible hypothesis for the emergence of life on Earth.

(CNN) Jason Rezaian has sat in jail in Iran for nearly nine months. The Washington Post's bureau chief in Tehran was arrested in July on unspecified allegations. It took more than four months for a judge to hear charges against him. They remained publicly undisclosed until last week. The Iranian-American will be tried soon on espionage, Tehran's chief justice said. He is accused of economic spying, the Post reported, citing Iranian state media. The Washington Post did not mince words on the allegation. "Any charges of that sort would be absurd, the product of fertile and twisted imaginations," the paper said in a statement. The State Department also reacted with term "absurd" after hearing of reports in Iran's press about the charges. "If the reports are true, these charges are absurd, should be immediately dismissed and Jason should be immediately freed so that he can return to his family," the State Department official said. Since officers picked up Rezaian and his wife, Yeganeh Salehi, on July 22 at their home, the Post, the State Department and Rezaian's family have protested and called for his release. Salehi was released on bail in October. Rezaian was denied bail. And for months, he was denied access to proper legal representation, his family has said. Boxing great Muhammad Ali, also an American Muslim, appealed to Tehran last month to give Rezaian full access to legal representation and free him on bail. "To my knowledge, Jason is a man of peace and great faith, a man whose dedication and respect for the Iranian people is evident in his work," Ali said in a religiously worded statement. The journalist has also not been allowed to see visitors aside from his wife and has endured long interrogations, family members have said. In December, after a 10-hour hearing, Rezaian signed a paper to acknowledge that he understood the charges against him, the Post reported. Iran's human rights chief, Mohammad Javad Larijani, told news outlet France 24 last year that he hoped Rezaian's case would come to a positive conclusion. He said, "Let us hope that this fiasco will end on good terms." More on detained Americans . CNN's Sara Mazloumsaki and Azadeh Ansari contributed to this report.

I am not a big fan of the SpielbergCruise version of this film, but I must admit that "War of the Worlds" boasts some truly impressive visuals and a captivating performance from Tom Cruise. While the storyline strays quite far from the original H.G. Wells novel, the film still manages to convey the distressing, chaotic mood of a full-blown alien invasion. Cruise delivers a strong performance as Ray Ferrier, a troubled, blue-collar father struggling to protect his two children through the chaos. Dakota Fanning and Justin Chatwin, who play Ferrier's children, also showcase some great acting chops and their performances are a cut above the usual portrayal of children in crisis. However, the film's great downfall lies in the veering away from the source material, which results in key characters and events being changed or omitted entirely. Furthermore, it feels like Spielberg is sidetracked by the big-budget Hollywood action tropes, resulting in an overreliance on jump scares and CGI spectacles rather than the suspenseful psychological horror of the original story. The film does make an attempt at exploring some deeper themes, such as the human ability to survive and the bonds of family, but these themes often get lost amidst the whirlwind of destruction. Shamefully, the ending seems rushed and counterintuitive, leaving viewers with a sense of disappointment. In conclusion, this version of "War of the Worlds" is an entertaining, high-octane roller coaster ride that is visually stunning and bolstered by the strong acting prowess of Tom Cruise, Dakota Fanning, and Justin Chatwin. Yet, the movie falls short of its potential in terms of storyline and thematic development. It is worth watching for its visual thrills, but those who seek a faithful adaptation of H.G. Wells' novel will be left disappointed.

As I watched this movie, I felt as if a plastic bag was slowly closing in around my head. The acting was horribly stifling, and it was Bad Acting. The most brilliant piece of acting in the entire film was the guy who had to play laid-out-in-state-in-a-coffin. I felt nothing but relief when it was finally over. I was expecting that this film was going to be some real tragedy, with some deep psychological intrigue in the aftermath. All around it was stupid, no beginning, no climax, no ending, just rambling on and on, and the plastic bag kept getting worse. Let's get real here. This is an awful movie.

Mean T2T1 was 4.7 for EGFR-amplified glioblastomas, greater than that of TP53-mutated glioblastomas (2.3) or non-TP53non-EGFR glioblastomas (2.6; P0.00005). All four tumors with T2T17.2 were EGFR-amplified; 0 of 15 with T2T14.7 underwent gross total resection. The mean T2 BSC of EGFR-amplified glioblastomas was 33.7, less sharp (P) than TP53-mutated (72.2) and non-TP53non-EGFR glioblastomas (81.2). All 15 glioblastomas with T2 BSC30.8 were EGFR-amplified. Percentage necrosis and T1 BSC did not differ between glioblastoma subtypes. The increased T2T1 ratio and decreased T2 BSC in EGFR-overexpressing tumors are the first radiographic distinctions described between glioblastoma molecular subtypes. These findings may reflect increased angiogenesis, edema, andor invasion in EGFR-overexpressing tumors.

Intersectionality provides a framework for understanding the experiences of dual stigma and discrimination faced by MSM living with HIV in Swaziland and highlights how programmes and policies should consider the specific needs of this population when designing HIV prevention, care and treatment services. In Swaziland, the health sector should consider providing specialized training for healthcare providers, distributing condoms and lubricants and engaging MSM as peer outreach workers or expert clients. Interventions to reduce stigma, discrimination and violence against MSM and people living with HIV are also needed for both healthcare workers and the general population. Finally, research on experiences and needs of MSM living with HIV globally can help inform comprehensive HIV services for this population.

Yes, beta-Arrestin2 regulates the differential response of cortical and trabecular bone to intermittent PTH in female mice. A study by Liu et al. (2015) found that loss of beta-arrestin2 in female mice led to a blunted anabolic response to intermittent PTH treatment, specifically in trabecular bone. This study concluded that beta-arrestin2 is a critical regulator of the anabolic effects of intermittent PTH on trabecular bone and that it's required for the differential response of cortical and trabecular bone to intermittent PTH treatment in female mice. Reference: Liu, S., Virdi, A. S., Sena, K., Hughes, W. F., Sumner, D. R., Ross, F. P. (2015). beta-Arrestin2 Regulates the Differential Response of Cortical and Trabecular Bone to Intermittent PTH in Female Mice. Journal of Bone and Mineral Research, 30 (2), 325-339.

Yes, chronic pain can affect the whole person, considering various aspects - physically, mentally, emotionally, and socially. A phenomenological study aims to understand the lived experiences of individuals with chronic pain and how it impacts their lives. This kind of study investigates the individual's unique perceptions, beliefs, and interpretations of their chronic pain and its effects on their daily life. Some common themes emerging from such studies are as follows: 1. Physical impact: Chronic pain restricts physical activities, mobility, and performance of daily tasks. People may experience fatigue, sleep disturbances, and a decline in overall health. 2. Emotional impact: Chronic pain increases vulnerability to negative emotions such as anxiety, depression, frustration, and anger. These emotions can intensify the pain and affect the overall quality of life. 3. Cognitive impact: People with chronic pain may experience difficulties in concentration, decision-making, and memory. These cognitive changes can further aggravate the emotional and physical consequences of pain. 4. Social impact: Chronic pain can lead to social isolation, impacting relationships with family and friends. People may withdraw from social participation, which can exacerbate feelings of loneliness, depression, and anxiety. 5. Spiritual or existential impact: Chronic pain can also lead to deep existential and spiritual questioning. Some people may struggle to find meaning and purpose in their lives, while others may experience renewed faith or spiritual growth. 6. Coping strategies: Individuals with chronic pain often rely on various coping strategies such as medication, alternative treatments, cognitive-behavioral strategies, or seeking support from friends and family. The effectiveness of these strategies can vary, and it is crucial to determine individual preferences and needs. In conclusion, a phenomenological study can help shed light on the complex and multifaceted ways in which chronic pain affects the whole person. Understanding these experiences can inform better treatment approaches and support for individuals living with chronic pain.

Yemeni Houthi rebels announced on Friday that fighters will not withdraw from major cities, as stated by the leader of the Iran-aligned Islamist movement. Abdul-Malik al-Houthi, leader of the Houthi militia, said in a televised address that the fighters will not abide by the humanitarian ceasefire in the four-year-long war. "The fighters will not move out, so long as there is no trust in the other parties who hold power. No retreat, no surrender!" al-Houthi announced in his heavily guarded residence in the town of Al-Durayhimi, South of Hudaydah. The speech came moments after a breakthrough in the talks in Muscat, Oman. Saudi-led, UN-organized peace negotiations over the weekend, which brought Yemen's internationally recognized Yemeni Government and the Iran-backed Houthi rebels to the table, aimed to halt fighting in the flashpoint city of Hudaydah. However, the Yemeni government, which is backed by a US-supported Saudi-led coalition, has already staged a partial withdrawal. In another development today, Brigadier General Tariq Saleh pledged his support to Yemen's ousted President. Tariq, nephew of the slain ex-President Ali Abdullah Saleh, emphasized in a statement released by his office that his fighters will focus on "liberating the remaining cities under the control of Houthi militia." The move emphasizes the divisions within the country, as the exiled President Abd-Rabbu Mansour Hadi and his separatist rivals struggle for control over the Yemeni provinces as well as the capital Aden. The Yemen war has killed more than 10,000 people since 2015, many of them civilians, in an alarming humanitarian crisis in the Arab region's poorest country. The crisis intensified after Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates led a coalition to overthrow the Iran-backed Houthi rebels who ousted the government-backed Hadi from Sana'a, Yemen's traditional capital. Iranian State TV has so far accused the Saudi-led coalition of numerous attacks on civilian targets such as markets and schools. The US, a key backer to the coalition, has been providing them with intelligence and logistical support but facing strong criticism by even its own officials. Despite the recent developments in peace talks, fighters remain on the strategic port city of Hudaydah, Yemen's fourth-largest city and a densely populated stronghold of the Houthi rebels. Al-Houthi also blamed the international community for "holding back peace" and failing to address the country's food crisis, energy, and water shortages faced by millions of Yemeni people today.

It is truly saddening to see a once-great director such as Deodato delivering such a second-rate giallo such as this. "Giallo Fiasco" had the potential to be a riveting murder mystery with all the classic elements of the giallo genre - suspense, stylish kills, and twists and turns. However, it falls short of expectations, feeling uninspired and riddled with cliches. The film's protagonist - a detective on the brink of retirement - is immediately recognized as a tired trope and Deodato fails to give him any depth or originality. The supporting characters are equally thin, making it nearly impossible to get invested in the story or care about who will survive until the closing credits. What is most shocking, however, is Deodato's mishandling of the bloodshed and gore that usually serves as the backbone of a giallo film. The kills lack any creativity or flair, resorting to cheap jumps scares and unconvincing special effects. It is as if Deodato's spark for innovation and artistic vision has been extinguished. The only redeeming aspect of "Giallo Fiasco" may be its vibrant color palette and visually striking shots, harking back to the golden age of giallo and Italian horror. Unfortunately, even those visuals are unable to save the film from utter mediocrity. "Giallo Fiasco" is an unfortunate letdown, a stain on the legacy of a once-acclaimed director. Deodato fans will be left with a bitter taste in their mouths, wondering where the genius behind classics like "Cannibal Holocaust" and "The House on the Edge of the Park" has gone. Save yourself the disappointment and watch a classic giallo instead.

An enormous 400lb, 11ft-long alligator has been removed from a family's backyard pond in Beaumont, Texas, by Gary Saurage, the owner of the Gator Country wildlife park. Saurage, 45, responded to an emergency call from the family on Monday morning, where he proceeded to apprehend the giant reptile using only his bare hands. A photograph of the captivating capture, which shows Saurage looking directly into the eyes of the alligator, was later shared on Facebook. The giant alligator will now be housed at the Gator Country wildlife park, which allows visitors to observe these magnificent creatures up close. Saurage hopes that the alligator's presence will help to educate people about alligators and their importance within the native ecosystems. Despite their impressive size and predatory nature, alligators are generally shy creatures that avoid contact with humans. However, as their habitats have been reduced due to human encroachment, these animals have been forced to live closer to people, leading to an increased risk of encounters. In Texas, alligator populations have bounced back from near extinction in the 1960s to an estimated 500,000 today, thanks to habitat conservation efforts. However, as these numbers continue to rise and expand, so do the number of human-alligator interactions, compelling local authorities to provide guidelines on how to safely coexist with the reptiles. Overall, captures such as this shine a light on the importance of understanding and coexisting with alligators, as well as highlighting the dedication of wildlife experts like Gary Saurage to protect and conserve these incredible animals.

The jury is rapidly nearing a verdict in Aaron Hernandez's murder trial after the defense team presented their entire case in just one day. Prosecution took two months and more than 100 pieces of evidence to accuse the former New England Patriots player of killing Odin Lloyd, who was shot six times in the chest and back on June 17, 2013. Defending his not guilty plea, Hernandez's lawyers called five witnesses to testify on Monday before resting at 3pm. Following tomorrow's closing statements, the jury will deliberate on their verdict. Scroll down for video . Nearing the end: Aaron Hernandez's defense team took just one day to deliver their case against prosecutors who spent two months producing 100 pieces of evidence. Hernandez has pleaded not guilty to killing Odin Lloyd . Lloyd was dating the sister of Hernandez's fiancee. At the time of the killing, in an industrial park near Hernandez's North Attleborough home, the tight end had a 40 million contract with the Patriots. The defense's first witness was Dr. David Greenblatt, a professor at Tufts University School of Medicine, who testified that the drug PCP can cause people to be suddenly violent, even days after smoking it. Hernandez's two co-defendants, Ernest Wallace and Carlos Ortiz, were seen smoking PCP a few days before the crime. Both men have pleaded not guilty and will be tried later. Prosecutor Patrick Bomberg went after Greenblatt's testimony, showing surveillance video of Ortiz, Wallace and Hernandez from Hernandez's home before and immediately after the killing. In the videos, the men do not appear to be acting strangely. The former New England Patriots smiles during his murder trial at the Bristol County Superior Court . The judge has said she expects closing arguments to be delivered on Tuesday or Wednesday . 'This is essentially three minutes after the murder - you'd expect to see something lingering of PCP psychosis or intoxication,' Bomberg said, asking if Greenblatt could detect such behavior. 'You just can't tell,' Greenblatt replied. Testimony by two other witnesses related to DNA on a shell casing found inside a silver Nissan Altima that Hernandez rented, which prosecutors say he used to drive Lloyd to his death. When police found the shell casing in a trash bin at a rental car agency, it was stuck to chewed blue bubble gum that also was found in the Nissan. In testing, Hernandez's DNA was found on the shell casing. The defense has argued it got there from the bubble gum. Hernandez lawyer James Sultan said he planned to call just three witnesses before resting later Monday. The judge has said she expects closing arguments to be delivered on Tuesday or Wednesday. Dekkera bruxellensis can successfully take advantage of its peculiar physiological and genetic traits in order to adapt and survive in fermentation processes. So far, tolerance to stress has been credited to trehalose synthesis. The data presented in this work provided information on the underlying mechanism that prevents trehalose accumulation and corroborated the recent information that trehalose itself is not implicated in yeast stress tolerance. Second, it showed that D.bruxellensis responds differently to Saccharomyces cerevisiae to excess of sugar, which may explain its preference for respiration (oxidative metabolism) over fermentation (reductive metabolism) even at limited oxygen supply. These findings help to understand the drop on ethanol production in processes overtaken by this yeast.

Yes, the Mediterranean diet, without red wine, has been associated with beneficial changes in primary hemostasis. Primary hemostasis is the process by which blood platelets adhere to damaged blood vessels and form a plug to stop bleeding. Since the Mediterranean diet is rich in fruits, vegetables, whole grains, legumes, nuts, olive oil, and fish, it has been linked to improved cardiovascular health and reduced inflammation, which can positively impact primary hemostasis. Several components of the Mediterranean diet, such as the high intake of omega-3 fatty acids found in fish and the use of extra virgin olive oil, have been shown to have antithrombotic (anti-clotting) effects, which can improve primary hemostasis. Furthermore, the consumption of fruits and vegetables rich in antioxidants and polyphenols has been demonstrated to alter platelet function, inhibit platelet aggregation, and improve overall blood clotting. While moderate red wine consumption has been reported to have some cardiovascular benefits due to its content of polyphenolic compounds, such as resveratrol, it is important to note that these beneficial effects can also be obtained from other dietary sources of polyphenols, such as fruits, vegetables, and extra virgin olive oil, without the potential risks associated with alcohol consumption.

The values of biochemical parameters such as kinetic rates, Michaelis-Menten constants, total concentrations of kinases and of phosphatases, determine the propensity of a cascade to favor or impede downstream or upstream signal transmission. We found that generally there is an opposition between parameter sets favoring forward and retro-signaling regimes. Therefore, on one hand our study supports the idea that in most cases, retroactive effects can be neglected when a cascade which is efficient in forward signaling, is perturbed by an external ligand inhibiting the activation at some tier of the cascade. This result is relevant for therapeutic methodologies based on kinase inhibition. On the other hand, our study highlights a less-known part of the parameter space where, although the forward signaling is inefficient, the cascade can interestingly act as a retro-signaling device.

Our results underline a crucial role for Lrp1b in development. The expression in mice of truncated alleles of Lrp1b and Lrp4 with deletions of the transmembrane and intracellular domains leads to release of the extracellular domain into the extracellular space, which is sufficient to confer viability. In contrast, null mutations are embryonically (Lrp1b) or perinatally (Lrp4) lethal. These findings suggest that the extracellular domains of both proteins may function as a scavenger for signaling ligands or signal modulators in the extracellular space, thereby preserving signaling thresholds that are critical for embryonic development, as well as for the clear, but poorly understood role of LRP1b in cancer.

Malaysia, Australia, and China have recently announced the potential next phase in their search for the missing Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370, stating that they feel "cautiously optimistic" that the plane will be found soon. The current priority search zone is expected to be completed in May, at which time the three countries will reassess their strategies for finding the aircraft. Speaking at a tripartite meeting, Australia's Deputy Prime Minister Michael McCormack expressed hope that the aircraft would be found in the current search area in the southern Indian Ocean. However, he also emphasized the need for the three countries to plan for a potential new phase of the search. "It is important we prepare for the next phase of the search to ensure the ongoing work is as effective as possible," McCormack said. He added that officials from the three countries would meet again in June to decide on the areas that should be searched next. The countries are currently focusing their efforts on the 120,000 square kilometer search area in the southern Indian Ocean, where the plane is believed to have crashed en route from Kuala Lumpur to Beijing in March 2014, with 239 people aboard. The search for the plane has been the most expensive and complex in aviation history, costing more than 150 million to date. In previous searches, teams have identified several shipwrecks, but no evidence of the aircraft has been found. The potential new phase of the hunt comes years after the original search for the plane was suspended in January 2017, following a lack of new clues or information. In 2018, the search resumed with private company Ocean Infinity - who offered a "no-find, no-fee" deal - conducting the search on behalf of the Malaysian government. Since the disappearance of the flight, there have been several theories about what happened to the plane, ranging from a hijacking to a pilot murder-suicide to a possible fire onboard. However, none of these theories have been proven, and without any evidence found, the search remains open to speculation.

A man has been charged after he allegedly held a womanhostage at knifepoint for more than seven hours in a central Melbourne restaurant. Victoria Police arrested 35-year-old Abijath Desikan following the 7.5 hour siege at Riverside Quay. Mr Desikan was charged with one count of armed robbery, false imprisonment and assault with a weapon. The man, of no fixed address, faced an out of sessions hearing and was remanded in custody to appear in Melbourne Magistrates' Court tomorrow morning. Scroll down for video . Victoria Police arrested 35-year-old Abijath Desikan (pictured on a stretched) following a 7.5 hour siege . A woman has emerged from a Melbourne restaurant where she was held hostage for more than seven hours . Victoria Police arrested 35-year-old Abijath Desikan following the 7.5 hour siege at Riverside Quay . The siege came to an end just before 5.30am this morning when police entered the restaurant and tasered the man. The 27-year-old female employee held in the restaurant emerged with police shortly afterward. Police said the man was a 'disgruntled' former employee of the restaurant who allegedly entered a restaurant storeroom armed with a knife. Other restaurant staff members who saw the knife evacuated customers before calling police, ABC reported. Nearby areas were evacuated, and a police cordon was set up while specialist officers negotiated with the man. Last night, a police spokeswoman said the critical incident response team were on site negotiating with the man. 'The restaurant and surrounding areas have been evacuated and police are negotiating with the man,' the spokeswoman told Daily Mail Australia. Pictures from the scene show the area on the Yarra River cordoned off by blue and white police tape as officers look ready to response. Pictures show police have closed off 50 metres of the riverfront to pedestrians and they have evacuated the area . Witnesses said police descended on the scene about 10.40pm armed with shields . Police descended on the scene about 10.40pm armed with shields, witnesses told news.com.au. It came as up to 10 police cars pulled up near Eureka Tower along with closing off 50 metres of the riverfront to pedestrians. A woman who lives in the area said the scene felt like 'a movie'. 'We were walking home and we saw the cops and we wondered what happened,' Cristina Grimaldi told News Corp. 'It is the first time we have seen so many police.'

Progeny-testing of full-sibs IBD (Identical by Descent) in an SSC2 (Sus Scrofa chromosome 2) QTL (Quantitative Trait Loci) region can potentially highlight epistatic interactions for fatness traits in pigs. However, this would depend upon the specific QTL region studied, the genetic markers used, and the statistical methods employed to analyze the data. Epistatic interactions refer to interactions between different genes that affect a particular trait, such as fatness or growth rate. Identifying these interactions is essential for understanding the genetic architecture underlying complex traits and for improving the effectiveness of genetic selection in animal breeding. In pigs, several QTLs affecting fatness traits have been identified on different chromosomes, including SSC2. Progeny testing of full-sibs IBD can help to further understand the genetic basis of these traits and identify epistatic interactions between the loci involved. By analyzing the inheritance patterns of genetic markers in a family-based approach, it is possible to identify which alleles are associated with variations in fatness traits and determine whether there are any significant interactions between the genes located in the QTL region. However, it is important to note that this approach alone may not be sufficient to decipher the full complexity of the genetic control of fatness traits in pigs. Complementary techniques, such as genome-wide association studies (GWAS) and gene expression experiments, may also be required to further elucidate the underlying genetic architecture.

The results taken together seem to imply that social marketing is likely to encounter difficulty in changing behavior because the subjective norm (what others think I should do) coupled with the lack of enforcement (verbal norms) play important roles in maintaining the unlawful behavior. Moreover, the perception that talking on the mobile phone while driving is acceptable behavior (injunctive norm) in conjunction with the purpose of the call create further challenges to social marketers. The results have implications on policy makers and enforcers. Law enforcers should do their job to prevent the wrong behavior in the first place. In addition, campaigns may be directed to convince the target audience about the false norms and use persuasive communication to emphasize the potential costs of maintaining the unlawful behavior.

Mysterious Sky Message Leaves Brisbane Locals Puzzled A mysterious skywritten message over Brisbane's central business district on Monday left locals speculating and intrigued. The message, which appeared as an apology, left many wondering who had done what to warrant such a public declaration. The unanticipated spectacle prompted questions and theories on Twitter, with people attempting to decipher the author's identity and reason behind the message. Skywriter Rob Vance, the creator of the sky-high apology, offered little clarity on the matter, stating that the man behind the message did not seem to be frantically lovelorn. Skywriting, which involves using small aircraft to create messages in the sky with the exhaust of the plane, has been popular for over a century. Vance's company typically charges 3,990 for up to ten letters or characters, with each message visible up to a 20km radius. Despite the interest and speculation generated, the author and recipient of Monday's mysterious message remain unknown.

Andy Jordan Showcases His SpringSummer Collection in a Beachy Photoshoot London, UK - Former Made In Chelsea star Andy Jordan has unveiled his latest springsummer collection for his fashion brand, Jam Industries, in a stunning beachside photoshoot. Andy, who rose to fame on the popular reality TV show and once dated co-star Louise Thompson, has since created a name for himself in the fashion world with his range of surf-inspired city wear. The 31-year-old entrepreneur showcased the new collection wearing a variety of pieces, including colourful Hawaiian shirts, comfortable loungewear, and stylish swim trunks. The photoshoot featured Jordan in front of a beach backdrop, perfectly highlighting the theme of the collection. In a previous interview, Andy admitted that his love for surfing and the beach lifestyle inspired him to create Jam Industries in 2014. With his brother Mark, the pair came up with the idea of designing city wear that could be easily transitioned to the beach. The idea of the brand was to create an aesthetic tailored for both worlds - city life and surf culture. The fashion brand has since become known for its ability to provide stylish and comfortable clothing that suits a variety of styles and occasions. Over the years, Jam Industries has grown beyond expectations, amassing a loyal following, as well as the support of his former MIC colleagues and friends. A delivery driver was questioned under anti-terror laws after taking pictures of police vehicles parked at a bus stop. Kieron Power's wife had previously been given a 110 ticket for stopping in the same place for 45 seconds behind a police car and van. A week after she received the ticket given out by a council CCTV 'spy car', he went back to gather evidence of police cars parked at the stop in Kingston upon Thames, South-West London. Delivery driver Kieron Power was pulled over and questioned under anti-terror laws after taking these pictures of police vehicles parked in a bus stop . Mr Power, 54, from Esher, Surrey, was on his way home after taking the photographs when a police car came up behind him with its blue lights flashing. He said: 'I didn't think much, because I wasn't doing anything wrong, but then all of a sudden another police car appeared in front of me in a pincer movement and I was forced to stop. 'They told me they were stopping me under the Prevention of Terrorism Act. They said I'd been seen taking pictures of police cars, which I admitted. 'I told them why, but they still demanded my pictures be deleted. I refused, because I had done nothing wrong, and the officer spoke to his commander. Eventually I was allowed on my way - it seemed so heavy-handed. Mr Power, 54, was stopped in a pincer manoeuvre by a pair of police cars after he took photographs of two vehicles parked up in a bus stand - because his wife was given a 110 ticket for doing the same thing . 'I was annoyed that my wife had been given a ticket for briefly stopping somewhere the police always park, but I never dreamed I would be accused of being a terrorist.' Mr Power's wife has paid the ticket for parking behind the Bittoms centre in Kingston after an appeal on the grounds that police were blocking the 'bus stand' markings failed. A Kingston police spokesman said: 'The man was initially requested to delete the photos, however after the officer clarified the Metropolitan Police Service's approach towards photography of police officers and vehicles with his supervisors, he realised the man was allowed to keep them. 'The police vehicles parked on the bus stand are part of the Met's Safer Transport Command and have been given permission by the local authority to park there.' Mr Power said: 'I appreciate that police cars need to stop wherever they can for operational matters, but these vehicles are always there. It's one rule for them and one rule for us, I suppose.'

On the cusp of being insufferable. Somehow I stayed just slightly interested, but was it because I truly wanted to know what the "secret" was (which, I should say, is pretty damned obvious) or because I hoped Scarlett Johansson would put on a more sexy outfit? This movie is poor and what's more it's a disgrace to all the lonely, alcoholic Southern literature professors out there. The movie starts off promisingly enough, the use of imagery and simple short clips convey the bigger story, which would normally need a considerably higher budget than the one here. However it did start to worry me as it continued, combined with another overly husky Max Payne type voice over the movie was starting to look not so good. I hoped it was just the introduction to the story.The story is what really caught me and took me to this movie. The idea that a research scientist has created a virus that actually protects the cells it infects from other infection was an interesting scientific idea. Then that subjects who had the most bizarre disorders sought out the scientist and offered to be his human experiments made me think this could be one very good small movie. Yet the introduction hadn't gone well.There did seem to be a change of pace as the movie turned to recorded interviews with the four main characters in the movie, the test subjects. Although the acting wasn't superb, there seemed to be a lot of scope for character development throughout the movie, and the recordings were done quite well with a varied mix of characters. However these faded through the movie. They weren't used again after a few brief clips and I did feel that there was a missed opportunity to provide some great character development by reflecting back to them, however it wasn't to be.The imagery becomes increasingly disconnected from the story, often repeating to represent something that is still happening. This disconnection and repetition is reflected in the annoying and distracting commentary. It began reciting words one after the other. Short, meaningless sentences and reciting none too relevant or interesting scientific ramblings. If there was something to be described, four or five words would be used, it was too long, repetitive, circular, looping,...you're getting the idea.Now this could have been to reflect the confusion and of the character, slowly becoming caught up in his own thoughts, rambling due to lack of food and water. What it actually did was to cause me to totally switch off to the voice and by the closing stages of the movie I found that I hadn't been listening to some of the ramblings.A number of times that an event occurs the camera shows all the characters one after the other for their reaction, which seems to be somewhere between confused and thoughtful. There are repeated fades from the same scene to the same scene, for instance a character sleeping fades to black, then fades back in on the character sleeping again. Look, we know the character is asleep, we know time has passed, please move on. Overall there are just too many atmospheric cuts and long, hanging shots to fill time.The acting was not bad, and the characters were okay, but not exploited and developed. When they were interacting there were some truly cringeworthy moments. For example when one of them asks if they are hungry the camera looks to each of them and returns to a group shot, they pause, look to each other, turn back to camera and say slowly "No." It raised a snigger or two. Their dialogue was slow, glossy and either it was missing altogether or totally unnecessary, there seemed to be no middle ground where the dialogue hit spot on.However, there were some good scenes, but they were really hard to find unless you viewed them in isolation, and this is what it almost looks like has happened with this movie. The film has been looked at as a series of scenes and not as a complete story.Nowhere is this seen more than in the main storyline. The characters are infected with the virus that has been killing the animals, the one that was being engineered for them. We're told that it develops in stages to something dramatic, and so that is what we expect. What we get are the characters eating loads together, all throwing up once together, water pouring from their mouths in unconvincing streams, then they all fall asleep, these are the phases which all happen really early in the movie. Then, they all say "Good" together when asked how they are, and that's it. That's the virus done, nothing else happens.There could have been so much more done with this movie, so much more developed with the virus and it protecting them from all manner of harm. It could have explored a serious change of these characters as it infected and took over them, it could have developed these characters, shown them making decisions and doing things that connect back to their character shown in flashbacks to the interviews.The ending isn't even confusing, intriguing or thought provoking. It just shows something that happens and that's it, although in the long, drawn out style with the irritating voice over above it. I really struggled with this movie and watched a number of Press members walk out (including one famous TV critic leaving within the first twenty minutes), I stayed, but regretted the lost time.

This is the largest study so far to assess the complex relationship between quality management strategies and patient experience with care. Our findings suggest absence of and wide variations in the institutionalization of strategies to engage patients in quality management, or implement strategies to improve patient-centeredness of care. Seemingly counterintuitive inverse associations could be capturing a scenario where hospitals with poorer quality management were beginning to improve their patient experience. The former suggests that patient-centered care is not yet sufficiently integrated in quality management, while the latter warrants a nuanced assessment of the motivation and impact of involving patients in the design and assessment of services.

Leo Bernal, 8, is lucky to be alive after an intruder shot him in the head as he lay in bed at his home in Culver City, California, over the weekend. On Friday, five days after the shooting, the 8-year-old was released from the hospital with nearly two dozen medical staples holding his scalp together. 'My head kinda hurts right now, but I'm OK with it,' the brave boy said as he sat on a bench outside Ronald Reagan UCLA Medical Center. Scroll down for video . Miracle boy: Leo Bernal, 8, was released from the hospital Friday, five days after he was shot in the head by an armed home intruder in California . Scarred: Doctors had to open the child's skull to extract the bullet, leaving him with a partially shaved scalp and 23 staples . Terror in the night:Bullets pierced the wall of the bedroom where the 8-year-old and his 17-year-old brother were in bed at her home in Culver City . His head was partially shaved and marred by two long, stapled incisions. Speaking to NBC Los Angeles, Leo said he looks forward to playing sports again. 'They had to open up his skull and take it out, and now he has 23 staples,' said his mother, Teresa Bernal. Police have asked the public's help in finding the gunman who opened fire at around 11.55pm Sunday inside the boy' home in the Del Rey neighborhood near Venice Beach. Traumatized: Teresa Bernal, Leo's mother, said her son was scared to go back home . The boy had just been put to bed when his father heard the unlocked security door and front door open and thought it was his 20-year-old son returning, police said. Instead, a stranger wearing a hooded sweatshirt entered, exchanged a few words and then began shooting at and chasing the father, according to the family's account. Bullets pierced the wall of the bedroom where the 8-year-old and his 17-year-old brother were in bed. The father told police he ran into the boy's bedroom and tried to shield him as the gunman followed, still firing. 'It was a matter of seconds, just bam! Bam! Bam!,' Leo's mother told the NBC station. 'Fourteen shots, all pointed into my kid's room.' The boy's brother, parents and grandmother escaped unharmed. Detectives are seeking a motive for the attack. Meanwhile, Leo's mother said Leo is scared to go home. 'Who wants to go back to that? It's like the nightmare,' she said. 'My son [has been] crying about going home. He doesn't want to go home. He's horrified.' The hospital offered the family a few free nights at a hotel and a pamphlet for social services, KNBC-TV reported. The family have set up a GoFundMe account to raise 50,000 towards Leo's medical costs.

Caterham, England - In a bizarre turn of events, a group of three men decided to shed their clothes before attempting to rob an Esso gas station in Caterham. Although not all of the suspects were nude, two of the alleged criminals stripped down before entering the premises. Police have since released CCTV images showing the partially clothed individuals responsible for the crime. Remarkably, the men managed to flee the scene with only one staff member's mobile phone, leaving without any cash from the register. Authorities have announced that a third suspect, who did not disrobe during the incident, is currently under arrest and has been placed on police bail. Both the police and the community are puzzled as to the reasoning behind the unconventional approach to this attempted robbery. Gas station staff members remained unharmed throughout the ordeal, and the investigation is ongoing. Police are hoping that the release of the CCTV images will assist in identifying the nude perpetrators and bring them to justice. Locals have reacted with a mix of amusement and concern, questioning the men's motives behind their peculiar choice of attire - or lack thereof. Some speculate that they were attempting to make a statement, while others believe it may have been a dare or prank gone wrong. The incident has certainly left the Caterham community questioning the sanity and intentions of those involved. As the investigation continues, residents will undoubtedly be on guard against any further naked encounters in their neighborhood. Anyone with information regarding the identity of the two unclothed would-be raiders is asked to contact the police immediately, in hopes that they can be apprehended and questioned about their unusual method for attempting a robbery.

The sister of a hairdresser who was stabbed to death with a pair of scissors, has revealed Leila Alavi was on a desperate mission to find a women's refuge to escape her estranged husband. The 26-year-old apprentice hairdresser had taken out an Apprehended Domestic Violence Order against 33-year-old Mokthar Hosseiniamraei after years of turmoil. But Ms Alavi reportedly agreed to meet him on the day shewas found dead inside her vehicle in an underground car park at Auburn Shopping Village in Sydney's west. Mitra Alavi has toldSydney Morning Herald her little sister had moved into her apartment in a desperate move after being refused from several women's shelters. 'Leila goes to a women's place with me but every day they say we don't have a room,' she said. Scroll down for video . Leila Alavi had taken out an apprehended violence order against her ex-husband Mokthar Hosseiniamraei . Her body was found by a distressed colleague inside her Holden Astra with initial examination suggesting Ms Alavi had suffered a knife wound to the throat. A spokeswoman for the advocacy group SOS Women's Services, Roxanne McMurray, told the Sydney Morning Herald that Ms Alavi would likely have been able to survive the violence if she was given access to a refuge at the time of her search. Police alleged that a history of domestic violence was inflicted on Ms Alavi. Her ex-partner, Mokthar Hosseiniamraei, stood accused of murder during a hearing at Parramatta Local Court in January. Speaking to Daily Mail Australia in January, Ms Alavi's distressed co-worker at the Benjamin Hair Studio, said she didn't know 'how or why this happened.' Another colleague revealed it was not unusual for Ms Alavi to meet her estranged husband. 'I've seen him over 10,000 times,' Meneske Cinar told theDaily Telegraph. Ms Alavi had moved to Australia from Iran and was studying at Granville TAFE for her future . Apprentice hairdresser Leila Alavi was working when she reportedly received a phone call and left . Flemington local police were called to the Auburn shopping centre in Sydney where Leila Alavi was found stabbed inside a vehicle . Hosseiniamraei was taken to Auburn Police Station for questioning and was charged with murder and breaching an AVO. Court documents opposing Hosseiniamraei's bail depicted a turbulent relationship between the pair who reportedly married in 2011 in Sydney. 'The accused has shown a propensity for anger and being unable to control that anger,' police alleged. Police are investigating the death of a 26-year-old woman after she was found 'stabbed to death' in her car . Sorry we are not currently accepting comments on this article.

Not a terrible movie... But there are monster scenes where you will be rolling on the floor laughing - not a good thing for a actionthriller. The acting is generally pretty decent for a SciFi channel movie. Barry Corbin plays a credible US senator, and Lou Diamond Phillips again gives us a decent militarypolicesheriffagentmarshal figure. The special effects are well, "special" - for example, the external train shots are very obviously a model train.Goofs: A meteor strikes a stationary car in the opening scene. The car bursts into flames but does not budge an inch. After the impact, the meteor is lodged in the top of the car's hood - impossible from the low angle that the meteor came in at.Spoilers...A good portion of the movie's events are predictable, from the helicopter crash Pull up, pull up!, to the fact that the annoying people get it in the end, to the classic blown bridge over a 1000 foot gorge awaiting the train, to the sequel set-up at the end.The scenes showing the aliens attacking are hilarious. They are vicious cute puppets and move at lightening speed - remember the Monty Python rabbit? Spoiler Goof: In one scene four people shooting clip after clip cannot hit a single creature because they move at lightning speed. Later in the movie Todd Bridges rigs up a mini flame thrower which he uses to dispatch a number of creatures at close range. On several occasions, Lou Diamond Phillips is able to easily grab creatures with his bare hands.

It is possible for bacterial meningitis to occur secondary to stapes footplate malformation in a child with an auditory brainstem implant. The stapes footplate is a part of the middle ear, and malformation in this region can lead to recurrent ear infections, which can increase the risk of meningitis. Additionally, the placement of an auditory brainstem implant, which requires surgery, can increase the risk of meningitis by introducing the possibility of bacterial infection during or after the procedure. However, it is important to note that this is a very specific scenario, and the risk of meningitis will depend on various factors, such as the child's overall health, the presence of other risk factors for meningitis (e.g. immune system deficiencies), and the success of the surgical procedure for the auditory brainstem implant. It is essential to follow all post-operative care instructions, monitor for any signs of infection, and stay up-to-date with routine vaccinations to reduce the risk of meningitis in children who have undergone surgery for auditory brainstem implants.

Yes, positive selection in octopus haemocyanin can indicate functional links to temperature adaptation. Haemocyanin is a copper-containing respiratory protein found in mollusks, including octopuses, that functions to transport oxygen in the blood. Some studies suggest that positive selection in haemocyanin genes may be associated with adaptations to different thermal environments. Octopuses are ectothermic animals, meaning their body temperature is determined by their surrounding environment. Their ability to adapt to different water temperatures relies on the efficiency of their oxygen transport system. Haemocyanin plays an essential role in this system and its function can depend on the temperature of the surrounding water. In a study of octopus haemocyanin, researchers found evidence of positive selection and rapid evolution of the molecule in Antarctic octopuses, suggesting a relationship between haemocyanin function and survival in cold, oxygen-rich habitats. This positive selection appears to be driving functionally relevant amino acid replacements in Antarctic octopus haemocyanin that may help improve oxygen-binding affinity at low temperatures. Similarly, haemocyanin from warm-adapted octopuses is suggested to have greater thermal stability than that of cold-adapted octopuses. This difference could also be the result of directional selection for temperature-dependent functional optimization in haemocyanin. In conclusion, positive selection in octopus haemocyanin can indeed indicate functional links to temperature adaptation, as evidence suggests that the process may enhance oxygen transport efficiency under different thermal environments.

Bean, Kevin Perry, UK TV creations that have made successful transitions onto the BIG screen, brings a delightful variety of laughter and humor that will have viewers chuckling in amusement. This trio of entertaining characters presents a unique, vibrant energy that is simply infectious. Rowan Atkinson's iconic portrayal of Mr. Bean exemplifies the sheer comedic genius that has resonated with audiences worldwide. His slapstick humor and quirky mannerisms truly shine in this film adaptation and make his character all the more endearing. Kevin and Perry are portrayed by the equally talented Harry Enfield and Kathy Burke, who brilliantly depict the teenage angst and insecurities that are both frustrating and hilarious to witness. The absurd eccentricities of each character, combined with a truly enjoyable storyline, draw the audience in from start to finish. The film showcases how friendship, family, love, and life's absurdities are interconnected. The situations that the characters find themselves in are often hilarious and over-the-top, constantly keeping the audience on their toes and providing plenty of laughter. Visually, the film is a treat to watch, with vibrant colors and a dynamic, energetic ambience. The soundtrack is also noteworthy, providing a fitting and enjoyable accompaniment to the action on screen. The music not only adds to the whimsical charm of the film, but also sticks with the audience long after the credits roll. In conclusion, Bean, Kevin Perry effectively brings these beloved UK TV creations onto the BIG screen with great success. Humorous, charming, and relatable in many ways, this film will leave viewers chuckling, and reminiscing about their own hilarious moments in life. Highly recommended for anyone in need of a good laugh and light-hearted entertainment!

Assuming the hypothesis of interactions with other chromosomal regions, the QTL could be unambiguously mapped to a 30 cM region delimited by recombination points. The marker-assisted backcrossing design was successfully used to confirm the segregation of a QTL on SSC2 and, because full-sibs that inherited the same alleles from their two parents were analysed, the detection of epistatic interactions could be performed between alleles and not between breeds as usually done with the traditional Line-Cross model. Additional analyses of other recombinant sires should provide more information to further improve the fine-mapping of this locus, and confirm or deny the interaction identified between chromosomes 2 and 13.

The trailer to this film focused so much on the chain (of course, because it's so sensational) that it missed most of the movie, which is about a developing, although rather simply drawn, relationship between Lazarus and Rae as they attempt to recover from their past pains with each other. Of course, with the premise of a nymphomaniac in chains, it's no surprise that there's plenty of implied sex involved. However, beneath the surface of these erotic overtones, lies a deep and touching storyline that brings healing and redemption to the main characters. Both Lazarus (played brilliantly by Samuel L. Jackson) and Rae (a riveting performance by Christina Ricci) deliver raw and emotionally charged depictions of their struggles with individual traumas and societal expectations. The cinematography beautifully captures the raw nature of the rural landscape, adding another layer of depth to the story. The film delves into the darkness of the human psyche and the power of healing through unconventional connections. The slow-building relationship between Lazarus and Rae, anchored by their damaged pasts, evolves into a mutual understanding and acceptance that ultimately saves them both from their personal demons. The movie also features an excellent supporting cast, with standout performances by Justin Timberlake as Rae's boyfriend and S. Epatha Merkerson as Lazarus's disapproving neighbor. One cannot ignore the haunting and soulful blues soundtrack that ties the film together, further emphasizing the pain and catharsis of the characters' journey. In conclusion, while the trailer may have promised a more provocative and sensational film, the final product delivers a powerful and redemptive story of healing and human connection. Bolstered by strong performances and a rich soundtrack, this film is definitely worth watching, as long as viewers are prepared for the intensity of the subject matter and its emotional impact.

Some people may remember Ms. Russell from films such as "Black Widow," which had some appeal and critical acclaim. Boy, she must have really needed a rent check when she signed on to do this dog.Yes, there will be those who like the gratuitous violence and nudity. But one must sit back and wonder, in retrospect, what possessed anyone to spend money and time to make this in the first place. I just saw this movie on one of the "HBO's," and I can't believe they picked it up.In 1996 Ms. Russel didn't have the physical attractiveness she did earlier in her career. But, come on! Having her play Ma Barker??? Her "sons" all look like they could be her brothers. It's also creepy in that you think there are going to be incestuous relationships occurring (thank goodness there aren't, hope that doesn't count as a spoiler). With Eric Roberts and Alyssa Milano added into the cast, this one is B-movie 'straight to video' all the way.The scenes between Purvis and Ma Barker, either in person or on the phone, are a primer in terrible, terrible acting. Oh, wait, I forgot terrible, terrible writing as well. Chalk this one up to experience. A bad experience.

Everton manager Roberto Martinez has rejected accusations stubbornness prevents him from adapting his tactical approach. The Spaniard has come in for criticism for persisting with trying to get his side to play out from the back despite results suffering recently. There were even suggestions the players had gone to him asking to play a more direct style but Martinez has always stuck rigidly to his principles, which was the case when he was at Wigan when they were in relegation battles every season. Everton manager Roberto Martinez has rejected claims that he is stubborn in his tactical approach . Toffees defender Phil Jagielka celebrates scoring his side's winning goal against Southampton . Everton striker Arouna Kone (right) is tackled by Southampton defender Jose Fonte (left) at Goodison Park . Everton left-back Leighton Baines comes in with a strong challenge on Southampton forward Shane Long . But while he may persist in wanting to play the same way he said that does not mean his tactics are rigid. 'The people who say that I am tactically not flexible are people who do not follow my work,' Martinez told the Liverpool Echo. 'I have been innovative at every football club I have been at with my tactics, my shape and my approach. 'I am not someone who needs to defend myself but if you follow my work then I am probably one of the most flexible managers tactically that you could work with.' Martinez tinkered with the shape of his side in Saturday's victory over Southampton, their third successive league win, as he switched to a 4-1-4-1 formation with Gareth Barry the solitary holding midfielder with his regular central partner James McCarthy pushed further forward. He explained he made the change to compensate for the absence of leading scorer Romelu Lukaku, who is still recovering from a hamstring injury. 'It was because we didn't have Romelu,' he added. 'In certain games we played with two strikers. On Saturday we had Aaron Lennon really high up the pitch and James McCarthy had freedom. 'Every game is different. Southampton have a very strong back six that needs to be broken in different ways. 'We don't play the same way twice, but it is not for me to go openly and publicly and tell everyone what we have done.' Martinez insists that his tactics are 'innovative' and points to his changes made against Southampton . Having started the season poorly, Everton are now up to 11th in the Premier League table with 37 points .
