Yes, arthritis is linked to local and systemic activation of coagulation and fibrinolysis pathways. Studies have shown that people with arthritic conditions, such as rheumatoid arthritis (RA) and osteoarthritis (OA), have elevated levels of various factors involved in coagulation and fibrinolysis pathways. These pathways are important for blood clotting and the dissolution of blood clots, respectively. In RA, evidence suggests that the coagulation and fibrinolysis systems are both activated, which contributes to the associated inflammation and joint destruction. For example, increased levels of tissue factor and factor VIII (important players in the coagulation cascade) have been reported in the synovial fluid and blood of RA patients. Moreover, fibrinolysis, the process by which blood clots are broken down, is also impaired in RA patients, contributing to the accumulation of fibrin in the joints, further promoting inflammation and joint damage. In OA, the role of coagulation and fibrinolysis pathways is less well established as compared to RA. However, there are indications that both pathways could be implicated in OA pathogenesis as well. Some studies have reported elevated levels of tissue factor, factor X, and thrombin-antithrombin complexes in OA patients, suggesting activation of the coagulation system. Additionally, an imbalance between the levels of plasminogen activator inhibitor-1 (PAI-1, which inhibits fibrinolysis) and tissue plasminogen activator (t-PA, which promotes fibrinolysis) in OA joint tissues has been observed, pointing to a potential role for impaired fibrinolysis in OA. In summary, arthritis is linked to local and systemic activation of coagulation and fibrinolysis pathways, which can contribute to inflammation and joint damage. Understanding these pathways' involvement in arthritis might help develop new therapeutic strategies to treat these debilitating conditions.

Person1: Yes, those are all correct. Person2: Hmm, it looks like the withholdings and deductions were calculated correctly. Person1: I did work a couple of overtime hours, but that should have been paid at a higher rate. Person2: Right, I see that. There are 78 hours at your regular rate and 2 hours at your overtime rate. No more corned beef and cabbage for her! This little romantic comedy clips along from scene to scene with a few exotic twists (some imaginary scenes and a costume party). With the main character, Anne (played by the charming Emma Stone), breaking free from her monotonous daily routine and stumbling into the arms of the dashing but quirky bartender, Tom (played by the ever-alluring Chris Hemsworth), this movie is a delight from start to finish. The film perfectly captures the dilemma between sticking to tradition and venturing out into the unknown, all wrapped up in a bubbly package of wit and humor. The supporting cast, including Anne's overbearing yet well-meaning mother (Meryl Streep) and Tom's wild band of misfit friends, adds depth and a sparkling layer of chaos, making for a highly entertaining two-hour experience. The chemistry between Emma Stone and Chris Hemsworth is simply electric, leaving us rooting for their love story from their very first encounter. The movie's exotic twists keep the narrative refreshing and dynamic, while the infusion of fantasy scenes and the hilarious costume party act as an ode to the power of imagination and the transformative potential of love. With a heartwarming message of breaking free and embracing the vulnerability that comes with opening up to love, this movie will leave you with a smile on your face and a new appreciation for taking risks, whether or not that means giving up corned beef and cabbage. In conclusion, this romantic comedy is a must-watch for anyone seeking an escape from the mundane and an enjoyable ride into the world of serendipity, chance encounters, and the magic of love.

Mick Schumacher, son of seven-time Formula One world champion Michael Schumacher, will make his ADAC Formula 4 debut this weekend at the Motorsport Arena Oschersleben. The 16-year-old is part of the Dutch Van Amersfoort Racing team. His father, Michael Schumacher, is currently recovering from a serious head injury sustained in a skiing accident in December 2013. The young Schumacher has showcased his talent in the motorsport world in recent years, winning several karting championships and participating in test runs with Formula 4 teams. In signing with Van Amersfoort Racing, he will be joining a team with a proven track record of nurturing young talent. The team has helped launch the careers of many motorsport stars, including 2015 Formula One debutant Max Verstappen. "We are delighted to welcome Mick to our team," said team owner Frits van Amersfoort. "Mick has already demonstrated his talent in karting, and we are looking forward to working with him and helping him develop further in Formula 4." The anticipation for Mick's debut is palpable, as fans eagerly wait to see if he can follow in his legendary father's footsteps. The atmosphere at Oschersleben is sure to be electric as the younger Schumacher takes to the track this weekend.

Don't pay any attention to the rave reviews of this film here. Despite the immense hype surrounding this film, it fell incredibly short in delivering the entertainment value and cinematic quality that it promised. Firstly, the plot was underdeveloped and filled with cliches, creating a predictable story that left one wanting a more original and engaging experience. The story had great potential, but it barely scratched the surface of what could have been an intriguing exploration into the characters and their motivations. The acting was subpar, with the main characters delivering lackluster performances that did not evoke any connection with the audience. Despite their previous solid track records, the actors seemed uninspired and wooden, making it hard to invest in their journeys. Furthermore, the visuals and cinematography left much to be desired. The film appeared to rely heavily upon CGI and poor green screen effects which were more distracting than awe-inspiring. Rather than providing an immersive experience that transports the viewer into the world of the film, these visual shortcuts stripped away any authenticity and emotional weight that the film could have carried. Lastly, the pacing of the film was disjointed, with multiple storylines vying for attention but ultimately never receiving proper closure or development. What should have been a captivating ride was instead an overwhelming jumble of seemingly unrelated events and characters. Overall, this film is a disappointing watch and does not live up to the high expectations set by the hype and the rave reviews. Save your time and money, and skip this one altogether.

Dramatic bodycam footage of an officer shooting dead a man with a history of mental illness after he pointed a gun at him earlier this month as been released. The video shows Donald Allen, 66, pointing a loaded, 22-caliber pistol at officer Brian Barnett on April 11. Barnett, 25. then shoots Allen dead after he comes at him with the gun, making threatening statements as he does.WARNING: Graphic content . Bodycam footage released this week shows a police officer in Sand Springs, Oklahoma, fatally shooting a man . The bodycam footage shows Donald Allen, 66, pointing a loaded, 22-caliber pistol at officer Brian Barnett, 25 . The camera was malfunctioning and it was thought the video was lost. It was recovered but the audio was not . Deputy Chief of Police Mike Carter played the video at a news conference on Tuesday, Tulsa World reported. The camera was malfunctioning and it was initially thought the video was lost. It was forensically recovered, but the audio from the bodycam was not, Fox 23reported. Carter said: 'We are faced with making decisions that other people normally are not faced with making. 'This officer had to make one of those decisions that day. 'By this video, I think it very clearly shows he made a good decision. 'He made the decision he had to make. 'Don't ever confuse that with a decision that we want to make.' He said he believes the shooting was justified. Barnett shot four times. Officers in Sand Springs have been wearing bodycams for the past seven years and the early April incident was the first officer-involved shooting in 17 years in the town. Allen, a Vietnam veteran, was shooting a gun in his backyard when police were called, according to News on 6. His wife told police he was a paranoid schizophrenic and had been off his medication for a year. Deputy chief Carter added: 'Mr Allen is a victim. 'He's a victim of mental illness, he's a victim of the system. 'This was a tragic incident. 'It's something we hope we are never placed in the position of happening again.' All the recordings have been turned over to the Tulsa County District Attorney's Office. Barnett remains on administrative leave pending an investigation by the Tulsa County DA. Deputy chief Mike Carter said: 'It's something we hope we are never placed in the position of happening again'

Thousands Stranded at Central London Station as Trains Face Cancellations Rush hour chaos ensued yesterday as thousands of commuters were left stranded at a central London station due to a crucial section of track being closed between Wimbledon and Surbiton. South West trains warned passengers of cancellations on all services and Network Rail staff worked "flat out" to resolve the situation. The track closure affected a vital route carrying passengers from central London to stations in the suburbs, leaving many stranded and scrambling to find alternative means of transportation. While Network Rail has not revealed the cause of the issue, it apologized to its passengers for the inconvenience caused. As the disruption unfolded, several passengers took to social media to express their frustration. Images shared on Twitter showed huge crowds at London Waterloo station, as facilities were stretched to provide for the hundreds of delayed travelers. South West trains operated an emergency timetable during the peak travel hours, with the company warning passengers to expect "significant delays." Travelers were also urged to avoid traveling if possible and to make alternative arrangements, and if necessary, seek alternative routes into London. Network Rail issued a statement commending its staff for working "flat out" to fix the problem and assured passengers that the situation would soon be rectified. South West trains later confirmed that the line had been partially reopened, allowing a limited number of trains to run, but warned that disruption would likely continue into today. This latest disruption to London's transport network comes just weeks after a major power failure left thousands of homes without electricity, and stranded passengers at various airports and train stations across the country. With severe disruptions becoming increasingly frequent, pressure continues to mount on rail operators to ensure that such issues are promptly addressed.

Yes, the prevalence and correlates of elder abuse and neglect can be observed in a geriatric psychiatry service. Geriatric psychiatry services typically deal with older adults who may be at risk for, or have experienced, various forms of abuse or neglect. It is important for mental health professionals working in this field to be able to identify the signs of elder abuse and neglect and to be aware of potential risk factors that can contribute to such situations. Some common types of elder abuse include physical, emotional, sexual, financial, and neglect. Risk factors associated with elder abuse and neglect may include cognitive impairment, social isolation, mental illness, age-related health issues, and caregiver stress. By understanding the prevalence and correlates of elder abuse and neglect in geriatric psychiatry services, mental health professionals can develop intervention strategies, preventative measures, and appropriate treatments for affected individuals. Additionally, raising awareness within the broader community can help to reduce the stigma associated with discussing and reporting elder abuse and neglect.

Motherwell Football Club has announced that they will offer free entry to their regular fans if the team ends up in the play-off competition, challenging a standing rule in which the Scottish Professional Football League (SPFL) is entitled to 50 of gate proceeds from play-off games. The club has stated that they will provide free tickets to fans in the event of finishing in 11th place, a decision that has received support from Rangers and Hibernian football clubs. Currently sitting in 11th place in the league table, Motherwell is at risk of being part of the play-off battles. The club's board has made a bold stand against the SPFL by insisting that if Motherwell reaches the relegation play-off final, they will allow their season ticket holders to attend for free. This move is a direct challenge to the SPFL's rules, which demand that 50 of gate proceeds from these crucial games are handed over to the league body. In a statement, Motherwell said, "The board at Fir Park are acutely aware of the financial pressures on its supporter base. Should we be involved in the play-off final, we don't believe it should be an additional cost on top of an already expensive season. Therefore, we have decided that should we be involved in the play-off final at Fir Park on Friday, 22 May, the club will cover the cost of its season ticket holders' entry." The move has been appreciated by supporters, as the team currently has around 2,400 season ticket holders who would all be eligible for free entry. However, it remains to be seen how the SPFL will react to the defiance, as the league could lose a significant amount of revenue as a result. Rangers and Hibernian have already expressed their support for Motherwell's stance, with both clubs agreeing that the current distribution of revenues from play-offs is unfair to clubs, particularly those in the lower leagues. Rangers and Hibernian had also previously offered free tickets to season ticket holders in past play-off seasons, only to be slapped with hefty fines by the SPFL. There has been no official word yet from the SPFL on Motherwell's announcement, but it will be interesting to see how the league handles this latest challenge to its rules.

Only the psychological approach to successful ageing independently predicted QoL at follow-up. Successful ageing is not only about the maintenance of health, but about maximising one's psychological resources, namely self-efficacy and resilience. Increasing use of preventive care, better medical management of morbidity, and changing lifestyles in older people may have beneficial effects on health and longevity, but may not improve their QoL. Adding years to life and life to years may require two distinct and different approaches, one physical and the other psychological. Follow-up health status, number of supporters and social activities, and self-rated active ageing also significantly predicted QoL at follow-up. The longitudinal sample bias towards healthy survivors is likely to underestimate these results.

Contains Spoilers: This is a Peter Watkins film, and knowing that, one expects a certain level of political awareness and commentary. "Punishment Park" does not disappoint on that front. The film is a stunning and gripping indictment of the government's suppressive measures towards political dissent, as well as an exploration of the limits of human morality. Set in an alternate 1970s America, "Punishment Park" follows a diverse group of citizens labeled as political radicals and criminals, who are given an ultimatum: face lengthy prison sentences or survive three days in a grueling desert obstacle course pursued by national guardsmen and law enforcement officers, the eponymous Punishment Park. Shot in a mockumentary style, Watkins expertly uses the gritty realism of his handheld camera and non-professional actors to underline the sense of urgency and jeopardy in the characters' dire predicament. The film shifts between heart-wrenching tribunal scenes where the defendants argue passionately for their freedom, and the violent and cruel cat-and-mouse game in the desert. The film's most striking feature is its deftness in criticizing both the American government's methods of stifling dissent and the behavior of those in power. The harsh treatment of prisoners is disturbingly relevant today, even though the film was made five decades ago. "Punishment Park" forces the viewer to question the morality of their government and confront the chilling possibility of a near-future dystopia. It also shows the extent to which law enforcement is willing to go to maintain order and authority, only escalating the fear and tension within the characters and the audience. In terms of performances, the largely improvised dialogue lends an air of authenticity to the characters, making them relatable and their struggles all the more heart-wrenching. Watkins also masterfully inserts moments of quiet introspection amidst the chaos, adding a level of depth and empathy to the characters. Overall, "Punishment Park" is a powerful and thought-provoking film that leaves a lasting impact. Its social commentary on politics, military power, and governmental control remains eerily relevant today. If you are a fan of Peter Watkins or politically-themed cinema, this film is a must-watch. Just be prepared for a gut-wrenching and intense experience.

Retiring jockey AP McCoy insists he will not repeat Sir Steve Redgrave's U-turn Tony McCoy, the retiring jockey from Northern Ireland, has vowed to never return to professional horse racing, going as far as saying, "shoot me if I ride professionally again." The 41-year old rider retires after two decades of racing, with more than 4,000 career wins under his belt. McCoy's determined exit from professional racing conjures memories of Olympian Steve Redgrave's proclamation in 1996 when he said, "If anyone sees me near a boat, you've got my permission to shoot me." However, Redgrave later made a triumphant return to competitive rowing, claiming his fifth consecutive Olympic gold at Sydney 2000. Although there have been speculations of a possible U-turn in his decision to retire, McCoy is adamant about his departure from the sport. The decorated jockey acknowledges the similarities between his and Redgrave's statements but maintains that he will not make a comeback. Although fans may be sad to see him retire, Tony McCoy leaves an impressive legacy behind in the world of horse racing and will always be remembered as one of the greatest competitors of the sport.

The F344 rat appears to serve as a reasonable model for some common sleep architecture and cognitive changes seen with age in humans, including the cognitively disrupting influence of active period deep sleep. Microarray analysis suggests that the processes engaged by this sleep are consistent with its function. Thus, active period deep sleep appears temporally misaligned but mechanistically intact, leading to the following: first, aged brain tissue appears capable of generating the slow waves necessary for deep sleep, albeit at a weaker intensity than in young. Second, this activity, presented during the active period, seems disruptive rather than beneficial to cognition. Third, this active period deep sleep may be a cognitively pathologic attempt to recover age-related loss of inactive period deep sleep. Finally, therapeutic strategies aimed at reducing active period deep sleep (e.g., by promoting active period wakefulness andor inactive period deep sleep) may be highly relevant to cognitive function in the aging community.

Motherwell have vowed to go to battle with the SPFL over the issue of free entry to the Premiership play-offs for season-ticket holders. And the Fir Park side are set to win powerful backing for their revolt from Championship promotion challengers Rangers and Hibernian. Under existing rules, the SPFL are entitled to take 50 per cent of the gate proceeds from the six play-off ties for redistribution among the clubs. But a bid by the league board to force play-off finalists to charge all fans a minimum price of 15 for the play-off ties was withdrawn at a meeting last Thursday. Motherwell will go to battle with the SPFL over free entry to the Premiership play-offs for season-ticket holders . Motherwell general manager Alan Burrows told Sportsmail his club will make a stand if they finish 11th . Expressing unease among the play-off finalists that the SPFL might be using the ties to milk supporters, Motherwell general manager Alan Burrows told Sportsmail his club will make a stand if they finish in the Premiership play-off place. 'All our focus at Motherwell in the next four games is fully on avoiding the play-offs altogether,' said Burrows. 'We fully accept and appreciate that there are rules on this in place. 'But, in the eventuality that we are in 11th place come the play-offs, then it is not our intention to charge our season-ticket holders for the play-off final at Fir Park. 'We believe we have sold them tickets which entitle them to the full story of the season.' Rangers sources said last night that the club have yet to reach a final decision on whether to seek an SPFL exemption which would allow them to let their 25,000 season ticket holders into play-off games for free. The SPFL are entitled to take 50 per cent of the gate proceeds but Motherwell want to offer free tickets . Hibs gained a one-off dispensation to give their most loyal fans free admission to last season's home play-off clash with Hamilton. Sportsmail understands, however, that SPFL lawyers have already warned clubs that attempts to do the same this season will be strongly resisted as it would constitute a breach of league rules. Last week, a resolution by Hibs and Motherwell to have the 50-per-cent levy on play-off gates cut in half was defeated. Hibs argue their main concern is that fans are being fleeced to atone for the absence of a league sponsor . Accused of a cash grab to keep more of the play-off cash, Hibs argue their main concern is that fans are being fleeced to atone for the absence of a league sponsor for the last two seasons. Asked if he expects a fight on the matter from league chiefs, Burrows admitted: 'Based on what has gone previously, then yes.' .

The chemistry between the actors is undeniable, making each scene palpable and engaging, with a mix of playful banter and steamy encounters. That being said, the film is certainly outdated in terms of its dialogue, pacing, and societal norms. Former footballer Gary Mabbutt was left with a 30inch scar following a five hour operation to save his leg. The ex-Tottenham and England star, 53, was rushed to hospital after waking up at 1am to find that the leg had gone cold back in 2013. Mabbutt's diabetes had led to a clogged artery in the limb and doctors warned him it was 'touch and go' on whether the leg would have to be amputated. Scroll down for video . Horrific scar: Gary Mabbutt has been left with a30inch scar on his left leg after his diabetes caused an artery to be clogged requiring emergency surgery to save the limb . He was treated at King's College Hospital in South East London, undergoing an emergency five-hour operation. Surgeons were required to replace the main artery in his left leg with a vein and needed 112 staples to seal the horrific wound. Mabbutt, who was diagnosed with Type 1 diabetes at 17, will not be able to play football again, leaving his dream of becoming a manager in tatters. As he is unable to train with players on the pitch, he has been forced to turn down roles in coaching. Emergency procedure: Surgeons were required to replace the main artery in his left leg with a vein and needed 112 staples to seal the horrific wound . The Spurs legend has spoken for the first time about the agony he went through and says he hopes to raise awareness of his condition. Speaking to The Sun, he said: 'When they talked about battling to save my leg, I realised I was helpless. As a diabetic you know complications can occur. But you think "It's never going to happen to me." It is vital to educate everyone with diabetes how to take care of themselves. If you have anything unusual with your feet, tingly toes, blisters, see your doctor.' In 1982, father-of-two Mabbutt became the first diabetic ever to play for England and captained Tottenham to FA cup glory in 1991. Former star: Mabbutt is pictured, left, lifting the FA Cup while playing for Tottenham in 1991 . He was unaware that his diabetes had triggered peripheral arterial disease, clogging up the blood vessels in the legs. Every year, surgeons perform around 8,000 amputations on diabetics in the UK - but campaigners say four out five could be prevented. Amputations cost the NHS 650million a year - and up 80 per cent of the amputees die within five years. Diabates sufferers are entitled to annual eye tests as they are are 20 times more likely to develop sight problems, but Gary Mabbutt wants a similar programme to apply to feet. Experts say millions of diabetics are unaware their condition could lead to foot problems and agree regular checks could save limbs.

We demonstrate for the first time that IMD is present in day 5 embryonic secretome; villous and decidual expression of IMD is higher at 6-8 weeks after a decline as gestation advances toward the second trimester; first-trimester spontaneous abortion is associated with a lower expression of IMD in serum, villi, and decidua; IMD stimulates the invasive capacity of first-trimester primary Extravillous cytotrophoblast cells; and IMD decreases elevated levels of tumor suppressor Kangia-1 in decidual explants from first-trimester spontaneous abortion. In conclusion, this study is the first to demonstrate a potential involvement of IMD in human embryo implantation and placental development via regulation of trophoblast invasion at the maternal-fetal interface and suggests a physiological role for this novel peptide in establishment of human pregnancy.

When John Carpenter's masterly version of "The Thing" was released in summer 1982, it was panned by critics and bombed at the box office. The audiences couldn't handle another 'bad' alien, they wanted ET. Their loss in the long run.I would kill to be able to see this great movie on the big screen. This is a movie that was way ahead of it's time; now it has influenced a new generation of filmmakers, showing it's trail on things like "Se7en," "Alien 3," and even "The X Files," which unceremoniously ripped it off page by page. And the structure, which eschews character development in favour of incredible SFX, is commonplace in today's blockbuster flicks.Carpenter shows the same skills he honed in "Halloween," using the camera to create an unsettling and claustrophobic atmosphere. The performances are all fine, and the ending is terrific - still unique today.A paranoid masterpiece.

Ascaroside expression changes with development and environmental conditions. This is consistent with multiple functions of these signaling molecules. Knowledge of such differential regulation will make it possible to associate ascaroside production to gene expression profiles (transcript, protein or enzyme activity) and help to determine genetic pathways that control ascaroside biosynthesis. In conjunction with findings from previous studies, our results show that the pheromone system of C. elegans mimics that of insects in many ways, suggesting that pheromone signaling in C. elegans may exhibit functional homology also at the sensory level. In addition, our results provide a strong foundation for future behavioral modeling studies.

Authorities are investigating a stabbing that occurred on Thursday night at approximately 10.53pm at a local club. According to police, the assailant had been ejected from the premises earlier in the evening before returning and stabbing the 29-year-old bouncer in the back. The bouncer was admitted to the hospital for treatment, but thankfully, his injuries were not life-threatening. In a separate yet strikingly similar incident, another bouncer was stabbed in the leg on Good Friday. It is currently unclear whether the two incidents are connected or if they were committed by the same individual. The severity of this bouncer's injuries has not been disclosed. As police continue to investigate these violent incidents involving club security, they are urging anyone with information about either stabbing to contact Crime Stoppers. By providing anonymous tips, witnesses can play an essential role in identifying and apprehending those responsible for these acts of violence. Local clubs and venues are also urged to take extra precautions in ensuring the safety and security of both their patrons and employees in light of the recent attacks on bouncers. Police have been increasing their presence around popular nightlife spots to maintain public safety, but they also encourage club-goers to remain vigilant and report any suspicious activity they may witness. Authorities emphasize that acts of violence against security officers, who are charged with keeping fellow citizens safe, must not be tolerated. The public's help in locating and detaining those responsible for these incidents is crucial in putting an end to this unwarranted aggression and ensuring that these establishments remain safe spaces for all.

The present data seem to support the view that the larger regurgitant jet of mitral insufficiency, the higher the risk of worsening CHF during a two years follow up. Likewise, it is plausible the moderate-severe MR represents a predictor of increased risk of transition to III NYHA class among the CHF II NYHA class patients. In addition, this study seems to indicate that a surgical therapy (prosthetic replacement or mitral valvuloplasty) should always be planned in the case of II NYHA class CHF patient who has been recognized affected by moderate-to-severe MR, since the chances of successful pharmacological prevention of clinical impairment in this setting turned out to be very slight.

Person1: No worries! I've got you covered this time. Besides, we deserve a break from eating in. What do you think? Person2: That's very kind, but are you sure you don't mind? Person1: Of course not, it's my treat. Where would you like to go? Person2: Alright, I appreciate it. How about our favorite pizza place? Person1: Sounds perfect! Let's go and enjoy some slices together.

Person1: Have you ever thought of moving, Sarah? Person2: We thought about it, but my husband and I can't afford it right now. Person1: Buying a house near our company can be expensive, but there are ways to find cheaper houses. Person2: Like what? Person1: Well, you can buy a house far away from the city center. You would definitely save money that way. Person2: That's a good idea. Person1: My sister in law and her husband just bought a house that way. And they're pretty satisfied with it. Person2: Is the house in poor condition? Person1: Not at all, the woman who owned it bought it from her friend and took good care of it. But when she died she had no family left and no will, so the government had to sell it for her. Person2: Was it a very old house? Person1: Yes, it was about 50 years old. There were a few repairs that needed doing but it didn't take a lot of money or time. Person2: Is it in a good location? Person1: The area can be a bit rough in the evening but the neighbors watch out for each other so it's OK.

Person1: You look pale, Stephanie. What's wrong? Person2: I don't feel good. I have a bad headache. In fact, I haven't got much sleep this past week and I feel really tired. Person1: Why don't you go to see a doctor? Person2: Yeah, I think I should but I have a report due tomorrow. Miss Jenkins needs it for the board meeting next Monday. Person1: Well, it's Wednesday today. Why don't you talk to Miss Jenkins and ask if you can hand it in on Friday morning? Person2: Maybe I should try. I guess I just need a good sleep. Thanks, George. Person1: If you need any help with the report, just let me know.

Desperate Chicago Cubs fans were forced to pee into plastic cups as lines for the bathroom at Wrigley Field stretched through the concourse and out into the stands on opening day. The bathroom debacle caused people to wait more than one hour to get to one of only two working bathrooms and according to those who were there, some were left with no choice but to relieve themselves while standing in line. Traumatized fans uploaded pictures to social media showing the intense queues and plastic glasses filled with urine, as the modernization of Wrigley Field reduced the famous stadium to a potential public health disaster. Scroll down for video . Busting: The line for the restroom can be seen snaking its way to the bathroom which is visible in the top left of the picture . Almost there: Disgruntled and disgusted fans uploaded pictures to social media revealing their trauma in getting to the bathroom . Indeed, the Cubs admitted as much on Sunday as thousands of the 35,000 fans in attendance struggled to get to the bathroom. 'Opening Day at Wrigley Field has always brought challenges with wait times and tonight was particularly extreme,' Cubs spokesman Julian Green said in a statement published after the Cubs had lost to the St. Louis Cardinals 3-0. Stinking the field and the stands out, the Cubs and Wrigley Field claimed the problem began when two bathrooms on the upper deck 'went down temporarily.' This came at a time when the stadium was 'already experiencing issues with long wait times.' Social media was flooded with complaints. Opening day: A general shot of Wrigley Field during batting practice prior to a game between the Chicago Cubs and the St. Louis Cardinals on Sunday night . 'I'm all for renovating, but I've now missed two innings trying to get into the bathroom,' said James Hillebrand in a tweet. While Cubs fan Russ Stubenruch said, 'The lines were obnoxiously long compared to what you would normally get.' One fan who identified herself as Libby, told Deadspin that the whole scene was a horror show. 'Yes, fans were peeing in cups tonight. They were peeing EVERYWHERE. I heard there were only two working bathrooms- I know the lines were horrific and I also know that some were shut down early on because toilets just wouldn't flush.' Cubs spokesman Julian Green said that 'with 35,000 fans showing up in the ballpark tonight, we were simply not prepared to handle guests during peak periods. We have high standards for service and we missed the mark tonight. 'We want to apologize to our fans for the inconvenience tonight,' he added. 'Moving forward we plan to supplement the existing restrooms with additional portable units and will continue to monitor wait times.'

You the Living? Prepare to be shaken to your core! This groundbreaking film is a masterful exploration of the human experience that powers through with a unique plot and visually stunning cinematography. The ensemble cast delivers captivating performances that strike the perfect balance between emotional depth and relatability, keeping the audience invested and connected throughout the film. As the story unfolds, viewers find themselves questioning their beliefs and examining their own lives more deeply. Director Jane Smith takes risks with her unconventional storytelling approach, resulting in a movie that's both thought-provoking and entertaining. Her portrayal of the rawness of human emotions and the deceptively simple storylines are utterly breathtaking, while the haunting score adds another layer to the movie's intense atmosphere. You the Living? will make you laugh, ponder, and even shed a tear as it takes you on an emotional roller coaster ride that delves into the common struggles and joys of everyday life. As the credits roll, you'll leave the theater contemplating the beauty and complexity of the human experience. So, if you're in for a captivating, soul-stirring film that might just change your perspective on life, make sure to catch You the Living? in theaters now. You won't regret it!

Our results demonstrated that the presence of an intracellular pathogen, such as T. cruzi, is able to impair HIV-1 transduction in an in vitro system of human placental histoculture. Direct effects of the parasite on cellular structures as well as on cellularviral proteins essential for HIV-1 replication might influence viral transduction in this model. Nonetheless, additional mechanisms including modulation of cytokineschemokines at placental level could not be excluded in the inhibition observed. Further experiments need to be conducted in order to elucidate the mechanism (s) involved in this phenomenon. Therefore, coinfection with T. cruzi may have a deleterious effect on HIV-1 transduction and thus could play an important role in viral outcome at the placental level.

Yes, platelet-activating factor receptor (PAF-R) mediates oxidized low-density lipoprotein (ox-LDL) -induced migration of bone marrow-derived mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs). According to studies, ox-LDL plays a role in the migration and proliferation of MSCs, and this process is mediated by the activation of PAF-R. MSCs express PAF-R, and activation of the receptor by ox-LDL can lead to increased migration of the cells, which contributes to processes like tissue repair, inflammation, and atherosclerosis. Targeting and modulating this receptor might be of therapeutic interest in the context of MSC-based cell therapies and in controlling pathological events where MSC migration is involved.

Washington Post Journalist Faces Charges Proven "Absurd" Washington Post journalist, Jason Rezaian, has finally had the charges against him made public after months of being held by Iranian officials. Rezaian and his wife were arrested in July for unspecified allegations. The charges brought against him were made public last week, after a long and suspenseful wait. Both the Washington Post and the State Department have deemed the charges against Rezaian absolutely "absurd." They are standing by their employee throughout this difficult time and it appears that clearer information will be required to have him released from custody. The Washington Post's Executive Editor, Martin Baron, has also made statements to reinforce their position in supporting Rezaian. "Any charges brought against Jason Rezaian are absurd, should be immediately dismissed, and he should be immediately freed from custody," Baron said. Representatives from the State Department have also released statements in defense of Rezaian and the charges against him. "We just wanted to say on the record that that's absurd, about as silly as the very idea of a secret underground lair where he was waging untold war against the brutal Mullahcracy," said State Department officials. Fans and supporters of Rezaian have voiced their concerns for his case and how it has been handled. Many are questioning why Jason and his wife were arrested in the first place and are demanding further explanation for these "absurd" charges.

Recent changes in the format of the ABSITE to a 2-tiered examination in 2006 and subsequent plan to return to a unified test for all PGY levels has made preparation difficult. With a more focused, question-based approach to studying, residents may see a demonstrable improvement in their scores. Our study supports this hypothesis-showing that residents who complete more review questions had higher ABSITE percentile scores. In the past, it has been demonstrated that strong ABSITE scores are associated with higher written board scores. With the widespread adoption of the Surgical Council on Resident Education curriculum, we postulate that residency programs that rely on this review question-based curriculum will report improved ABSITE percentile scores and written board pass rates.

Major General James Post III fired over A-10 Warthog "treason" comment Last week, Major General James Post III was fired after expressing his opinion on the retirement of the A-10 Warthog aircraft, stating that the decision amounted to 'treason.' His highly debated opinion has added fuel to an already existing controversy over efforts to retire the low-flying, tank-killer plane, which is widely renowned by ground troops. Post defended himself by stating that his choice of the term "treason" was for dramatic effect, rather than a legal statement. However, his decision to voice his opinions has left some questioning whether it was right that his comments led to his dismissal. Major General Post previously held the position of Vice Commander of Air Combat Command, and reportedly made the controversial statement during a discussion in a room full of officers back in January, 2015. Post is reported to have said, "If anyone accuses me of saying this, I will deny it ... anyone who is passing information to Congress about A-10 capabilities is committing treason." However, Post has since said that the context of his statements has been misunderstood. He stated that the Air Force did not want to retire the A-10 Warthog, but felt that it had no other choice due to existing budget constraints. Despite the other implications of his statements, Post's use of the term "treason" has led to his firing, ending his 32-year career. He expressed remorse for his actions by saying "The objective of my comment was simply meant to focus the attention of the audience on working within the command's constraints." The A-10 Warthog has provided the US with four decades of military service, which has included seeing ground-attack action in Iraq, Afghanistan, and most recently against ISIS.

The cloaked similarity between HIV-1 and SARS-CoV might suggest potential strategies for developing treatments against SARS-CoV. Both viruses use a similar mechanism to evade the host immune system, such as the presence of the envelope glycoproteins that are concealed under sugar molecules (glycans). However, despite the similarity in their glycan shielding, the two viruses have different structures, replication mechanisms, and target cells. An effective treatment or strategy for one virus may not necessarily work for the other virus. Nonetheless, studying the similarities between the two viruses may help identify potential targets for antiviral therapies and vaccines. Researchers can leverage the knowledge gained from HIV research to inform the development of SARS-CoV (and SARS-CoV-2) treatment strategies. Studying the glycan shielding in HIV has led to the development of broadly neutralizing antibodies against the virus, and similar strategies could be explored for SARS-CoV as well. However, it is important to note that HIV and SARS-CoV are fundamentally different viruses, with SARS-CoV being a coronavirus, and HIV-1 being a lentivirus (a type of retrovirus). Therefore, while similarities in certain aspects may guide researchers in identifying potential strategies, it is essential to consider the unique aspects of each virus when developing treatments.

'Kondogbia was incredible for Monaco, he was exactly the player Arsenal needed to sign,' Sportsmail's Jamie Redknapp said back in February. The French midfielder had just put in a dominant display at the Emirates Stadium as the Ligue 1 side all-but-sealed their place in the quarter-finals of the Champions League after a 3-1 first-leg win. But rather than Arsenal, it now seems Liverpool hold the main Premier League interest in the 22-year-old. So, what more do you need to know? Monaco midfielder Geoffrey Kondogbia is a Liverpool target and has also interested Arsenal in recent years . 22? He's been around for a while... Despite his young age, Kondogbia has amassed over 100 league appearances for Lens, Monaco, and even Sevilla. And during that five-year professional career, the central midfielder has been constantly watched by Arsenal scouts. He also impressed at the FIFA Under-20 World Cup alongside Paul Pogba in the French midfield, while his frame and playing style doesn't exactly scream 22 years old. Kondogbia is only 22 but has racked up over 100 league appearances with Lens (above), Sevilla and Monaco . The central midfielder was a key player for France alongside Paul Pogba at the Under 20 World Cup in 2013 . Tough guy then? Exactly. Standing at 6'2," Kondogbia is a real presence in the Monaco midfield, allowing the likes of Joao Moutinho to strut their stuff further forward. He's strong in the tackle, but make no mistake, his prowess on the ball is also impressive. Possessing a fine left foot, Kondogbia doubles up as a playmaker, and also scored the first goal in the tie in the first leg against Arsenal. Having made his mark in both Ligue 1 and La Liga, you could say the Frenchman is the perfectly well-rounded midfielder, someone who would fit in seamlessly in the Premier League... Kondogbia's fine strike put Monaco in front against Arsenal in the Champions League last-16 first leg . So why haven't we seen him in England? Time is still on Kondogbia's side, but Premier League clubs have certainly tried. Arsenal were heavily linked with him before he left Sevilla, though the versatile player bought out his contract and opted for Monaco. With Liverpool crying out for players to freshen up an ageingdeparting spine, the 22-year-old's presence would surely suit Brendan Rodgers. But he must move quick, withReal Madrid, Manchester United, Juventus and Paris St Germain all keen to sign the man who has been capped three times by his national team. Mesut Ozil swapped shirts with Kondogbia at half-time in the second leg at the Stade Louis II .

I like all of the main actors involved in this quite bizarre film. Their performances were truly captivating as they each brought their unique touch to their eccentric characters. The plot may have been far-fetched, but it was the undeniable chemistry between the actors that made this film a wild, memorable ride. The art direction and set design deserve a special mention as they managed to create a visually stunning world that was both surreal and intriguing. From the moments of striking color contrasts to the whimsical scenery, the film was a feast for the eyes. However, the film's erratic pacing and seemingly endless twists and turns did make for a somewhat confusing viewing experience. The disjointed storyline may have been intentional to match the bizarre premise, but it certainly left some viewers scratching their heads. Overall, this movie was a roller coaster of surreal visuals, mesmerizing performances, and a convoluted plot that has managed to spark countless conversations and debates. While it may not be everyone's cup of tea, those looking for a unique and unexpected cinematic experience will definitely appreciate this peculiar gem.

AP McCoy Rides Don Cossack to Victory in Melling Chase Jockey AP McCoy has won the Melling Chase at the Randox Grand National Festival, riding horse Don Cossack to victory during one of the event's most anticipated races on Friday. McCoy will ride Shutthefrontdoor, the favorite for the prestigious Aintree race, on Saturday. McCoy, 45, demonstrated once again why he's considered a legend in horse racing, expertly guiding Don Cossack through a thrilling race that only cemented his reputation as a jockey not to be underestimated. The victory comes during a festival in which McCoy announced he would be retiring from racing this year.

ASCENDING to power in 1933, Hitler and his "National Socialist German Workers Party," which of course we all know as the Nazis, tightened their grip on the country more and more as time went by. This chilling and gripping story is expertly portrayed in the movie, "The Rise and Fall." The film seamlessly weaves together the personal and the political, giving us an intimate portrait of a leader and his loyal followers while revealing the dangerous ideologies and ruthless tactics that swept through the nation. The cinematography and the visuals of 1930s Germany are hauntingly beautiful, effortlessly capturing the sinister mood of the time. The director deftly balances the wide-reaching ramifications of the regime with the human aspect of the story, allowing us to deeply understand and empathize with both the victims and the perpetrators of the Holocaust. The movie doesn't shy away from the horrors but also doesn't indulge in them gratuitously, striking the perfect balance between historical accuracy and narrative sensitivity. The ensemble cast featuring both seasoned actors and up-and-coming stars bring their awe-inspiring performances, fully embodying the complex characters they portray. The unapologetically authentic portrayals of these individuals make the events of the time feel more real and accessible to modern audiences. What sets "The Rise and Fall" apart from other films of this genre is its ability to offer fresh insights into the events of this dark chapter in history. By providing political, social, and psychological context, it complicates the narrative and challenges the simplistic notion of the Nazis as pure "villains." Instead, it forces the viewers to confront the unsettling truth of how ordinary people can be swept up in a tide of evil and violence when they have been manipulated and led astray. In conclusion, "The Rise and Fall" is a masterfully crafted film that effortlessly captures the essence of one of history's darkest periods. With its unflinching portrayal of the turmoil, captivating performances, and fresh insights, this movie is an important and chilling reminder of the capability of humanity for both greatness and depravity. It is not only a must-watch for history buffs but also an essential viewing for anyone who wishes to understand the dangers of blind obedience and the consequences of apathy in the face of injustice.

Xabi Alonso: Following the Steps of European Football Legend Clarence Seedorf Former Liverpool and Real Madrid star, Xabi Alonso, has a chance to emulate the incomparable success of European football legend, Clarence Seedorf, as his current team, Bayern Munich, prepares to face Porto in the UEFA Champions League quarter-final. Seedorf is known for his incredible record as the only player to have won the UEFA Champions League with three different clubs - Ajax, Real Madrid, and twice with AC Milan. Alonso's illustrious career stands out as he secured victories in the UEFA Champions League with both Liverpool and Real Madrid. During his first season with Liverpool, Alonso scored the critical equalizing goal that led to the club's victory. The talented Spaniard was also part of Real Madrid's triumphant side last season. Now, as a crucial player for Bayern Munich, Alonso has an opportunity to join Seedorf in the renowned status of winning the prestigious European title with three clubs. The highly anticipated quarter-final match against Porto will be the first step in achieving this extraordinary feat. Xabi Alonso's journey to potentially matching Clarence Seedorf's exceptional record highlights the incredible skill and passion of these two elite football players. As fans eagerly await the outcome of the UEFA Champions League quarter-final, the possibilities for both Bayern Munich and the legendary Xabi Alonso are limitless.

Ipilimumab, a monoclonal antibody that targets cytotoxic T-lymphocyte-associated protein 4 (CTLA-4), has been shown to significantly improve overall survival for patients with advanced melanoma. Since its approval by the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) in 2011, there have been several clinical updates on the use of ipilimumab in the treatment of advanced melanoma. 1. Combination therapy: Combining ipilimumab with other immunotherapeutic agents, such as anti-PD1 checkpoint inhibitors like nivolumab and pembrolizumab, has demonstrated improved response rates compared to monotherapy. A phase III trial (CheckMate-067) showed that the combination of ipilimumab and nivolumab resulted in improved progression-free survival and overall survival compared with ipilimumab alone or nivolumab alone. 2. Adjuvant therapy: Adjuvant ipilimumab therapy has been studied in resected stage III melanoma patients. The phase III EORTC 18071 trial demonstrated a significant improvement in recurrence-free survival in patients receiving ipilimumab compared to placebo. 3. Optimizing dosing and schedules: Newer clinical trials have explored different dosages, durations, and schedules of ipilimumab administration to optimize efficacy and minimize side effects. For instance, reducing the dose of ipilimumab when given in combination with nivolumab may result in a better safety profile without compromising treatment benefits. 4. Predictive biomarkers: Identifying biomarkers that can predict which patients are most likely to benefit from ipilimumab treatment remains an ongoing area of research. Factors like baseline tumor size, early changes in tumor burden, and immune-related gene signatures may help select patients more likely to respond to the therapy. 5. Managing immune-related adverse events: Clinical experience has led to improved management strategies for ipilimumab's immune-related adverse events (irAEs), such as rash, diarrhea, hepatitis, and hypophysitis. Early recognition and the use of immunosuppressive medications like corticosteroids or other immune-modulating drugs have helped manage these side effects while maintaining treatment efficacy. In conclusion, ipilimumab has significantly impacted the treatment of advanced melanoma, with ongoing research focused on optimizing its use, minimizing side effects, and identifying predictive biomarkers for optimal patient selection.

Person1: Awful! My cell phone is out of service again. Fred, can you lend me some money? Person2: How much do you want? Person1: 200 yuan. I bought a new computer online, so I have to pay the mortgage. Person2: I am so sorry to hear that. Is that enough? Person1: It's so nice of you. You really make my day. Person2: Forget it! We seemingly need to gather money little by little. Person1: What you said is absolutely right. I will pay you back as soon as I get back on my feet. Person2: No rush. You can give it back whenever you have it.

A man has been arrested in connection with the death of a transgender escort who was found strangled and beaten last month. Vanessa Santillan's body was found in a 400,000 flat in Fulham, south west London, at the end of March. The 33-year-old Mexican national, who worked as a transgender escort, died as a result of injuries to the head and neck. Vanessa Santillan, 33, was killed at the end of March. Her body was found in a flat in Fulham having been strangled and beaten to death . A 23-year-old man was arrested in connection with her death but has been bailed. He has been told to return to a London police station for further questioning at a later date. Meanwhile Scotland Yard is appealing to anyone who may have had contact with Miss Santillan in the hours before her death. According to her website Miss Santillan worked in London, Paris and Miami as an escort. Police did not confirm whether her profession was central to the investigation but insisted they would do 'everything' to solve the case. London Ambulance Service was called to a flat in Romily Court, Fulham, on March 28 at around 9.30pm. Miss Santillan was pronounced dead at the scene having suffered injuries to her head and neck. The woman had been working as a transgender escort, her website revealed. Miss Santillan is understood to have moved to London from Mexico . The woman, who described herself as visiting London from Miami, was pronounced dead at the scene last month . Miss Santillan spoke of her love for London and Paris online in the weeks before her death. Police are urging anyone who had contact with her in the hours before her death to come forward . Detective Chief Inspector Rebecca Reeves, who leads the investigation, said: 'We want to speak to anyone who saw Vanessa on Friday or Saturday. 'We need to know why this has happened and we want help from anyone who knew her while she was in London.' In the weeks before her death Miss Santillan took to social media to talk of her love for London. On her website she described herself as visiting from Miami in search of 'upscale' gentlemen. Miss Santillan's body was found when London Ambulance Service was called to an address in Fulham, south west London . Sorry we are not currently accepting comments on this article.

Carrot Top's "Chairman of the Board" and his ATT commercials are living proof that fly-blown fecal matter is available in the color orange. Not FREELY available, however, as HBO charges for such garbage. Blehhh! The saving grace of COTB is that it surely fills suicide hot-lines across the country, perhaps providing employment for thousands of telephone therapists who lost their jobs when recovered memory treatment was discredited, although (sadly) Carrot Top probably contributes to his sponsor ATT's bottom line with the increased phone traffic from devastated HBO viewers. I can visualize the hordes of traumatized TV viewers, phone in one hand and fully loaded .45 auto in the other hand, dialing out of last-minute desperation before walking off the plank of life to escape the specter of COTB's orange-haired monster echoing in their synapses like the agony of searing, irreversible meningeal swelling.

Person1: Tim, you're going to talk about your project and how to lead a greener life. Why did you choose that subject? Person2: Well. We'd learned a lot about the environment in our science lessons, so I decided to see what I could do in my own life rather than just act completely helpless. And I knew the rest of my family would be interested. Person1: Did you find it easy to get information? Person2: Yeah, I discovered there were lots of people at my age trying to be green. I'd always gone to school by car. Catching a bus would be better, but there's no bus where we live. So I've gone for riding my bike to school now. Person1: OK. And what about being green once you're actually at school? Person2: Well, I realized that although all school paper was recycled and most of my friends use both sides of paper. We use huge quantities and I thought we should cut down and then it came to me that we should be sending in most of our work electronically. I'm going to recommend it to our teachers. Person1: And what about the school cafeteria? Person2: One school I've read about has meatless Mondays. It's good to use local produce, too. That something our school already does, but we still have machines with bottled milk, water and juices for sale. And I think we shouldn't have them.

The predictive value of intraoperative nerve monitoring varies greatly depending on the stimulation levels used. At low amplitudes of stimulation, nerve monitoring has high sensitivity and negative predictive value but low specificity and positive predictive value, related to the high rate of false positives. At high levels of stimulation, specificity and negative predictive value are high, sensitivity is low, and the positive predictive value rises as the rate of false negatives increase and the rate of false positives decrease. A stimulation level of 0.5 mA optimizes the predictive value of nerve monitoring; however, stimulation at multiple levels significantly improves the predictive value of intraoperative nerve monitoring.

DNA barcoding works in practice as a tool for species identification and discovery, but there may be some discrepancies when it comes to neutral theory. In practice, DNA barcoding involves using a standardized fragment of DNA (usually a gene sequence that is highly conserved across different species) to differentiate and identify species. The method has been successful in addressing issues of species identification, discovering cryptic species, and in biodiversity assessments. On the other hand, neutral theory is a concept in evolutionary biology that suggests that genetic diversity within populations is mostly driven by genetic drift and mutation, rather than selection. In other words, most observed genetic variation is functionally neutral, i.e., it doesn't affect the fitness of an organism. In the context of DNA barcoding, neutral theory highlights potential issues with using conserved gene sequences for species identification because there may be significant variation in these sequences that is irrelevant to the species' functional characteristics. For this reason, DNA barcoding might not align perfectly with neutral theory, since it largely relies on the assumption that small genetic differences between the sequences being compared are sufficient to differentiate species. However, while this may be a theoretical limitation, DNA barcoding has been shown to be an effective tool in practice for many applications. Careful consideration in choosing appropriate DNA sequences for barcoding and understanding the limitations of the method are necessary for its continued success.

(CNN) Sen. Elizabeth Warren insists she's not running for president. But her description of a 2016 "dream" presidential candidate sounds a lot like, well, her. Warren, during an appearance Friday on CNN's "New Day," said she wanted to see someone willing to fight for the middle class and "make Washington work for families again." Warren says she feels that Washington functions well for special interest groups and the well-connected but leaves out the rest of the nation. " (I've) spent my whole life studying what's happening to America's middle class and watching year by year, one blow after another," she said. "We live in an America now where the game is rigged, where Washington works really great for those who hire armies of lobbyists, armies of lawyers. It's just not working so well for the rest of America." Warren, a Massachusetts Democrat, also got specific with her wish list, mentioning that a candidate willing to lower the interest rates on student loans and shore up Social Security would get high marks from her. What the economy means for 2016 . She wouldn't say which of the slew of declared or yet-to-declare candidates fit that bill, but she did want to give all of them a chance as the 2016 campaign kicks off. "I really want to give everybody who gets in this race a chance to get out there and put their agenda in front of us," she said. However, Warren said the two Republican candidates who have gotten into the race Texas Sen. Ted Cruz and Kentucky Sen. Rand Paul have already disqualified themselves in her eyes because of how they've voted in Congress. "I've watched them vote," Warren said. "They voted against the Social Security benefits increase. They voted against reducing the interest rate on student loans." Opinion: Can Democrats really take on Wall Street? Warren, a former special adviser for the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, is something of a political rock star in the eyes of many liberal and progressive voters because of her populist leanings and her passionate calls for an end to income inequality. Many of them want her to get into the race and become a viable challenger to Democratic frontrunner Hilary Clinton. When asked, yet again, if she was going to run, Warren didn't exactly say no. "I want to see who else gets in this race," she said. "And I want to see what the issues are that they push."

Second-half goals by Mohamed Yattara and Alexandre Lacazette helped Olympique Lyonnais go top of Ligue 1 with a 2-0 home win against Bastia on Wednesday. Substitute Yattara opened the scoring in the 77th minute and Ligue 1 top scorer Lacazette took his tally to 25 eight minutes later to move Lyon up to 64 points from 32 games. French champions Paris Saint-Germain, who have one game in hand, are second two points off the pace. Alexandre Lacazette and Mohamed Yattara were both on the score sheet as Lyon beat Bastia . Guinean striker Yattara opens the scoring against Bastia on Wednesday at the Stade de Gerland . Lyon dominated throughout but were made to wait by Bastia, who were reeling from their 4-0 defeat in the League Cup final against PSG last Saturday. Lyon's Jordan Ferri dribbled past a defender before his curling shot was superbly saved by Alphonse Areola in the sixth minute. Areola was at it again when he blocked Steed Malbranque's back heel on the half hour and tipped away Clinton Njie's low shot three minutes before the break as Lyon continued to dominate. Lacazette seals victory and top spot in the French Ligue 1 for Lyon in the second half . Frenchman Lacazette is the top scorer in Ligue 1 this season with 25 goals to his name . Malbranque was substituted in the 62nd minute and replaced with France international Clement Grenier, who was making his comeback after an eight-month injury layoff. Nabil Fekir was not having his usual influence in the Lyon midfield and was replaced in the 74th minute with Yattara, who had an immediate impact, scoring three minutes later with a shot on the turn from Grenier's pass. Lacazette wrapped it up from close range five minutes before full-time, converting Njie's cross from the left.

I've just been at the cinema in downtown Prague watching this film, and I must say it was absolutely captivating. Titled "Bridges of the Past," the film explores the intricate connections between people who discover that their ancestors have crossed paths throughout history. The movie features a stellar ensemble cast that brings some truly memorable characters to life. From a lovelorn woman trying to discover her roots to a history professor who finds himself entangled in his own investigations, each character's journey masterfully intertwines with one another as they attempt to uncover secrets hidden deep within the city's historical past. Kudos to director Milan Kubes for crafting a multilayered story that keeps you guessing until the very end! What I found particularly fascinating was the rich portrayal of Prague's culture and history, with its cobblestone streets, ancient bridges, vibrant nightlife, and more. The film makes you feel as if you are right there in the heart of the city, exploring and uncovering mysteries yourself. The screenplay, written by Jiri Polak, is sharp and witty, with snappy dialogue that never descends into cliche. The film expertly balances moments of drama and suspense with lighter comedic scenes, providing a sense of balance to what might have otherwise felt like a heavy-handed story. The cinematography is also top-notch, with sweeping shots that capture the beauty of Prague and intimate scenes that make you feel like a fly on the wall. However, the film's true strength lies in its themes of fate, connection, and the impact of our ancestors on our lives. "Bridges of the Past" poses profound questions about whether we are truly in control of our destinies or merely pawns in a vast, interconnected web of events. While the film offers no definitive answers, it invites the viewer to ponder these concepts long after the credits roll. In conclusion, "Bridges of the Past" is a must-see for those who enjoy thought-provoking stories, breathtaking visuals, and strong performances. While it is deeply rooted in the city of Prague, the film extends its reach beyond the Czech Republic, resonating with viewers around the world. Do yourself a favor and catch this beautifully crafted gem before it leaves theaters.

Our data suggest that reproduction does not significantly reduce the predatory efficiency of gravid C. sculpturatus, and that these females can cope with increasing body mass and the physiological costs of gestation. However, the observation that brooding females and females 24 hours FOR did not catch prey within the trial period indicates that maternal care significantly reduces predatory efficiency in these scorpions. Females 28 days FOR were still not as efficient at catching prey as non-gravid and gravid females, suggesting that reproductive costs extend for at least 4 weeks after the end of the maternal care period. Preferential use of an active foraging strategy by brooding females may increase prey encounter rates, allowing the scorpions to more rapidly replenish energy reserves depleted during reproduction. However, active foraging may be energetically costly and increase predation risk for brooding females. Our findings regarding antagonistic interactions between reproduction and feeding in female C. sculpturatus demonstrate the pervasive nature of reproductive costs for viviparous females, and may provide insight on factors that influence the diversity of reproductive strategies observed in nature.

There is evidence to suggest an association between the COMT val158met polymorphism and peak bone mineral density (BMD) in men. Some studies have reported that men carrying the met158 allele may have higher peak BMD, thus potentially decreasing their risk of osteoporosis and bone fractures. However, further research is needed to confirm these findings and to understand the mechanisms underlying this relationship.

There is evidence to suggest that thyroid hormone can influence the expression of opsins in the retinas of salmonid fish and may play a role in the opsin switch. A study by Allison et al. (2006) showed that thyroid hormone treatment could induce an opsin switch in juvenile Atlantic salmon, leading to a change in their visual sensitivity. This opsin switch is believed to be related to the fish's developmental changes and migration from freshwater to seawater habitats in a process called smoltification. The change in light conditions in these different habitats requires a shift in visual sensitivity, and thyroid hormone may help regulate this adaptive response. However, more research is needed to fully understand the mechanisms and time-dependent effects of thyroid hormone on opsin expression and visual function in salmonid fish.

A heroic army dog who lost her entire front leg while clearing a Taliban compound on patrol in Afghanistan has a new home with one of the men she saved. This week, US Army Staf Sgt Julian McDonald, welcomed 4-year-old Layka, a Belgian Malinois, into his Columbus, Ohio home after fighting to adopt her for two years. Layka was on her eighth overseas military tour with Sgt. McDonald in 2012 when she was shot four times at point blank range by an enemy fighter armed with an AK-47. Scroll down for video . Great team:U.S. Army Staff SGT. Julian McDonald (left) of Columbus, Ohio has welcomed a 4-year-old Belgian Malinois named Layka (right) into his home after she protected him in Afghanistan in 2012 . Injured:Despite being injured, Layka completed the mission with her team and her wounds were treated upon her return to safe territory . Best friends: Layka and McDonald's son Liam have become best friends and they play daily . Her comrades rushed her back for emergency surgery during which she had her leg amputated as the cost for saving them. So endebted to her for the selfless bravey she showed in combat, Sgt. McDonald decided that he must bring her home to live with his young family. 'I realized I had a responsibility to take care of her, just as she took care of me,' said Sgt. McDonald to ABC News. 'She saved our lives and I owed it to her to obviously save hers.' Medal of honor:Even though Layka no longer has her right leg, she has a new family to keep her safe and a medal of honor in recognition of her bravery. Fast friends: Layka is gentle with McDonald's children despite being trained to attack enemy soldiers . In Afghanistan: While McDonald was on his eight overseas military tour and completing a mission to clear an enemy compound with Lyka, a man started to shoot at them . McDonald told ABC that Layka adapted to civilian life quickly and that she became fast friends with his son Liam. 'Her excitement brought me to tears,'McDonald says. 'She was the sole reason why I was living and breathing and able to come home to my son and wife.' McDonald says that Layka will always hold a special place near his heart. The U.S. military deploys more than 500 dogs worldwide at any given time. Each year a few are killed in action.

What are Forest Whitaker and Clifton Collins Jr. doing in this? Despite their unquestionable talents, they find themselves in "A Walk in the Shadows," the latest addition to muddled crime thrillers that fail to land a memorable impact. Both Whitaker and Collins Jr. play detectives assigned to investigate a serial killer's mysterious spree, but their skills are wasted on a script that lacks depth and innovation. Instead, the film sluggishly meanders through a series of cliched action sequences and predictable twists. While it is true that both actors deliver an adequate performance, their on-screen chemistry can't elevate the uninspired dialogue they are given. Consequently, the viewers are left feeling disconnected from their characters and the stakes in this cat-and-mouse game. On a positive note, the film delivers some visually striking cinematography that captures the eeriness of the crime scenes and adds a layer of atmosphere to an otherwise weak ensemble. However, it is not enough to save it from drowning in a sea of similar, stronger genre entries. In the end, "A Walk in the Shadows" is a disappointing exploit of Forest Whitaker and Clifton Collins Jr.'s remarkable capabilities. Die-hard fans of crime thrillers might find some enjoyment in their performances, but it's unlikely to stand the test of time or generate any buzz. Better to walk right by and find stronger offerings from these great actors elsewhere.
