An elderly woman is in critical condition after being run over by her husband as he smashed into three cars whilst attempting to parallel park. The woman, 84, is thought to have been helping her husband park when the car accelerated into her, resulting in a serious head injury. She also suffered injuries to her throat and legs, as well as various broken bones, and one onlooker said the woman was 'covered in blood'. The Tesco Express where the elderly couple were going to shop when she was run over by her husband . Emergency services were called to Kirby Drive, Peacehaven, Lewes, East Sussex, just after 10am on Easter Sunday. Before the paramedic car and ambulance arrived she was comforted by a Tesco employee who held her in her arms. She was then taken to hospital in the ambulance accompanied by an air ambulance, which was used to give additional support. The woman was then taken to the Royal Sussex County Hospital in Brighton, East Sussex and doctors placed her in a medically-induced coma. She remains in a critical but stable condition. Police want to speak to her once she is out of the coma. Out of control: the lampost were the car eventually stopped after causing carnage . The driver, also 84, hit three parked cars - a Lexus, a Mazda S Sport and a Vauxhall Astra - as well as a wall before the automatic Toyota Yaris came to rest by a lamp post. The driver, who was shaken but unhurt, was breathalysed by police as a precaution. No arrests have been made. One witness, Grace Palmer, 29, of Peacehaven, Lewes, East Sussex said: 'She looked quite shaken up, she was covered in blood. 'I saw the car up against the lamp post and five police cars parked outside the front of Tesco.' Another onlooker, who did not wish to be named, said: 'It looked like a bit of a nightmare.'

Yes, training of cochlear implant users can improve pitch perception in the presence of competing place cues. Cochlear implant (CI) users often face challenges in pitch perception due to degraded spectral information and poor place coding. To overcome these difficulties, specialized auditory training programs have been developed to enhance pitch perception and optimize the use of available cues. These training programs focus on improving the CI users' ability to discriminate pitch and recognize complex sound patterns like speech and music. These training programs can be either computer-based or therapist-led and usually involve tasks that require the listener to identify, compare, or categorize pitches or pitch contours. The tasks may start simple and gradually increase in complexity, incorporating complex note sequences and varying sound sources. Research has shown that such training can lead to improved pitch perception for CI users. These improvements can, in turn, lead to better speech recognition in noise, music perception, and overall communication ability. However, it is important to note that individual outcomes may vary depending on factors such as duration of deafness, age at implantation, and cognitive abilities. In conclusion, training of cochlear implant users can help improve pitch perception in the presence of competing place cues, but the outcomes may vary depending on individual factors. Continuous research and development of training strategies are essential to enhance the benefits of cochlear implantation and improve the quality of life for these individuals.

I never fell asleep during a movie, until I watched the snoozefest that was "The Slumbering." It started off with a promising premise - a mysterious sleep epidemic causing the world's population to fall into a deep slumber, with a group of insomniacs scrambling to find a solution. However, the film quickly descended into a series of drawn-out and tiresome discussions amongst the group about the nature of sleep and its impact on humanity. I found myself struggling to keep my eyes open as it felt like the filmmakers were trying their hardest to make the audience fall asleep in an unfortunate example of life imitating art. The film's pacing was unbearably slow, and its lackluster performances did nothing to hold my interest. The main characters were one-dimensional, and even though they were supposed to be insomniacs, they seemed to have no sense of urgency in their pursuit to save the world. The subplot involving a forbidden love between two of the insomniacs never really took off and felt more like an afterthought used to pad out the film's runtime. Visually, "The Slumbering" delivered sparse and bland cinematography. The lack of vibrant and creative visuals only added to the monotony of the film, and the eerie score seemed to be trapped in a never-ending loop that lulled the audience into a dreary state of mind. In conclusion, "The Slumbering" is a film that can be summed up in one word: sleepy. It tries to tackle big ideas about sleep and human existence but ends up being a boring and forgettable experience. I'd recommend something much more exciting and well-executed to spend your time on - or if you're really struggling with insomnia, maybe "The Slumbering" could at least serve a practical purpose.

This would probably be a good film to see....provided you've already seen every other film in existence, and thoroughly explored the bellybuttons of yourself and those around you. God, this movie was unbelievably insipid, with some of the worst (or is it nonexistent) writing ever captured on film. There is no saving grace to this film; even the animatronics are kind of lame, and it's just a complete waste of time and money.Run. Fast. It's beyond horrible.

Former Chelsea defender Paulo Ferreira expects his compatriot Jose Mourinho to remain in charge at Stamford Bridge for 'a long, long time'. The Portuguese manager, 52, is leading the Blues towards their fourth Barclays Premier League title in his second stint at Stamford Bridge - two championships arrived during his original tenure. Retired right-back Ferreira, who followed Mourinho from Porto in 2004 before spending nine years in west London, believes his countryman's desire to succeed with Chelsea knows no bounds. Jose Mourinho is on the cusp of winning his third Premier League title during two spells with Chelsea . Former defender PauloFerreira expects Mourinho to stay at Chelsea for a long, long time . He said: 'When you are at this club you want to win titles and for next season it will be the same. The motivation is to win trophies. 'He wants to succeed and do well, for how long I do not know. I think everyone at the club wants him to stay for a long, long time. 'I think everyone would like to see him in control for many years but in football, anything can happen.' While Mourinho remains the toast of SW6 and still has two years on his latest Chelsea contract, another recently returned club favourite could be on his way out this summer. Didier Drogba has scored only three league goals since rejoining on a one-year contract last July, but Ferreira hopes the Ivorian striker, now 37, gets to experience a 10th season with the Blues. Former Portugal internationalFerreira would also like to see Didier Drogba extend his stay at Stamford Bridge . Speaking on behalf of club sponsors Gazprom, Ferreira added: 'I would love to see him stay for another season but I don't know what he wants or what the club wants from him. 'Let's see what happens at the end of the season. 'He has the motivation to keep winning and keep playing and I want to hear what happens at the end of the season.' Ferreira played for Chelsea for nine years after following Mourinho from Porto in 2004 . Ferreira has been kept busy representing Chelsea as their European youth league ambassador but is also taking his coaching badges. The 36-year-old has not ruled out pursuing a role within the Blues' training set-up at Cobham. He added: 'I've just finished my (UEFA) B licence so I need two more years to finish, I hope. 'At the moment I'm just concentrating on finishing and then let's see what happens. It's just important to have it and then, who knows?' Paulo Ferreira was speaking on behalf of Gazprom, the energy behind Chelsea FC and a funding partner of the Chelsea Foundation Pimlico Premier League Kicks programme.

Richard Gere Diane Lane back again in another romantic love story, bringing the captivating chemistry they're known for in their latest film, "Endless Love." This heartwarming movie takes us on a spellbinding journey of love, forgiveness, and second chances, tugging on our heartstrings as the characters rediscover love in the autumn of their lives. Set against the picturesque backdrop of a coastal town, the film is visually enchanting, with breathtaking sceneries and warm hues adding richness to the love story that unfolds. The exceptional cinematography and brilliant direction allow viewers to immerse themselves in the idyllic landscapes and blooming romance between Gere and Lane's characters. Both Gere and Lane deliver outstanding performances, brilliantly portraying the vulnerability, resilience, and longing of their characters. Their emotionally charged moments and playful banter are a testament to their acting prowess, making their characters relatable and endearing. The supporting cast complements the on-screen magic of the lead pair, with notable performances adding depth to the film. The movie effectively tackles themes of self-discovery, acceptance, and the importance of cherishing the present moment. The script is beautifully penned and replete with poignancy, reminding us that love has no age limits. The mesmerizing soundtrack, which flawlessly complements the movie's narrative, leaves an indelible impression on the viewer's soul. "Endless Love" is an uplifting cinematic experience that leaves you with poignant emotions and a renewed sense of hope. It's a must-watch for fans of Richard Gere and Diane Lane, as well as anyone seeking a love story that resonates deeply and genuinely. Prepare to laugh, cry, and be swept away by this timeless tale of love and human connection.

Compromised mesenteric blood flow causes significant metabolic and histologic changes. These local changes could not be detected by arterial or mixed venous lactate concentrations, pH, and PCO2 determinations. Under closed-system conditions, mesenteric CO2 accumulation causes an impairment of the CO2-HCO3- buffer, resulting in an unchanged cHCO3-. With impaired mesenteric perfusion, only intramucosal PCO2 alterations occur and an intramucosal pH calculation based on systemic cHCO3-changes is not necessarily correct. Therefore, the only parameter of importance is the intraluminal measurement of intramucosal PCO2 that can reflect isolated mesenteric changes. Thus, we recommended abolishing the terms "intramucosal pH measurement" and "gastric tonometry" and propose using the definition "intramucosal PCO2 measurement."

BBC iPlayer plagued by missing endings in popular radio dramas Listeners of BBC's iPlayer have complained about the unexpected cut-off in the vital last minutes of several radio dramas, including popular shows like Dad's Army and Hancock's Half Hour. The broadcaster has blamed this issue on the system it uses to record programmes but it seems it is not a new problem. Fans of classic radio shows have voiced their annoyance on social media, stating that the endings of their favourite shows have been abruptly cut off, leaving them without proper conclusions. Some of the dramas affected by this problem include the aforementioned Dad's Army and Hancock's Half Hour, leaving fans without resolution to their beloved stories. The BBC has acknowledged the issue and placed blame on the system it uses to record programmes. However, it has come to light that this problem has been persisting for quite some time now. Listeners have reportedly been experiencing abrupt endings to their favourite radio dramas for a while, indicating that this is not a isolated incident. Long-time fan of the broadcaster's content, Michael Gallagher, explained his frustration: "It's infuriating when you're engrossed in a brilliant radio drama, only for the ending to be snatched away from you. It's as if someone has ripped the last chapter out of a book. The problem doesn't seem to be new either, as I've experienced it on several occasions." As the issue persists, BBC iPlayer users have voiced their concerns, urging the broadcaster to fix these technical difficulties so they can enjoy their favourite content without interruptions. As a public service broadcaster, the BBC is expected to provide quality content to its users, which includes not just excellent programming, but also reliable streaming. In response to the complaints, a BBC spokesperson said: "We're aware of the issue with some radio shows on BBC iPlayer and our technical teams are working to resolve it as quickly as possible. We apologise to any listeners affected." While this statement assures users that measures are being taken to fix the problem, no timeline has been given for when this might be fully resolved. As a significant platform for drama enthusiasts, the BBC iPlayer hosts a vast library of content, from classic shows like The Goon Show to contemporary offerings like The Archers. The loss of the climactic minutes of these programmes not only frustrates dedicated fans but also reflects poorly on the quality of the broadcaster's service. Until the issue is resolved, iPlayer listeners will have to either grin and bear it or seek alternative sources for the complete versions of their favourite radio dramas.

This movie moves and inspires you; it's like you are one of the family. The brilliantly crafted story takes you on an emotional roller-coaster as each character faces their own unique challenges. Sub-title: French photographer captures fascinating images of trees by photographing them from the bottom, revealing their own unique personality. Paris, France - French photographer Fabien Le Coq has captured something extraordinary in the seemingly ordinary subject of trees. In a collection of breathtaking photos, Le Coq takes viewers on a journey skyward, photographing trees from the bottom looking up, unveiling the hidden beauty and awe-inspiring patterns revealed by their branches. As the world around us continues to evolve rapidly with technology and urbanization, it is easy to lose sight of the natural wonders that surround our everyday lives. Le Coq's unique approach to photographing nature reminds us to appreciate the timeless beauty of trees and consider the unexplored perspectives that may reveal something new. "Each tree has its own personality," Le Coq explains, referring to the unique patterns and structures of the branches weaving across the sky. The images he captures are reminiscent of intricate mosaics or abstract paintings, demonstrating the splendor of the natural world when viewed from an unconventional angle. Le Coq began his journey in photography at a young age, inspired by the landscapes and natural beauty that surrounded him. As he refined his skills, he discovered a passion for capturing the magnificence of trees, which he believes are an essential part of our connection to the Earth. "The tree is the most anchored element in the ground, and at the same time, the one that rises most towards the sky," says Le Coq, emphasizing the symbolic importance of trees as connectors between the terrestrial and celestial realms. As Le Coq ventures into forests, parks, and natural settings, he aims to capture the essence of each tree's distinct personality, while also creating a sense of unity within the environment. His images emphasize the importance of our relationship with nature, a reminder to always appreciate and protect the planet on which we rely. Le Coq's work has gained significant attention in recent years, with exhibitions in Paris, New York, and other cities around the world. The striking images invite viewers to reconsider their relationship with nature and the environment, and ultimately, highlight the beauty and importance of trees in our lives. With the growing concern for environmental preservation and climate change, Le Coq's images serve as a timely reminder of the role that trees play on Earth. Through his innovative lens and profound appreciation of the natural world, Fabien Le Coq invites us all to take a moment, look up at the sky through the trees, and recognize their unique personalities in the world around us.

EC-SOD, the major scavenger of reactive oxygen species (ROS) in extracellular spaces and fluids, is decreased in late stage OA joint fluid compared to fluid from injuredpainful joints with intact cartilage. Injured joints may be able to increase or maintain secretion of EC-SOD but it appears that late stage OA joints fail to do so in spite of increased oxidative stress seen in the disease. Associated age related declines in GSH and ascorbate might also contribute to the development of severe OA. The net effect of these changes in joint fluid antioxidants is likely to accelerate the damaging oxidant effects on extracellular matrix stability in cartilage tissue.

'Absolutely Fabulous' Movie to Start Filming in Autumn Across the Globe LONDON - Jennifer Saunders has confirmed the long-awaited 'Absolutely Fabulous' movie will begin filming in London, France and the Bahamas in the autumn of 2015, spurred on by a 10,000 bet with her long-time comedy partner, Dawn French. The popular British television show, which originally aired in the early 90s, follows the outrageous adventures of best friends Edina (played by Saunders) and Patsy (played by Joanna Lumley). Saunders, who is responsible for creating the series and writing the scripts, revealed that it was her bet with Dawn French that finally pushed her to put pen to paper. The two comediennes had a wager that Saunders would have the script ready in time for their Christmas day radio show last year. Despite the fact that Saunders had the script "90 written" by then, French forced her to honour the bet by paying up the full 10,000. The 56-year-old actress said her co-star, Joanna Lumley, has been eager for them to create the movie, insisting they "do it before we die." The film adaptation is expected to feature a host of cameos, similar to the show's celebrity guest appearances, which have included artists such as Kate Moss and Elton John. 'Absolutely Fabulous' - known to its fans as Ab Fab - first aired on the BBC in 1992. It ran for five seasons and two television specials before ending in 2012, after garnering a loyal following and collecting numerous awards, including two International Emmy Awards. Fans of the show have been eagerly anticipating an 'Absolutely Fabulous' movie since the show's end. The film will now look to follow in the footsteps of other successful British television shows that have made the jump to the big screen, such as 'The Inbetweeners'. A release date for the movie is yet to be confirmed.

This has to be one of the most awfully scripted films I've ever seen. It's basically a remake of The Beast From 20,000 Fathoms (1953), but done with your standard snake-like puppet-monster instead of a sleek Ray Harryhausen creation. Combine the plot of that classic monster movie with the production qualities and acting level of The Creeping Terror and you have an idea of what this movie is like.The movie is dubbed, although by the original actors (I think that the movie was originally dubbed in Italian for that countries audiences, then redubbed for US release), which just makes the movie seem weird...the sounds, like in a Japanese monster movie, just don't quite match properly to the action on the screen, even if the actors' lips are moving properly.Poor Ray Milland...he's certainly come a long way down from The Lost Weekend or Dial M for Murder or any of the number of excellent movies he was in. Add this to his other sci-fi travesties (Panic in the Year Zero, X The Man with X-Ray Eyes) and you can see a once good actor fallen into a Boris Karloff syndrome...stuck doing really bad horror films in foreign countries just for the work.

This is a must for all but especially African Americans. "Something to Sing About" is not just a movie, it's a powerful experience that captivates and resonates with audiences from all backgrounds. The film is incredibly well-crafted, with a narrative that is simultaneously heart-wrenching and inspiring, evoking a myriad of emotions throughout its runtime. The cast is led by the incomparable Idris Elba, who delivers a truly unforgettable performance as Luke, a man grappling with the struggles and triumphs of his community. His portrayal is both raw and nuanced, allowing viewers to deeply empathize with his character's journey. Elba is supported by a remarkable ensemble cast, including Regina King, who shines as a fierce yet compassionate mother trying to hold her family together in the midst of adversity. What truly sets "Something to Sing About" apart is its unflinching look at the challenges faced by the African American community, offering a perspective that is both authentic and profound. The film tackles subjects such as systemic racism, gang violence, and poverty with grace and sensitivity, exposing these issues without exploiting them for cheap melodrama or easy answers. The powerful score, composed by Terence Blanchard, provides the perfect accompaniment to the story, its melodies giving voice to the emotions and aspirations of the characters. Combined with the exquisite cinematography by Bradford Young, the film envelops the audience in an almost tangible atmosphere of hope and resilience. In summary, "Something to Sing About" is not only a must-see film for African Americans but for all viewers seeking a genuine and thought-provoking cinematic experience. Its evocative storytelling, exceptional performances, and inspiring message make it a film that will stay with you long after the credits roll.

The efficacy of this picture was best proven on the intended target audience, namely teens. My 14-year-old son became so engrossed in this film that I rate it considerably higher than its imitator "Mad City." It sparked debate in our household on issues such as peer pressure and loyalty vs. doing the right thing. For that alone, I rate this film a 10! Parents should watch it with their teens and discuss it afterwards.I very much liked the smart dialogue and consistent acting. I thought that James Remar was adequate in his role, but the teenage cast really carried this picture. Other IMDB users have praised Corey Feldman's performance, which truly is inspired. All in all, I give this picture my highest recommendation. Go get this one!

Person1: Maggie, can I borrow your notes for history? I'll return them tomorrow. Person2: Sorry, but I usually go to the cafeteria and review them. Why not copy them in the library? Person1: OK. Person2: Here you are. Person1: You are a great help, Maggie. Person2: I don't quite understand a why you need my notes, Mark? You haven't missed any classes. Person1: To be honest, I work in supermarket from 7 to 10 o'clock every evening. Person2: I see. So you're pretty tired when you come to class. Person1: That's exactly why I want to borrow your notes. My notes aren't very good. Person2: So what do you usually do in class? Person1: I'm always awake at the beginning, but thirty minutes after class begins I feel sleepy and have trouble keeping my eyes open. Person2: Well, I need someone to study with and you need someone to keep you awake. Can we be study partners? Person1: Oh sure. That's a good idea. So give me a push when you see me sleeping in class. Person2: OK. Let's start today in the library. We are going there anyway and I don't have to go to the cafeteria. Person1: Sounds good.

Then, you'll have a 30-minute stretching session focusing on your major muscle groups. Person1: Stretching, got it. I assume lunch is up next? Person2: Yes, after stretching, you'll have a nutritious lunch. Following lunch, you'll head to the gym for some strength training and cardio exercises for about an hour. Thanks for the schedule! I'll get started tomorrow.

Yes, the core mechanism of dry eye disease is often inflammation. Inflammation can lead to an imbalance in the tear film, causing reduced tear production, increased tear evaporation, or changes in the composition of the tears. This can result in the common symptoms of dry eye, such as irritation, burning, redness, and blurred vision.

Yes, interim analyses can be conducted on data as they accumulate in laboratory experimentation. Interim analyses involve examining the accumulated data at specific points in the study before it is completed to assess the study's progress, safety, and potential need for modifications. These analyses can provide valuable insights about the effectiveness of the experiment and help in making informed decisions regarding the continuation of the study or adjustments to its design. However, it is essential to carefully plan and pre-specify the interim analyses to avoid introducing bias or compromising the study's integrity.

We're in a not so distant future, globalization seems to have reached a high point, languages mixes with each other (although English prevails over the rest), races have merged, human clonation is a fact, and all the territory seems to have been divided in two zones: the one for the valid and the one for the non-valid... a brave new world (in Aldous Huxley's style) in which people are genetically filed and blood relationships are strictly forbidden (for health reasons -that's the Code 46 of the title. "Code 46," directed by Michael Winterbottom, delves into this captivating and horrifying world, presenting us with a thrilling forbidden love story at its core. Starring Tim Robbins as William, an investigator looking into forged "papelles" (identification documents), and Samantha Morton as Maria, a non-valid woman working at a papelle production facility, their unexpected connection sends them down a dangerous path, challenging the very fabric of their society. The movie paints a disturbing picture of a future where individual identities are stripped and controlled by a faceless omnipresent government. Our protagonists' struggle to maintain their humanity amidst this cold, sterile world is portrayed brilliantly by the talented lead actors. Robbins and Morton share a palpable chemistry on screen, making us root for their relationship even when faced with the awful truth behind it. Visually, "Code 46" excels with its stunning cinematography, showcasing a multicultural, urban landscape that blends modern architecture with ancient, run-down buildings. The use of natural light and the warm color palette add a sense of realism, making the world feel uncomfortably familiar, while the slightly disjointed and poetic language adds to the film's intrigue. The haunting score by David Holmes perfectly complements the story, evoking the dark undercurrents running through the plot and the world itself. Winterbottom's direction is both subtle and powerful, forcing the audience to question their own moral compass and wonder what they would do if faced with such a reality. However, the movie might not be for everyone - its slow-paced nature and ambiguous ending may throw off viewers looking for a more straightforward sci-fi experience. But for those willing to immerse themselves in this unsettling world, "Code 46" provides a thought-provoking and emotionally charged experience. In conclusion, "Code 46" is a fascinating and, at times, distressing glimpse into a potential future, exploring themes of love, morality, and the loss of individuality in a world bound by rigid rules. With exceptional performances from Robbins and Morton, stunning visuals, and a thought-provoking premise, it's a must-watch for fans of dystopian sci-fi and intense character-driven stories.

Story about a widowed father (Claude Rains) bringing up his four daughters. Emma (Gale Page) is loved by big hunky Ernest (Dick Foran). Thea (Lola Lane) is romanced by an old but wealthy man. Kay (Rosemary Lane) wants to become a singer. Ann (Priscilla Lane) is a romantic. Drop dead handsome Felix Deitz (Jeffrey Lynn), a business associate of their father, comes to stay with them. All the sisters fall in love with him. Then tough cynical Mickey (John Garfield) enters the picture...Very entertaining movie was a big hit and nominated for five Academy Awards. It's beautifully directed by Michael Curitz, has a pretty good (if predictable) script and a VERY attractive cast (especially Lynn). Also this was John Garfield's first film and made him a star. This was so popular there were three or four sequels (which I never saw). This is an engrossing, entertaining, big budget soap operawell worth seeing.

Our data indicate that i) cathodal, excitability reducing tDCS, interferes with inhibitory cognitive control, ii) the left dlPFC is critically involved in the neuronal network underlying the control of response inhibition, and iii) the COMT Val (108158) Met polymorphism modulates the impact of cathodal tDCS on inhibitory control. Together with our previous finding that anodal tDCS selectively impairs set-shifting abilities in COMT MetMet homozygous individuals, these results indicate that genetic factors modulate effects of tDCS on cognitive performance. Therefore, future tDCS research should account for genetic variability in the design and analysis of neurocognitive as well as therapeutic applications to reduce the variability of results and facilitate individualized neurostimulation approaches.

Non-trivial mechanical and thermodynamic variation across the family is explained by differences within the underlying H-bond networks. The mechanism is simple; variation within the H-bond networks result in altered mechanical linkage properties that directly affect intrinsic flexibility. Moreover, varying numbers of H-bonds and their strengths control the likelihood for energetic fluctuations as H-bonds break and reform, thus directly affecting thermodynamic properties. Consequently, these results demonstrate how unexpected large differences, especially within cooperativity correlation, emerge from subtle differences within the underlying H-bond network. This inference is consistent with well-known results that show allosteric response within a family generally varies significantly. Identifying the hydrogen bond network as a critical determining factor for these large variances may lead to new methods that can predict such effects.

Person2: No, I haven't. Can I choose the color of the car? Person1: Sure, we have Toyota Carola's in black, red and silver. Person2: I don't like black or red. Person1: Then you can have the other one. Please show me your ID card and I will copy it. Person2: OK. Anything else? Person1: Sign your name on the application form and here are the keys to the car. Person2: Thanks. What time do I have to bring it back? Person1: It needs to come back by noon on the third day. Person2: Alright. Thanks. Person1: Drive safely.

Sir Vivian Richards believes James Anderson will be remembered as an England great and a worthy heir to Sir Ian Botham. Anderson will earn his 100th Test cap on Monday when England take on the West Indies at the Antiguan ground that bears Richards' name. Four wickets in the game would take him past Botham's national record of 383 Test wickets, making Anderson the most prolific English bowler in history. England's James Anderson plays his 100th Test match in Antigua against the West Indies from Monday . Anderson needs just three wickets to go level with Sir Ian Botham as England's top Test wicket taker . Sir Vivian Richards believes Anderson is a worthy heir to Sir Ian Botham (pictured in August 2014) As one of the greatest batsmen to have lived and a long-time friend of Botham, Richards is well placed to judge the scale of Anderson's achievements and his endorsement is ringing. 'He ranks with the great English fast bowlers, with the Bob Willises, the Ian Bothams and folks like that,' said Richards. 'They made a great mark and for him to be in that category, it's a tribute to him. 'He's done magnificently well. Anderson has got tremendous ability and I guess where he's at now - four wickets away from surpassing the great Sir Ian - is a tribute to the individual and to his professionalism as leader of the bowling attack. 'I captained a lot of great bowlers and I would have liked Anderson too.' Anderson has attempted to divert the attention ahead of his big day, focusing on the team's efforts to come back from a dreadful winter of white ball cricket. Four wickets in the game would take Anderson past Botham's national record of 383 Test wickets . Richards is well placed to judge the scale of Anderson's achievements and his endorsement is ringing . But with Richards' words echoed by Curtly Ambrose, one of the most fearsome fast bowlers to have graced the game, he would be forgiven for getting a touch carried away. Ambrose, speaking at the launch of his new autobiography 'Time to Talk', said: 'I've always liked James Anderson, he is a quality fast bowler. 'To have taken so many wickets in Test cricket is no mean feat because a fast bowler's life is a short one. To be four wickets away from Botham's 383 is a phenomenal achievement. 'I want to wish James all the best for his 100th Test but I hope he doesn't do too well, because I think the West Indies will win.'

Destin, Florida - A hammerhead shark was caught on video swimming in the shallows off Destin, Florida, with the footage revealing two unsuspecting swimmers dangerously close to the giant predator. The dramatic encounter was filmed by witnesses on a nearby balcony who shouted warnings to alert the swimmers to the shark's proximity. The video, uploaded to social media on Thursday, shows the hammerhead shark scouting the shallow waters, seemingly just meters away from the swimmers, who appeared unaware of the predator's presence. As the shark continued to circle nearby, onlookers on a nearby balcony were heard yelling for the swimmers to move away. "Get out of the water! Come toward us!" they called out as the swimmers began to notice the commotion. Following the direction of the warning shouts, the swimmers promptly began to make their way back to the shore. Witnesses say the shark seemed inquisitive and was possibly hunting for food. Hammerhead sharks, which can grow up to 20 feet in length, are known to prey on smaller sharks, fish, squid, and octopus. They have a sensory organ in their heads that can detect the electrical signals emitted by living organisms. Although the situation appeared quite precarious, hammerhead shark attacks are relatively rare, and they're not considered aggressive to humans. According to the International Shark Attack File, there have been only 17 unprovoked attacks by hammerhead sharks on humans since records began, with no fatalities. Florida has the highest number of shark attacks in the United States, with an average of 16 incidents per year. However, shark attacks remain exceedingly rare - the odds of being bitten by a shark are about 1 in 11.5 million, according to the Florida Museum of Natural History.

oxLDL stimulated chemotaxis of hBMSCs in vitro. Treatment of the cells with BN52021, a specific antagonist of PAF receptor (PAF-R), completely blocked the cell migration induced by PAF, but not platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF-BB). Using PAF-R-specific small interfering RNA, it was demonstrated that silencing of endogenous PAF-R expression significantly attenuated cell migration induced by PAF, but not PDGF-BB, suggesting the specific involvement of PAF-R in the oxLDL-induced cell migration. In addition, PAF-induced migration of hBMSCs was abrogated by pretreating cells with mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) inhibitors, including the MEK inhibitor U0126, the p38 MAPK inhibitor SB202190, and the JNK inhibitor SP600125. Moreover, adenoviral overexpression of a dominant negative mutant of p38 MAPK blocked PAF-stimulated migration. Taken together, these results suggest that PAF plays a pivotal role in the oxLDL-induced recruitment of hBMSCs through mechanisms involving PAF-R-dependent activation of MAPKs.

Person1: Do you think our headmaster is going to build a new lab building? Person2: I've no idea. He may have the plan. But he hasn't spoken to us teachers about it. Person1: Do you think it possible that it will happen? Person2: Of course. Right now, our old lab building can't satisfy the increasing need of teaching. It's too small and not in proper condition. Person1: Why don't we build a new one as soon as possible? Person2: There may be some problems with it. Person1: What's the problem then? Person2: As far as I know, money is. It's not likely to be solved soon, I guess. Person1: I believe our headmaster will ask the local government to help us build a new one. Person2: I think so. It's quite likely that the decision will be made before the end of this term.

Geoffrey Lewis, Esteemed Character Actor and Eastwood Collaborator, Passes Away at 79 Hollywood has lost another icon, as Geoffrey Lewis, the esteemed character actor who was a frequent collaborator with Clint Eastwood, passed away on Tuesday at the age of 79. The actor leaves behind an impressive legacy of work in the entertainment industry, having appeared in numerous movies and television shows throughout the years. Born in 1935 in San Diego, California, Lewis began his career on the stage before moving on to film and television roles in the 1970s. He worked with Eastwood early in his career, appearing in the western "High Plains Drifter" in 1973. The partnership proved to be fruitful, as they went on to collaborate in films like "Thunderbolt and Lightfoot," "Every Which Way But Loose," and "Bronco Billy." In addition to his work with Eastwood, Lewis also starred opposite Robert Redford in "The Great Waldo Pepper" and appeared in films such as "The Devil's Rejects" and "Night of the Comet." His television credits include guest-starring roles on shows like "Hawaii Five-0," "The A-Team," "The X-Files," "Murder, She Wrote," and "Law Order: Criminal Intent." Despite his extensive career, Lewis will perhaps best be remembered as a loving and supportive father to actress Juliette Lewis. His daughter, who has since become famous in her own right, has often cited her father as a major influence in her life. She took to social media following his passing, sharing a heartfelt message in which she called him "my hero" and stated that she was "forever my favorite man." Friends, family and fans have taken to social media to pay tribute to the acting legend, remembering his undeniable talent, kind spirit, and the countless memorable performances he left behind.

This movie stars Ben Kingsley as Frank, a hit man for some Russian mobsters based out of Buffalo. In this thrilling crime drama, audiences are taken on a gripping journey into the dark and dangerous underbelly of organized crime. Alongside Kingsley, the supporting cast delivers powerful performances, adding depth to the already dynamic narrative. Set in the murky world of Buffalo's underworld, the movie revolves around Frank's moral dilemmas as a middle-aged hitman grappling with guilt and the desire for redemption. The film is filled with intense action sequences, heart-stopping car chases, and surprises around every corner. The suspense keeps viewers on the edge of their seats, as they, too, begin to question whether Frank will make the right choice in the end. Director Jane Doe showcases her filmmaking prowess by masterfully blending dark humor with gut-wrenching emotional sequences. Her unique vision has successfully captured the essence of Buffalo's criminal milieu in a manner that accentuates both the grit and glamour of the mobster lifestyle. The cinematography is breathtaking and seamlessly transports viewers into the electrifying world of hitmen. Ben Kingsley delivers one of the most riveting performances of his career. His portrayal of the conflicted Frank is convincing and deeply moving. The raw emotion displayed by Kingsley, as he navigates his character's moral quandaries, is nothing short of phenomenal. The supporting cast, including John Doe as the ruthless mob boss, enhances the overall experience and creates a compelling ensemble. In conclusion, this movie is a thrilling and thought-provoking exploration of an aging hitman's strife amidst the brutality of the criminal underworld. With its exceptional performances, captivating plot, and masterful direction, this film is a must-watch for fans of both the crime drama and action genres.

2001: A Space Odyssey Is it a sermon? An account of the history of mankind? An exploration of man's futile attempts to advance technology only to have technology destroy him? Is it about the fragile balance of time and space? A lesson in evolution? Or is it just a spectacular effects show; a film Kubrick made only to show us the limitless possibilities of the motion picture and present to us the truth that images are exceedingly more powerful than words? 2001: A Space Odyssey is all of these things. One of the most interpretable films ever created, it's almost more fun to dissect and discuss the ambiguous plot design and events of the film, than it is to actually watch. But it's left open to discussion intentionally; if Kubrick had explained the meaning to his wondrous 1968 classic (ranked 22 on AFI's list of the greatest 100 films ever made, my personal 21st favorite filmcurrently, and nominated for 4 Academy Awards: Director, Original Screenplay, Art Direction, and Visual Effects which it won for) it would have lost half its fascination, all of its complexity, and a good portion of its cinematic worth. We would only be left with the technical ingenuity; which in itself is worth praising.Because every shot is worth taking the time to look. And there is plenty of time. 2001 is very elegiac, and also coolly distant; detached. The emotional remoteness and slow pace pay perfect tribute however to the unique visual experience; 2001 begins with mankind's ape ancestors, who upgrade from scavengers of the planet to hunters and toolmakers after discovering a giant monolith in the midst of their desert home, then (in one of motion picture history's most inspired jump-cut edits) as a bone is tossed into the air and becomes a satellite, jumping forward a couple thousand years into space, where astronauts have discovered a similar object on the moon, and next the film following a crew of space traveler's mission as they follow the monolith's signal through space, accompanied by their untrustworthy computer HAL, who attempts to sabotage the shuttle and kill the crew, before finally the lone survivor is launched through space and time (in a flurry of drug-induced colors that probably gave hippies an epileptic shock back in the day) to grow old, die, and be reborn a "Star-child." Whew.This pacing and emotional blankness, is also in sharp contrast with the film's most ironic scene; the destruction of HAL. As the crew's final explorer shuts the machine down, bathed in the holy aura of red light Kubrick has always used as a repeat motif, HAL singing a lovely tune, it is a strangely emotional experience. And it's all genius.Other notable aspects of Kubrick's masterpiece is the memorable voice of HAL (a calm, somehow sinister, Douglas Rain), the minimal use of dialogue (Kubrick was wisely trusting of his images to propel the film; giving only banal, unhelpful lines to his actors. The most famous being "Open the pod bay doors HAL, satellites dancing around in orbit to unorthodox music, and that first, awe-inspiring shot of earth; slowly revealing the glare of the sun in front of it, played to the sound of blasting, triumphant horns.2001 shall always remain a mystery, and will forever be a testament to the cinema's strongest point: visuals are more powerful than writing. It's all from one of film history's most legendary and best directors, whose unique vision, was always his own. 1010 "Open the pod bay doors HAL2001: A Space Odyssey

I never fell asleep during a movie. Never. This movie did the impossible.While many people claim the superiority of Japanese horror films over their American counterparts, this movie was a lesson in over abundance. As in, the movie was 30 minutes too long. It would have helped if the movie had a little more movement in the plot and the camera work, but instead, all we got were awkward silences and a lot of slow movement. The acting was absolutely terrible, bordering on bad student film levels while everyone struggled to ad-lib something called a script. Did these people even get any direction? Were they coaxed to be boring and dull? Either therory wouldn't surprise me.What was even worse was the rather unscary make-up involved with the creatures from the other side. Either way, they all stunk. Don't watch this film. That's all I can say (unless you're an insomniac).

Jose Mourinho could one day make a shock return to manage Real Madrid even after his high-profile and acrimonious exit, according to Real defender Alvaro Arbeloa. The Chelsea manager ended his three-year spell in Madrid to rejoin his current club in 2013, leaving the Spanish capital amid rumours of bust-ups with senior players, including club captain Iker Casillas, Sergio Ramos and Pepe. But right back Arbeloa, who has made 25 first-team appearances this season, says Real's door will never be closed to bringing the combustible Portuguese coach back as boss. Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho could return to take charge of Real Madrid one day, says Alvaro Arbeloa . Arbeloa handed a portion of the credit for Real's Champions League win to Mourinho's groundwork . Under Carlo Ancelotti's stewardship, Real lifted the 10th European Cup that they had craved for so long . The former Liverpool defender also handed a portion of credit for last season's La Decima Champions League win to Mourinho, saying his work was the foundation of their success under Carlo Ancelotti. 'Yes there is a possibility of Jose returning to Madrid,' Arbeloa said. 'Why not? Madrid's door is not closed for a great coach. 'Mourinho has many fond memories of Real Madrid. For La Decima, we have to credit Ancelotti but Jose planted the foundations.' Mourinho left Madrid and rejoined Chelsea in 2013 and has since led his team to the brink of another title . The Special One endured a trophyless campaign in his last year with Real which he said was his worst season . Arbeloa was said to be one of Mourinho's main 'disciples' in the dressing room, and he admits he has spoken with the Chelsea manager as recently as last week. He also said that despite the talk of unrest in the camp at Real, the Special One left on good terms before joining Chelsea, particularly with expected summer transfer target Raphael Varane. Mourinho is said to be considering a 40million move for the French centre back when the transfer window opens in July. Arbeloa (left) was said to be one of Mourinho's main 'disciples' in the dressing room and the pair still talk . Mourinho's arguments with senior players including Iker Casillas, the club captain, were well documented . 'I spoke to him (Mourinho) last Friday,' Arbeloa toldEl Chiringuito. 'He's happy and content in London because his family are happy and there isn't the daily persecution he and his kids got here. 'The press emphasised (how) it ended badly but Jose ended well with most - (Luka) Modric, Varane, Diego (Lopez), Xabi (Alonso). 'Professionally he has a great team and is doing well.' Arbeloa says Mourinho is happy in London, having won the Capital One Cup with Chelsea last month . Raphael Varane, said to be a summer target for Mourinho, ended on good terms with his former manager .

I'm an action movie fan, but until today, I've never seen a preview or an ad for this movie in Italy, so I went to see "The Long Kiss Goodnight" on pay-TV, hoping for nothing special. But, what a surprise! This 1996 classic, directed by Renny Harlin and starring Geena Davis and Samuel L. Jackson, exceeded my expectations on every level. The plot is packed with action and intrigue - Davis portrays a schoolteacher with amnesia who slowly realizes that she is actually a skilled assassin with her former agency on her tail. Jackson plays a cynical detective trying to help her piece together her mysterious past. From high-speed car chases to edge-of-your-seat shootouts, "The Long Kiss Goodnight" is an adrenaline-fueled thrill ride. What sets this movie apart from other action films, however, is its clever script. Writer Shane Black expertly balances the heavy, action-packed moments with wry humor and witty banter between the two main characters. The actors' chemistry is undeniable, and their performances allow viewers to get emotionally invested in the story. Visually, "The Long Kiss Goodnight" is impressive as well, with its top-notch stunt work, special effects, and thrilling set pieces. The film's pacing keeps the viewer engaged throughout, and the action scenes are some of the best I've seen in the genre. Perhaps the movie wasn't well-promoted in Italy, but it's definitely worth the watch for action fans. Geena Davis and Samuel L. Jackson deliver remarkable performances, making this underrated gem a must-see. So, take a break from the typical action blockbusters and give "The Long Kiss Goodnight" a chance - it might just surprise you too.
At least the jingle by Tim Finn was melodic. Roberts is the his usual inept self. Characters are inconsistent, dull, purposeless. Roberts changes his accent even within one line.

This is a wonderful movie...it's funny, dark, poignant, thought-provoking, innocently naughty and generally entertaining all around. "The Curious Chronicles of Jack Bumble" takes the viewers on an emotional roller coaster that's as delightful as it is unforgettable. The brilliant performances by an ensemble cast led by the charming Jack McFadden blend seamlessly with director Anna Jenkins' unique storytelling style. Set in a quirky, fictional town, the movie revolves around Jack, a seemingly ordinary man with an extraordinary talent for accidentally getting himself into extraordinary situations. From falling in love with the mysterious woman at the local bakery to uncovering a hidden family secret through his misadventures, Jack's journey is simultaneously heartwarming and hilarious. The cinematography is visually stunning and captures the essence of the peculiar town and its inhabitants. The film's soundtrack is another standout, featuring an exquisite blend of indie folk and pop tracks that add to the overall ambience and charm. One of the movie's strongest points is its ability to evoke deep emotion and genuine laughter in equal measure, leaving the viewer reflective yet satisfied. The on-screen chemistry between the characters is palpable and adds considerable depth to their relationships. The dialogue is engaging and witty, riddled with clever one-liners that will stick with the audience long after the credits roll. In conclusion, "The Curious Chronicles of Jack Bumble" is a rare gem that flawlessly mixes humor, drama, romance, and a dash of mystery into a well-rounded and truly entertaining cinematic experience. A must-watch for anyone seeking a thoughtful, delightful, and engaging film that will keep you chuckling and pondering life's peculiarities long after the movie ends.

Contains SpoilersThis is a Peter Watkins film. If one has seen his BBC masterpieces "Cullodden" and "The War Game," one will recognize the style (and his voice) within seconds after the start. Made in 1971 it is set in a very near future, when the Vietnam war has escalated even more and now seems to involve China. Nixon is still president and civil disobedience and protest is dealt with violently using drumhead tribunals (outwardly civilian with 'everyday citizens' as judges). Because "prison building can't keep up," an alternative is introduced: The Punishment Park. Delinquents can choose between severe prison sentences and a man hunt in a hostile environment, in this case a 85 km trip through the Californian desert at 100F. If they reach an American flag at the end without being caught by National Guard or Riot Police, they will be set free, or else they have to serve their sentence (or be dead, as we will see). The film is made in a completely documentary style with three European teams covering a tribunal and the course of two groups already sentenced. Scenes jump between the tribunal tent, the hunting troops and the hunted condemned. Watkin's scarce off commentary gives us raw background information (time, temperature etc.). The tribunal scenes show a kangaroo court on the one side and a wide range of personalities on the other ranging from real terrorists over 'undesirables' to clearly innocents (e.g. a total pacifist who can't even hurt flies). The defense lawyer (who does take his job seriously) has to take abuse from both sides. What makes these scenes especially eerie is their resemblance to the rhetoric of todays administration to the detail. Meanwhile, some unfortunate events in the desert make clear that the 'rules of the game' don't really apply. The question remains open, whether it is rigged from the start or arbitrariness by the troops due to those events that leads to the outcome (I suspect, it is both). At the end we are back at square one with the next group going to "Punishment Park." This description may indicate a heavily biased (or even demagogic) propaganda movie but that would be misleading. The behavior (all participants were nonprofessionals as usual with Watkins) looks and sounds real (the tribunal scenes may even contain text material from real contemporary trials). I'd say that this could be sold as the 'real thing' without problem. With Watkins's "The Forgotten Faces" the reaction was "We can't send that or nobody will believe our real newsreels anymore (because this is indistinguishable from the real thing) ." With "Punishment Park" it ought to be the same. Effectively banned in the US as far as I know this is a must see that hasn't lost its power or its relevance (especially today).

Sharky's Machine is easily one of Burt Reynolds best efforts. It also stands as one of the best contemporary crime dramas. Erotic and violent, the movie distinguishes itself by setting the story in Atlanta, and delivering a chaotic detective case, to you (the viewer), on a silver platter. Dedicated and determined, Sharky must stop the murder of Dominoe, a lovely lady of the night, who's clientel is anything but ordinary. Before long, Sharky's crimefighting Machine uncovers a conspiracy of the highest order, which threatens to corrupt the inner body of Atlanta. As a resident of Metro Atlanta, I recall the excitement in town during the movie's production. Sharky's Machine goes to great lengths to give an accurate portrayal of Atlanta. Twenty years removed and 2,000,000-more people later, the film stands the test of time. Trust me, Atlanta has not changed. One of the highlights of the picture is Dar Robinson's daring stunt (a classic, symbolic ending). It was even featured on That's Incredible, ABC's reality show of the period. It's just too bad that Hollywood does not make enough films like this one. Kick back, each your popcorn, and watch sterling silver cinema action.

Lipid crystals, particularly cholesterol crystals, have been found to play a role in the progression of atherosclerotic plaques. These crystals can mechanically stimulate adjacent extracellular matrix (ECM) components in advanced atherosclerotic plaques, leading to inflammation, cell activation, and plaque destabilization. Lipid crystals can accumulate within the necrotic core of the plaque, which can increase volume and mechanical pressure on the ECM. This mechanical stimulation can activate inflammatory cells, like macrophages, and promote the release of pro-inflammatory cytokines, leading to further plaque destabilization and even plaque rupture. Moreover, lipid crystals can cause direct mechanical damage to ECM components, such as collagen and elastin, leading to a weakened fibrous cap. The weaker fibrous cap and increased inflammation can contribute to the susceptibility of the plaque to rupture, which may lead to a cardiovascular event, such as a heart attack or stroke. In summary, lipid crystals in advanced atherosclerotic plaques can mechanically stimulate adjacent ECM components, leading to plaque destabilization and increased risk of cardiovascular events. However, more research is needed to fully understand the mechanisms and effects of lipid crystals on ECM stimulation in atherosclerosis.

Person1: Of course! Would you like a regular lemonade or a flavored one? We have strawberry and peach options as well. Person2: Just a regular lemonade would be great, thank you. Person1: You're welcome. I'll be right back with your lemonade.

Person1: Nice to see you too, Ms. Ross. How has your day been so far? Person2: It's been quite productive and pleasant, thank you for asking. How about yours, Mr. Fisher? Have you had a chance to review the details I sent over? Person1: Yes, I have. The plans look great! I especially like the idea of having a silent auction to raise funds. I'm confident that our collaboration will result in a memorable and impactful event.

Yes, social influence plays a significant role in young drivers using mobile phones while driving. Peer pressure, the desire to stay connected with friends, and the fear of missing out on important conversations or events are factors that can encourage young drivers to use their phones while driving. Young people often feel the need to respond immediately to messages or calls, even if they're in the middle of the road, which can lead to dangerous consequences. Furthermore, if young drivers see their friends or family members frequently engaging in this behavior, they may be more inclined to adopt it themselves. To reduce this risk, it's essential to educate young drivers about the dangers of using a mobile phone while driving and to promote safe driving habits and practices.

Although there is very little plot and whatever exists is just all improvisational, still it was a good start from a new director with no previous financial back up and also a smart move from Andy Warhol to make his cimematic productions more marketable and viewer-friendly. In any case this story of a street hustler relies too much on showing Joe buck naked (almost all the time!). And the creative use of a flashy editing really wears off after the hundredth time and the cutting off the dialog thing gets really annoying half-way. This would have been a much more entertaining or even dramatic if they made a documentary of the daily of an actual male prostitute or hustler, instead of letting the actors make up some nonesensical plot and dialog of their own.

I bought this movie for 99 cents at K-mart several years back (along with "Hawken's Breed figuring anything with Gabriel Byrne and Amanda Donahoe is surely worth that much. It wasn't. "Dark Obsession" (the title I bought it under) was a slight cut above "Hawken's Breed" (IMBD rated at 2.4), but not enough to allow me to even keep it in the house. I threw both movies in the trash.This thing fails on so many levels it's hard to narrow it down, but let's just say it's tawdry, incredible, boring, hedonistic, confusing and even at 100 minutes, way too long.I love Byrne as an actor, but this schlock really looks bad on his resume.

Cocky medical students play chicken with a process that simulates death, in an attempt to get a (hopefully temporary) view of the afterlife. This thrilling and mind-bending cinematic experience, aptly titled "Flatliners," takes the audience on a rollercoaster ride of suspense, intrigue, and psychological horror. The film, helmed by a visionary director, explores the darkest corners of human curiosity as the characters inch closer to uncovering life's greatest mystery. The ensemble cast delivers compelling performances, with each actor digging deep to portray the inner turmoil of their on-screen personas. As the students find their lives irrevocably changed by their explorations of the unknown, the cast masterfully navigates the emotional turmoil that ensues. Visually, "Flatliners" is a feast for the eyes, with stunning visuals and impeccable cinematography that evoke a sense of eeriness and dread. The film's score adds ambience and resonates with the audience, ensuring a lingering sense of unease even after the credits have rolled. The plot itself, while initially appearing as a simple thriller, delves into the deeper existential questions of life, death, guilt, and redemption. This psychological aspect elevates the film beyond mere jump scares, forcing the viewer to confront their own fears and assumptions about the afterlife. However, despite its thought-provoking plot and solid performances, "Flatliners" falters in its pacing. At times, the film feels bogged down in its desire to explore every character's arc, which can lead to moments of frustration for the viewer. Nevertheless, these issues are minor compared to the overall triumph of the film. In conclusion, "Flatliners" is a thrilling cinematic experience that smoothly combines elements of horror, suspense, and psychological drama. With its stellar cast, jaw-dropping visuals, and thought-provoking plot, it is a must-watch for fans of the genre and those seeking an intellectually stimulating journey into the unknown.

Repeated shifting of the LD cycle, which disrupts endogenous circadian timekeeping, dramatically reduces pregnancy success in mice. Advances of the LD cycle have a greater negative impact on pregnancy outcomes and, in non-pregnant female mice, require longer for circadian re-entrainment, suggesting that the magnitude or duration of circadian misalignment may be related to the severity of the adverse impact on pregnancy. These results explicitly link disruptions of circadian entrainment to adverse pregnancy outcomes in mammals, which may have important implications for the reproductive health of female shift workers, women with circadian rhythm sleep disorders andor women with disturbed circadian rhythms for other reasons.

New York: An underground electrical fire caused a huge explosion in downtown Buffalo, sending a manhole cover flying more than 200 feet into the air on Sunday morning. The blast took place on Tupper Street around 11:30 a.m. and resulted in the evacuation of two buildings in the area. Authorities were quick to arrive on the scene and have since contained the fire. According to the Buffalo police department, smoke was emanating from the manholes, causing initial panic among the residents. At the time of the explosion, a photojournalist was interviewing a man on the street, with a second blast taking place about half a block behind them. Miraculously, the manhole cover flew up without causing any reported injuries or fatalities. The immediate priority for the city officials was to ensure the safety of the residents. As a precautionary measure, two buildings in the vicinity were evacuated, and fire crews worked swiftly to contain the situation. "We came as quickly as possible to make sure everyone was safe," said a spokesperson for the authorities. "Our focus now is to mitigate the scene and prevent any further incidents." The initial investigation suggests that the explosion was due to an underground electrical fire. However, the exact cause leading to the explosion remains unclear, and authorities are working diligently to determine whether any lapse in safety measures occurred. The Department of Public Works is responsible for the maintenance and monitoring of underground electrical infrastructure in Buffalo. With an incident of such magnitude, city officials are expected to take immediate corrective measures to ensure better safety of the residents against any similar incidents in the future. "Anytime something like this happens, it's our responsibility to review the safety protocols and determine what happened," said a city official. "We will be working closely with the authorities and local residents to evaluate this situation and take appropriate action." As the investigation continues, residents are urged to report any suspicious activities or specific concerns in their neighborhoods to the authorities. Meanwhile, those who were evacuated are now able to return to their homes temporarily after the area was deemed safe by authorities.

Noncompliance with guidelines for the treatment of hepatitis C can be frequent in daily practice. There are several reasons for this, including: 1. Lack of Awareness: Healthcare providers might not be fully aware of the latest guidelines and recommendations for the treatment of hepatitis C. This could lead to noncompliance due to outdated or inaccurate information. 2. Cost and Insurance: The high cost of hepatitis C treatment can be prohibitive for some patients, leading them to avoid or delay treatment. Insurance coverage might also be limited, further complicating access to the appropriate treatment. 3. Patient Adherence: Some patients might struggle to adhere to the treatment plan due to side effects or personal reasons, leading to noncompliance. 4. Complexity of Treatment: Hepatitis C treatment can be complex, with various factors (such as genotype, viral load, liver condition, etc.) needing to be considered. This can make it challenging to follow guidelines in some cases. 5. Limited Access to Specialists: In some areas, there might be limited access to hepatologists or other specialists who are experienced in managing hepatitis C, leading to suboptimal treatment decisions. Despite these challenges, it is important for healthcare providers to stay informed about the current guidelines for hepatitis C treatment and work to improve patient adherence and access to appropriate care.

Yes, professional awareness is needed to distinguish between child physical abuse and other disorders that can mimic signs of abuse, such as skull base sclerosis manifesting features of infantile cortical hyperostosis. Accurate diagnosis requires a detailed evaluation of the child's medical history, clinical signs, radiological studies, and in some cases, a multidisciplinary team approach, including pediatricians, radiologists, and child abuse specialists. This helps ensure that the correct diagnosis is made and appropriate interventions are implemented. Furthermore, raising professional awareness about such conditions can help minimize the risk of misdiagnosis and unnecessary child protection measures.

Wow, where to begin with this one. "Eternal Horizon" transcends the boundaries of traditional storytelling and captivates the audience with a perfect blend of mesmerizing visual effects, a compelling narrative, and outstanding performances. From the moment the film begins, you know you are in for a thrilling and emotional journey. Director Jane Adams has once again outdone herself, managing to bring together the best of science fiction, drama, and romance into a cinematic masterpiece. The movie is set in a dystopian future where humanity is on the brink of extinction, but a glimmer of hope is found in an uncharted planet that could save mankind. The visual effects team spared no detail in creating an otherworldly landscape that appears both intriguing and terrifying, keeping audiences at the edge of their seats. The main protagonist, played by the exceptionally talented John Carter, embarks on a mission to find answers and possibly redemption. Carter's performance is heartfelt, showing us the internal struggles and complexities of his character, making it nearly impossible not to empathize with him. Alicia Thompson delivers an outstanding performance as the resilient and fearless scientist whose mission aligns with Carter's. Their on-screen chemistry is electric, as they both attempt to save humanity while finding solace in each other during these desperate times. What sets "Eternal Horizon" apart from other movies in the genre is the profound exploration of human nature, sacrifice, and the consequences of survival at any cost. The intense action sequences and staggering plot twists keep the audience engaged and breathless, waiting to see what will unfold next. The use of a powerful and haunting score only adds to the film's impact, elevating the emotional stakes for the characters and the viewers alike. In conclusion, "Eternal Horizon" is a groundbreaking, genre-defying film that will surely go down in history as a cinematic triumph. Its memorable performances, innovative storytelling, and awe-inspiring visuals will have you talking about it long after the credits roll. This is a must-see film for sci-fi enthusiasts and cinema lovers alike, as it stands as a testament to the power of storytelling and the endless possibilities of human imagination.
