To study this immunoregulatory effect more directly, we induced acute GVH reactions in which we treated the donors rather than the recipients with palifermin. The recipient mice were protected from GVHD-associated morbidity, and their cytokine profile was predominantly Th2. The palifermin-treated donor mice alone showed a similar Th2 cytokine profile, and we observed elevated levels of thymic stromal lymphopoietin mRNA in the thymus. We further demonstrated that treating the donor mice with palifermin protects against GVHD-associated morbidity, even if the donors are deficient in Valpha14i natural killer T cells. Our findings clearly show that palifermin mediates immunoregulatory effects in addition to its cytoprotective effects and that both are likely to be involved in the mechanism through which palifermin provides protection from acute murine GVHD.

AR (in vivo) does not reflect cast geometry, probably because of (1) underestimation by AR because of methodological problems caused by the cavity geometry, (2) deformation of compliant structures within the nasal passageways resulting from the casting procedure, andor (3) the casting material reaches parts of the nasal cavity not accessible to sound, e.g., sinuses or recesses. Nevertheless, this study does not preclude the use of AR as a sensitive method suited to evaluate relative changes in nasal volume caused by experimental challenges of the nasal mucosa. Compared with AR (in vivo), casts still may be of use but it is less sensitive to measure relative changes after experimental challenge.

Cambridge University considers introducing entrance exams for applicants Cambridge University, one of the world's top institutions, is considering introducing entrance exams to help select the best and brightest applicants. The prestigious university explains that changes in A-level examination criteria have made it difficult to choose the most qualified and deserving pupils. These proposed entrance exams, which are expected to be introduced next year, will enable the university to streamline the selection process for undergraduate applicants. In recent years, A-level results have shown a downward trend in top grades, with fewer than 9 of pupils achieving the highest results this year, compared to 9.3 in the previous year. Furthermore, the structure of A-level exams is being altered, with coursework and assessment components being reintroduced after a shift towards traditional exams. Cambridge University is not alone in facing the challenge of assessing the aptitude of candidates for its competitive courses. Many universities, particularly those who are part of the Russell Group, have commented on the increasing difficulty of distinguishing between students with similar exam results. Given the recent changes to exam structure and the lack of consistency in A-Level subject choice within secondary education, selecting the best suited applicants has become a challenge for top educational institutions. The reintroduction of entrance exams would be one solution to this problem. It is important to note that Cambridge University used to require applicants to sit an entrance exam regardless of their subject choice but phased these tests out in the 1980s. This practice was, however, retained for international students and is still component of the admissions process for these applicants. These new Cambridge entrance exams are being developed by Cambridge Assessment, one of the UK's leading exam boards. Each subject area will have its own entrance test according to the demands of the course. The exams will consist of written papers, essays, problem-solving exercises, and multiple choice questions. Those who pass the entrance exams will then be invited for an interview before being offered a place at the prestigious university.

Yesterday, in Council Bluffs, Iowa, Hillary Clinton's signature black customized van, nicknamed "Scooby," was parked in a spot reserved for the disabled just outside a cafe. Clinton met with Democratic Party insiders inside the cafe for 90 minutes, where the former US president and first lady reportedly discussed sensitive matters. The meeting was so important, the insiders were asked to hand over their cameras and cell phones. The van completed Iowa's famous "River to River Road" in 2014, with Bill Clinton behind the wheel. The Clinton Foundation spent USD 10,000 to outfit the van for a three-day trip that included stops in Des Moines, Elkhart, and Indianola. The foundation's investment allowed her to park it on a nice blue handicap sign at the cafe. Although Clinton walked right past an unmistakable blue parking sign to climb into the van, as the Secret Service are technically federal law-enforcement officers and the vehicle is never left unattended, there was no chance of her receiving a parking ticket.

A zoo in Ohio is celebrating the 'miracle' birth of three rare Amur tiger cubs after it was feared their mother's biological clock had stopped ticking. Keepers at the Columbus Zoo say ten-year-old Irisa had mated before but never conceived. However, this spring it was found the female cat was pregnant - with triplets. While the birth on Tuesday morning went smoothly, Irisa failed to show any maternal care so her offspring are currently being hand-reared in an incubator. Scroll down for video . Open wide: A zoo in Ohio is celebrating the 'miracle' birth of three rare Amur tiger cubs after it was feared their mother's biological clock had stopped ticking . Bundle of joy: Keepers at the Columbus Zoo say ten-year-old Irisa had bred before but never conceived - however, this spring it was found the female cat was pregnant - with triplets . 'We are always cautiously optimistic about the survival of fragile newborns,' said Columbus Zoo president Tom Stalf. 'But the cubs seem to be thriving under the 24-hour care provided by our animal specialists and veterinarians.' Video footage shows the newborn siblings writhing around and napping. The baby cats currently weigh a healthy 2.5lbs but they're set to grow to a heftier 650lbs. Their eyes are also closed but should open over the coming days. In safe hands: While the birth on Tuesday morning went smoothly, Irisa failed to show any maternal care so her offspring are currently being hand-reared in an incubator . Taking it easy: Video footage shows the newborn siblings writhing around and napping . It is unknown when they will go on display to the public and how keepers will go about naming them. These are the first cubs for ten-year-old female, Irisa, although the Zoo team and the Tiger Species Survival Plan (SSP) had hoped for years she would reproduce and pass on her valuable genes. This is the third litter sired by 11-year-old, Foli, since 2012. Gestation for tigers is about three-and-a-half months which means the cubs were conceived just weeks before Foli left for another facility in Kansas on February 25. He has been retired from breeding. Tiny tots: They currently weigh 2.5lbs but are set to grow to a heftier 650lbs . Growing pains: Their eyes are also closed but should open over the coming days . Bright futures: It is unknown when they will go on display and how keepers will go about naming them . A new male tiger, Jupiter, arrived at the Columbus Zoo on March 19. Jupiter was born at the Moscow Zoo in 2007 and came to the Columbus Zoo from the Dvur Kralove Zoo in the Czech Republic. Both males were moved at the recommendation of the Species Survival Plan in an effort to maintain a sustainable population of tigers in human care. With the addition of the three cubs there are currently ten Amur tigers at the Columbus Zoo including four cubs born in 2013 and their mother, Mara.

Christine Carriage, 67, (pictured) was handed a six-month suspended sentence at Norwich Crown Court . A grandmother hoarded 1,300 items of stolen clothing in her tiny bungalow - which police said was like a 'warehouse'. Officers raiding Christine Carriage's one-bedroom home found that 340 of the stolen items still had price tags on. But this week the 67-year-old walked free from court. A total of 1,337 items of clothing, shoes and handbags - valued at 5,620 - were seized by police from the home in Bowthorpe, Norwich, on November 4, 2013. William Carter, prosecuting, said police found an 8ft-long clothes rail bending under the huge weight of the clothing in one room. He said: 'The officers described the property as looking more like a clothing warehouse than a dwelling. Each room was packed.' On Wednesday, Carriage admitted acquiring, using or possessing criminal property. When police searched the house, she was at the property with son Shane Carriage, 45, and grandson Luke Hall. Officers found cash, drug paraphernalia and at least an eighth of a kilo of cocaine. Carriage had convictions for dishonesty from the 1960s and 1970s, and two convictions for shoplifting in the 1980s, as well as one in 1996 and another in 2012. Philippa Page, defending, said some items were Carriage's clothes and those of her son, grandson and late husband. She said Carriage was guilty of mistaken family loyalty in allowing her 'increasingly out-of-control' grandson to store stolen clothes at her home. Sentencing Carriage, Judge Maureen Bacon told her: 'You have been a dishonest woman through all your life. 'I don't see why I should inflict your keep on the public purse by sending you to prison today.' She was given a suspended six-month jail sentence, ordered to do 120 hours of unpaid work and told to pay an 80 victim surcharge at Norwich Crown Court. But Carriage and her son were cleared of supplying cocaine last August after Recorder Peter Wallis ruled there was no case to answer. Hall had previously admitted supplying cocaine, possessing cocaine and possessing criminal property and was jailed for 34 months. A grandmother's swag: Hundreds of stolen items from shoes to handbags were discovered by police in a raid on the one-bedroom home of serial offender Christine Carriage in November 2013 . Police raided the one-bedroom bungalow in Bowthorpe, Norwich (pictured) where Christine Carriage lived. She was at the property at the time along with her son Shane Carriage, 45, and grandson Luke Hall . Seized: Police found an eight foot long clothes rail bending under the weight of the clothing in one room .

L'Auberge Espagnole is less funny and less interesting than any episode of Dobie Gillis. Where is their Bob Denver? Do they even have a Dwayne Hickman? A French man moves to Barcelona to attend classes. He moves in with some other students who are no more interesting than himself, and they do and say uninteresting things. This movie is unbelievably bland. The only bright spot was a pretty French girl who played a Belgian lesbian. She places her hands behind her head and reveals shaven underarms, not the usual tufts of dark, smelly hair. But bare armpits does not a good movie make. L'Emmerdeur was funny, so was La Cage aux Folles. L'Auberge Espagnole and Le Placard makes you wonder what is going wrong with French comedy.

In 1968 when, "SYMBIOPSYCHOTAXIPLASM: Take One," was released, it came from out of nowhere, and struck like a psychedelic thunderbolt. Director William Greaves dared to create a film that challenged social norms and conventional filmmaking, by blurring the lines between fiction and reality while delving into the inner workings of the human psyche. The premise of the film is simple yet wildly inventive - a documentary crew films a director while he tries to shoot a narrative film that is ultimately scrapped, creating a meta-film within a film. As the cameras roll, the cast and crew are forced to confront their own creative and personal struggles, ranging from relationship troubles to doubts about their roles in the production. This chaos and confusion gives birth to a strangely compelling and hypnotic experience. The loosely improvised performances of the actors add a certain charm to the film. They deliver rawness and vulnerability, which constantly keeps the viewer on their toes, questioning if they are stepping into the realm of unscripted reality or simply remaining within a tightly structured artistic vision. As a result, "SYMBIOPSYCHOTAXIPLASM: Take One" takes on a life of its own, transcending the boundaries of conventional cinema and evolving into an immersive and cathartic experience. The cinematography is equally impressive and groundbreaking, capturing the beautiful chaos and disorder of a tumultuous production both in and out of the frames. The multiple cameras used by Greaves break the walls of what would be deemed as "acceptable" in traditional filmmaking. The film's hallucinatory visuals and disorienting cuts add to the overall trippy and surreal experience. One cannot discuss "SYMBIOPSYCHOTAXIPLASM: Take One" without addressing the film's daring attempt to capture deeper philosophical questions about the nature of truth, art, and humanity. By allowing the characters to ponder about their own existence and purpose, the film forces the viewer to confront their own reality and perhaps even question the very nature of cinema itself. In conclusion, "SYMBIOPSYCHOTAXIPLASM: Take One" remains a fascinating and captivating cinematic masterpiece, a true attack on the senses and a testament to the boundless potential of the medium. It is a shining example of experimental filmmaking that challenges both form and content, and stands tall as a timeless work of art. If you're looking for a thought-provoking and otherworldly experience, this gem from 1968 is certainly worth a watch.

Thrombomodulin-dependent protein C activation has been shown to play a role in various processes in the central nervous system, including maintaining the blood-brain barrier, reducing inflammation, and promoting neuroprotection. However, the direct involvement of thrombomodulin-dependent protein C activation in mitochondrial function and myelination has not been extensively studied or clearly established. Some research has suggested that activated protein C (APC) may help promote oligodendrocyte differentiation and myelination. Oligodendrocytes are the cells responsible for myelinating axons in the central nervous system. Additionally, APC has been shown to have anti-apoptotic effects in various cell types, which might indirectly support mitochondrial function and overall cell health. However, more research is needed to determine the specific roles and mechanistic pathways through which thrombomodulin-dependent protein C activation may affect mitochondrial function and myelination in the central nervous system.

When John Carpenter's masterly version of "The Thing" was released in summer 1982, it was panned by critics and bombed at the box office. However, as the years have passed, this sci-fi horror thriller has achieved cult status and is now considered a groundbreaking classic in both its genre and filmmaking as a whole. Set in Antarctica, "The Thing" tells the story of a group of researchers who encounter a mysterious and deadly creature that assimilates and replicates other organisms. Kurt Russell delivers a standout performance as helicopter pilot R.J. MacReady, the somewhat reluctant yet determined leader of the group as they fight to survive against an extraterrestrial enemy that could be any one of them. The special effects in "The Thing" are truly a sight to behold, with Rob Bottin's practical creature designs both grotesque and mesmerizing. The innovative use of animatronics and puppetry creates a surreal, tangible horror, which many argue has yet to be replicated despite advances in CGI. Carpenter's direction is nothing short of masterful, ratcheting up the tension as the film progresses, intensifying the feeling of paranoia and mistrust among the characters. This is further complemented by the haunting, minimalist score by Ennio Morricone, which adds a depth of unease and terror to the movie. "The Thing" is also notable for its themes of isolation and the question of what it truly means to be human, all wrapped up in a gut-wrenching, suspenseful narrative that is both timeless and unforgettable. The film brilliantly balances the horrors of its monsters with the complexities of human relationships, making the viewer question who, or what, is the true enemy. In conclusion, "The Thing" is not only a classic sci-fi horror film, but is also a shining example of outstanding filmmaking. While it may not have initially been well-received by critics or financially successful upon its release, time has shown that it is indeed a groundbreaking and influential piece of cinema. With exceptional direction, an iconic story, and captivating visual effects, John Carpenter's "The Thing" deserves all the adoration it has since garnered, and it remains a compelling and visceral experience to this day.

This is a witty and delightful adaptation of the Dr Seuss book, brilliantly animated by UPA's finest and thoroughly deserving of its Academy Award. Special mention should be made of the superb music score and sound effects, which are an integral element in helping to make this such a memorable and enjoyable cartoon. Later episodes in the series (of which there were four in total) were not actually based on original Dr Seuss material, although all but the last continued to use his familiar rhyming style. The three sequels were: Gerald McBoing Boing's Symphony (1953); How Now Boing Boing (1954); Gerald McBoing Boing On Planet Moo (1956) - although he also appeared in a later episode of Mr Magoo.

Blackpool, UK - Controversial striker Nile Ranger has been absent without leave (AWOL) from Blackpool Football Club since early December. Fans and club management alike are growing increasingly concerned about the mysterious disappearance of the former Newcastle forward who last played for the Seasiders at the end of November. It's not the first time that Ranger has been involved in off-field issues. In 2013, he was arrested for assault and later in 2014, he faced a rape charge which was eventually dropped. The 28-year-old forward's contract with the League One team is set to expire at the end of this season, adding to the club's growing list of impending departures. Ranger, who originated from London, began his football career with Southampton before moving on to play for the likes of Newcastle United, Barnsley, and Swindon Town. After several loan spells, he joined Blackpool in 2017 and made a promising start, scoring his first goal for the club in a 3-1 win over Charlton Athletic. However, his career at Blackpool took a turn for the worse when he found himself on the wrong side of the club's management. Ranger accused Blackpool officials of mocking him and undermining his efforts to contribute to the team's performance on the field. Despite the player's claims, Blackpool has made it clear that they've always been supportive of Ranger. Club officials have been quoted as saying, "We gave Nile and his two representatives full access to our club's facilities and have worked closely with him to rehabilitate his troubled past." While there are no indications of Ranger's potential next move, his actions have left Blackpool in a difficult position. With upcoming crucial matches in the coming months, the team must now find a way to make up for the missing leadership and firepower of their AWOL forward. As Nile Ranger's departure from Blackpool seems imminent with the expiration of his contract, fans and authorities are left to wonder what could have been, had he been able to overcome the obstacles that have plagued his intriguing football career.

L'Auberge Espagnole is less funny and less interesting than any episode of Dobie Gillis, which is saying something, as the latter show aired six decades ago. While this French-Spanish co-production set in a lively European panorama and boasting a talented ensemble cast promises much, it ultimately falls short due to weak plot and characters whose emotional struggles don't quite resonate. The basic premise - a group of international students sharing an apartment in Barcelona - provides ample scope for a range of amusing escapades and cross-cultural camaraderie. However, it doesn't quite fulfill its potential. Xenophobic stereotypes are abundant and stale, and the comedic timing misses its mark, leaving viewers waiting for the punchline. Romain Duris shows promise in the lead role, but the lackluster script limits his ability to develop any depth to his character. He is surrounded by a diverse array of housemates, but unfortunately, they fare little better, with most existing only to perpetuate drawn-out, contrived storylines. The film's saving grace lies in capturing the beauty of Barcelona - from picture-perfect Gaudi architectural wonders to the vivid nightlife scene. The city's energy and vibrancy leap out from the screen, providing a stunning visual backdrop that outshines the narrative itself. In short, L'Auberge Espagnole had the potential to be a hilarious and insightful exploration of life as an Erasmus student facing culture shock, identity crises, and complex relationships. Instead, it disappoints with a combination of predictable gags, flat characters, and squandered opportunities. If only it possessed the charm and wit of Dobie Gillis, this film could have left a more agreeable and lasting impression.

STAR RATING: Saturday Night Friday Night Friday Morning Sunday Night Monday Morning Title: Treading Thin Blue Lines In "Treading Thin Blue Lines," unorthodox journalist Mike Sullivan (Vinnie Jones) flits away his time winding up the local constabulary and trying to romance a member of police personnel. This charming and comedic romp through a small town's police force delivers both thrilling action and tender moments. Vinnie Jones brings a charismatic, rough-around-the-edges charm to the role, making Sullivan's exploits all the more enjoyable. His entanglements with the local cops provide ample laugh-out-loud moments, and the stunt work brings an element of excitement to the proceedings. The romantic subplot between Sullivan and the police officer, played with equal parts sass and vulnerability by Hayley Atwell, helps to humanize both characters and provides a heartwarming anchor for the film. Their chemistry is magnetic and adds depth to the story. The supporting cast of oddball police officers is a consistent source of humor and surprises, with standout performances by Stanley Tucci and Rebel Wilson. Meanwhile, some well-timed cameos and references to similar movies elevate "Treading Thin Blue Lines" above the typical cop comedy fare. The result is a film that feels fresh yet familiar, and always entertaining. Although the climax may be a bit predictable, the journey getting there is filled with such fun twists and turns that it hardly matters. Overall, "Treading Thin Blue Lines" is perfect for a Friday night movie that delivers laughs, thrills, and a touch of romance.

An in vivo reporter of BMP signaling in organogenesis can potentially reveal targets in the developing kidney. Bone morphogenetic proteins (BMPs) are important regulators of organ development, including kidney organogenesis. By using an in vivo reporter system, researchers can monitor and visualize the localization and timing of BMP signaling during kidney development. This may help in identifying specific cells and structures that are targeted by BMP signaling, which in turn can contribute to the understanding of the molecular mechanisms underlying kidney development and the ways in which BMP signaling regulates this process. However, it is important to note that the results will depend on the specific reporter system used and the experimental design, as well as the developmental stage of the kidney being studied. Overall, though, an in vivo reporter of BMP signaling can potentially provide valuable insights into the role of BMP signaling in kidney organogenesis and reveal target structures within the developing kidney.

Wigan Athletic faces a nerve-wracking match against Brighton at home this weekend, knowing that a failure to secure a win will see them relegated to League One. Meanwhile, Bristol City is on course to win the League One title with a victory against Coventry City. The stakes are high in football circles this weekend as clubs across the country prepare to fight for promotion or battle to avoid relegation. Among those with everything to play for is Wigan, who currently sits precariously in the relegation zone, with only goal difference separating them from safety. A win against Brighton could stave off relegation, at least for a while, but Wigan will need to pull out all the stops in their remaining fixtures to secure their Championship survival. However, nothing less than three points will do, with a draw or a loss confirming their relegation to League One. On the other hand, Bristol City has been enjoying a spectacular season and currently sits atop League One, with a healthy lead over second-place Preston North End. A win against Coventry City this weekend will be enough to guarantee their promotion as League One champions. However, the race for promotion is still wide open, with several clubs within striking distance. Should Bristol City fail to secure all three points this weekend, it could open the door for the likes of Preston North End, Swindon Town, and Milton Keynes Dons to make a late push for the title. All eyes will be on these crucial fixtures this weekend, as the season reaches its climax. Fans and players alike will undoubtedly be on the edge of their seats, as the dreams of promotion are fulfilled for some and the nightmares of relegation become a reality for others. It promises to be a dramatic, nail-biting, and exciting weekend ahead in football.

Headline: Dame Maggie Smith's Character Rumored to Appear in Julian Fellowes' Upcoming American Period Drama "The Gilded Age" New York, [Date] - Fans of Downton Abbey may be excited to learn that Dame Maggie Smith's beloved character from the British period drama may be making her way across the Atlantic to the United States in the form of a guest appearance on the upcoming American period drama, "The Gilded Age," by creator Julian Fellowes. Set in New York during the late 19th century, "The Gilded Age" will tell the story of the immensely wealthy and the social climbers who flocked to the city in the pursuit of the American dream. With a similar vein as Downton Abbey, the show will focus on the lives of both the elite and their less privileged counterparts, whose relationships with one another create a complex tapestry of American history and society. As both Downton Abbey and The Gilded Age are conceived and penned by writer and creator Julian Fellowes, fans are cautiously optimistic about the potential inclusion of Dame Maggie Smith's character, the indomitable Dowager Countess Violet Crawley. Smith's performance on Downton Abbey captivated audiences and critics alike, earning her numerous accolades and awards throughout the show's six-season run. In addition to the possible appearance of the Dowager Countess, there may also be a plot for American-born Cora Crawley, Countess of Grantham, played by Elizabeth McGovern, allowing for more connections between the worlds of Downton Abbey and The Gilded Age. Fans have long speculated about the possibility of an American based Downton spin-off, and the inclusion of these characters in Fellowes' newest project would open the door to even more possibilities. The Gilded Age is set to premiere on [airdate] and will feature an all-star cast including Christine Baranski, Cynthia Nixon, and Amanda Peet. With the potential appearances of these iconic characters from Fellowes' previous work, the stage is set for a new period drama to captivate both American and international audiences alike. While it remains to be seen if and how the characters from Downton Abbey will blend into the world of The Gilded Age, the anticipation for this new period drama continues to grow as fans eagerly await its premiere. The intersection between these fascinating worlds will undoubtedly spark conversations and debates about the show's direction, the social nuances of the time, and the intricate connections between our shared historical pasts.

Pep Guardiola was in no mood to celebrate as Bayern Munich secured their place in the semi-final of the German Cup with a 5-3 penalty shoot-out victory over Bayer Leverkusen on Wednesday. The Munich boss instead admitted his concern at the scoring touch which appears to have deserted his side in recent games, with the German champions only finding the net once in their last three matches. Guardiola believes the team is shackled by the absence of Franck Ribery and Arjen Robben. Bayern Munich manager Pep Guardiola is concerned about his team without Arjen Robben and Franck Ribery . Ribery (left) is absent with an ankle injury while Robben is out until May with a stomach muscle tear . 'Without Arjen Robben and Franck Ribery, we are a different team,' Guardiola said after the game. 'Of course we have big problems because we have no players for the one-on-one situations. We have other players and have to adapt the game for them.' Robben was ruled out for around two months with a stomach muscle tear at the end of March. Ribery has an uncertain timescale on his recovery from an ankle injury but is doubtful for the first leg of Munich's Champions League quarter-final tie against Porto. Munich's players celebrate after progressing to the semi-final of the German Cup . Thiago scored the winning penalty for Munich against Bayer Leverkusen as the shoot-out was won 5-3 . Guardiola will hope he can inspire his players to overcome the problem when they host Eintracht Frankfurt on Saturday in the Bundesliga, looking to maintain their 10-point advantage over Wolfsburg. The one goal Munich did score over their last three encounters came from Robert Lewandowski in the 1-0 win against his former club Borussia Dortmund and the two sides will meet again in the semi-final.

Yes, elevated activation of ERK1 and ERK2 is associated with enhanced liver injury following an alcohol binge in chronically ethanol-fed rats. Studies have shown that binge alcohol consumption in rats that are chronically fed ethanol leads to increased activation of ERK12 (extracellular signal-regulated kinases 1 and 2). This increased activation is linked to heightened inflammation and liver injury, which may contribute to the development of alcoholic liver disease.

Based on the ability of an amino-terminal fragment of the beta1 subunit to inhibit activity of an heterodimer consisting only of the catalytic domains (alphacatbetacat), Winger and Marletta (Biochemistry 2005, 44:4083-90) have proposed a direct interaction of the amino-terminal region of beta1 with the catalytic domains. In support of such a concept of "trans" regulation of sGC activity by the H-NOX domains our results indicate that the domains within sGC are organized in a way that allows for direct interaction of the amino-terminal regulatory domains with the carboxy-terminal catalytic region. In addition, we constructed "fluorescent-conjoined" sGC's by fusion of the alpha amino-terminus to the beta1 carboxy-terminus leading to a monomeric, fluorescent and functional enzyme complex. To our knowledge this represents the first example where a fluorescent protein links two different subunits of a higher ordered complex to yield a stoichometrically fixed functionally active monomer.

Yes, vacuum frying is a modern frying technique that has gained popularity as a method to produce novel snacks with desired quality attributes according to new health trends. Vacuum frying involves frying food products at a reduced pressure and lower temperature than conventional frying, which helps in preserving the natural color, flavor, and nutrients of the food. This frying technique reduces the oil absorption by the food products, thus yielding healthier snacks with lower fat content. Additionally, vacuum frying can minimize the formation of harmful compounds, such as acrylamide, that may form during high-temperature frying processes. Therefore, vacuum frying aligns with the growing demand for healthier, tastier, and more nutritious snack options.

Fluorescent fusion proteins of soluble guanylyl cyclase (sGC) have been used to study the structure and dynamics of the enzyme, which is a key receptor for nitric oxide (NO) and plays a central role in NO signaling. sGC is composed of two subunits, each of which possesses a heme nitric oxide sensing domain (H-NOX) and a catalytic domain. The use of fluorescent fusion proteins allows researchers to monitor conformational changes in sGC upon binding of NO to the H-NOX domain. Studies with these fusion proteins have revealed that the proximity of the H-NOX domain and the catalytic domain changes upon NO binding. These conformational changes are believed to play a role in how sGC is activated and catalyzes the conversion of GTP to cGMP. So, fluorescent fusion proteins of soluble guanylyl cyclase can provide information about the spatial relationship between the heme nitric oxide domain and the catalytic domain, and how they change upon NO binding, which may help us understand the underlying mechanisms of sGC activation in response to nitric oxide signaling.

"Game of Thrones" Hit by Devastating Leak In a shocking turn of events, fans worldwide found the next four "Game of Thrones" episodes released on Saturday night, four weeks ahead of schedule, on several piracy websites. The hugely popular HBO series has long been known as one of the most pirated shows in the world. However, what makes this leak particularly devastating is that it is believed to have originated from press review copies. HBO released a statement expressing their awareness of the unauthorized leak and their intent to take the matter seriously. "Sadly, it seems the leaked four episodes of the upcoming season of 'Game of Thrones' originated from within a group approved by HBO. We take this breach very seriously and have already initiated forensic investigations at our end to quickly determine the cause. This is a damaging and distressing breach for our network and for the show." According to anti-piracy analysts, Brazil stands out as the worst offender in terms of pirating content from "Game of Thrones." In 2015, the country accounted for a shocking 29.77 million illegal downloads of the show. The United States and France followed behind Brazil, each contributing around 10 million downloads. As the wait for the last season of the popular show reaches fever pitch, this devastating leak raises vital questions about the effectiveness of the show creators' anti-piracy efforts. The source of the leak highlights the need for tighter security and stricter protocols in sharing review copies with press and perhaps reconsidering the extent of early access provided to press and other insiders. With HBO reeling from this breach of trust, it remains to be seen how much of a negative impact this leak will have on the highly-anticipated final season of the show. Many loyal fans have taken to social media to denounce those who have watched the leaked episodes, vowing to wait until the official release to watch the series in support of the creators. Whether the network will choose to alter its protocol for distributing sensitive material to prevent future leaks is yet to be seen, but one thing is for sure: "Game of Thrones" continues to reign supreme in popularity and piracy.

I just rented Blackwater Valley Exorcism because the cover and pictures looked terrifying, and I don't normally watch movies that are automatically released onto DVD, but this looked so interesting and scary! I was very much in the mood for a good scary film and to me, possession is one of the scariest subjects to watch or learn about. Just look at The Exorcist or The Exorcism of Emily Rose, both terrific movies that made break-throughs not only horror wise, but story as well.Blackwater Valley Exorcism is about a girl, Isabelle, who from the get go is automatically possessed, so we can't even tell what kind of a person she was to begin with. But a former wife beater turned priest is on the case with a gardener...? I know... I know. Then they go into several other stories with the priest and Isabella's sister, and the priest hit the sister and messed around with Isabelle? I'm not sure, then we get into a story with Isabelle's dad and his questioning of his wife's faithfulness to him.I mean, the story just goes into too many directions and wasn't well developed at all. Not to mention that the exorcism didn't seem authentic at all and more of a just scare your pants off type of a film, which I didn't like at all because I couldn't take it seriously. Whoever directed and wrote this clearly had no idea where to go or how to direct the story well, so I wouldn't really recommend this.210

Headline: Models Dazzle in Golden Runway Extravaganza in Xi'an, China Xi'an, China - In an opulent display of fashion and luxury, models took to the catwalk in extravagant outfits made from real gold. The fashion show was held in Xi'an, the ancient capital city of China and showcased designs featuring intricate gold craftsmanship. The 24-karat gold underwear and shirts worn by the models were worth a staggering 40,000 each. However, these dazzling items were designed as an artistic expression and are not currently intended for sale. Xi'an is known for its rich history, being the starting point of the Silk Road and the home to the legendary Terracotta Warriors. This unique fusion of history and contemporary fashion showcased the city's ability to bridge the gap between the ancient and the modern, creating a truly unforgettable spectacle. It highlighted the expertise of Chinese artisans who have passed down their craft through generations. The lavish event attracted fashion enthusiasts from around the globe, who marveled at the exquisite detailing and intricate patterns adorning the luxurious outfits. This is the first report applying the Porcine 60 K SNP array for simultaneous analysis of boar taint compounds and related sex hormones, using both GWA and LDLA approaches. Several QTLs are involved in regulation of androstenone and skatole, and most of the QTLs for androstenone are also affecting the levels of estrogens. Seven QTLs for androstenone were detected in one breed and confirmed in the other, i.e. in an independent sample, although the majority of QTLs are breed specific. Most QTLs for skatole do not negatively affect other sex hormones and should be easier to implement into the breeding scheme.

10-Year-Old Boy Seriously Injured After Being Hit by Stray Bullet Intended for Aggressive Dog A 10-year-old boy, Danel Hall, was rushed to the hospital after being shot in the stomach by a stray bullet over the weekend. The incident occurred when a bullet, originally aimed at an aggressive dog, missed its target and struck the young boy instead. Danel was playing outside when the unidentified shooter tried to subdue the aggressive dog in their neighborhood. The bullet narrowly missed the boy's liver but left him with serious injuries. Doctors and medical staff at the hospital have been working tirelessly to ensure that Danel recovers fully from the incident. The police have launched an investigation into the events leading up to the shooting, and are working to identify the person responsible for this tragic accident. Officers are currently reviewing surveillance footage from nearby homes and interviewing witnesses to establish a clearer account of what transpired. While the full extent of Danel's injuries and prognosis are yet to be determined, his family has expressed their gratitude for the overwhelming support they have received from friends, neighbors, and residents of their quiet community. The concerned residents have been rallying around Danel and his family, offering their help and assistance in any way they can. Local businesses and community members have also been donating funds to assist the family with any unforeseen medical expenses that may arise as a result of the accident. This tragic shooting has brought the issue of stray bullet incidents and the dangers of using firearms irresponsibly back into the spotlight. Authorities have urged residents to practice responsible firearm use and educate themselves on proper safety precautions. As the investigation continues, the community is hoping for swift justice and Danel's speedy recovery.

As demonstrated here, the Gpnmb and Tyrp1 iris phenotypes are both individually dependent on tyrosinase function. These results support involvement of abnormal melanosomal events in the diseases caused by each gene. In the context of the inbred D2 mouse strain, the glaucoma phenotype is clearly influenced by more genes than just Gpnmb and Tyrp1. Despite the outward similarity of pigment-dispersing iris disease between D2 and the B6 double-congenic mice, the congenic mice are much less susceptible to developing high IOP and glaucoma. These new congenic strains provide a valuable new resource for further studying the genetic and mechanistic complexity of this form of glaucoma.

However, I can provide you with some general information on the topic: D90 is a dosimetric parameter that refers to the dose delivered to 90 of the target volume (e.g., the prostate gland) during brachytherapy, such as I-125 seed implant monotherapy for localized prostate cancer treatment. It is used to evaluate the effectiveness of the treatment in terms of dose distribution, and it is typically expressed in units of Grays (Gy). There have been studies conducted to investigate the correlation between D90 and treatment outcomes. Some findings suggest that higher D90 values are generally associated with better outcomes, such as lower rates of biochemical failure (e.g., an increase in prostate-specific antigen or PSA) and improved local control of the tumor. You the living? OK I think I am an intelligent, educated, liberal and really into films. I really like and have a great sense of humour. I was under the impression this was a bleakly painful comedy. They got paid for making this, petrol was used, electricity burnt, food was consumed, sets built........why? I blame the current state of the world on this film and all those people associated with it, I will even include us the viewing public. We are all to blame and deserve whatever coming. Its not funny, not much happens, everyone it seems is bored or boring. There are no conversations, communication is minimal. There is no plot as far as I am aware. The only message I have come away with is perhaps life is too short to sit around watching movies of people doing not much......and then you die!

An inmate at an Arizona jail left one officer hospitalized with brain bleeding and broken bones in his face after a psychiatric ward assault. The 18-year-old, who was booked into Lower Buckeye Jail in Phoenix two weeks ago, is seen on surveillance video walking in a room he was not authorized to be in before being approached by two officers. Maricopa County Sheriff Joe Arpaio said that the two jail employees began telling the young man to go back to his cell before he began taking swings at them. Scroll down for video . An assault on an officer at a jail in Phoenix has left one officer in intensive care with brain bleeding. Above, the inmate is captured on video in a psychiatric ward area where he is not authorized . Officers including Scott Beaty (center) approached the unidentified 18-year-old inmate and told him to go back to his cell . The inmate then began punching Beatty and the other officer in the room, who used a Taser but could not subdue the young man . The unnamed inmate, who was not immediately affected by four taser shots, was eventually subdued by a large group of officers who came to the scene. Three detention officers were taken to a nearby hospital, and two of them had been knocked unconscious. Scott Beaty, a 15-year-veteran, was taken to the intensive care unit and will need reconstructive surgery after suffering a brain bleed and broken bones in his face. The inmate, who did not have any prior incidents of bad behavior, was not injured. After knocking Beaty to the ground, the inmate is seen attacking the other officer, who was also taken to a nearby hospital . More officers arrived on the scene where the assault took place, though additional taser shots did not immediately affect the 18-year-old . The unidentified inmate was eventually subdued by a group of officers, who saw their colleague knocked out on the ground after being hit repeatedly . 'Sometimes when you have a mental condition you fight and get super mad,' Arpaio said during a press conference, though he did not elaborate on the mental condition. Arpaio said he could not speculate on what led to the attack. The prisoner became 'very violent' according to officials, and was reportedly fighting until he was put in lock down in the psychiatric ward, where he remains. He will only be allowed out for one hour a day. Though he was booked into Lower Buckeye for a minor felony charge, the prisoner will now face aggravated assault charges. Arpaio said that there have been 178 incidents of assault at his county's jails in the last 12 months. Beaty was taken to the intensive care unit after the incident, where he suffered broken bones in his face and brain bleeding . Three of four officers injured in the attack went to the hospital. The inmate was not injured during the incident .

I first saw this on Thames television and loved it. The film, 'A Day at the Seaside', is a feel-good classic that takes the audience on a journey through the hustle and bustle of a quintessential British seaside town. The director, George Fontaine, masterfully captures the essence of a bygone era, as he follows the lives of diverse characters who converge for a day of laughter, love, and self-discovery. The film boasts a talented ensemble cast that brings each character to life. The eccentric ice cream vendor John, played by the brilliant Edward Miller, offers up more than just sweet treats - his kind words and unexpected wisdom are the glue that holds the community together. The budding love story between Mary and William, portrayed by Rachel Green and Sam James, is tender and relatable, illuminating the beauty within the awkward first steps of young love. The picturesque cinematography is breathtaking, offering a striking juxtaposition between dreary, gray skies and the vibrant colors of the beachfront attractions. The breathtaking background score effortlessly transports you to the seaside, providing the perfect ambiance for the story to unfold. In a world where cynicism often prevails, 'A Day at the Seaside' is like a breath of fresh air - a simple and whimsical take on the magic of human connections. It serves as a beautiful reminder of the power of a shared experience - whether it's a stolen moment with a stranger or a lifelong memory with friends. So, if you're in search of a film that will leave you with a sense of nostalgia and warmth, then this hidden gem is undoubtedly the one to watch. 'A Day at the Seaside' is an endearing and heartfelt film that will continue to resonate with audiences for years to come.

The progressive prolongation of latency of ABEP and BIC components with advancing position in the train may be attributed to cumulatively decreased synaptic efficacy at high stimulus rates, resulting in prolonged synaptic delays along the auditory pathway. The paradoxic enhancement of ABEP dipole III magnitude with advancing click position in the train may reflect higher sensitivity of inhibitory brainstem neurons to increased stimulus rate, resulting in disinhibition. The absence of significant effects on BIC dipole magnitudes may reflect the amplifying effect of divergence in the ascending auditory pathway, as has been observed for the monaurally evoked ABEP components from the upper pons.

A Maine man who may have had a few too many lobster rolls over the years became trapped in his seatbelt on the way back from Easter festivities and his family members captured it on video. Clint Chadbourne, 71, was headed back to Portland from Massachusetts with his wife and daughter when they pulled over at a rest stop. When Clint tried to get out the car, he couldn't do it because his gut was stuck in his seatbelt. Scroll down for video . Clint Chadbourne, 71, was headed back to Portland from Massachusetts when he got stuck in his seatbelt . Chadbourne, who was with his wife and daughter when they pulled over, said he was 'getting hydrophobic' While Clint struggled against the confining strap and his wife Bonnie watched, daughter Kelly began filming. In the video, he said in a thick Maine accent: 'You look at me.I am stuck in this cah. 'I'm getting hydrophobic.' It's unclear what he was trying to say, but probably didn't mean he was getting scared of water. After he tried to tell Bonnie and Kelly that the seatbelt was 'defective' they informed him it was his body that was likely causing the problem. Bonnie, 67, and Clint are celebrating their 50th anniversary this year, according to the Portland Press Herald. She posted thetwo-minute clip on Facebook and it has been viewed almost30 million times. Clint said: 'We didn't do it expecting publicity. It was just something that happened.' Kelly was eventually able to free her father from his nylon shackle, the Bangor Daily News reported. Bonnie said: 'He tried to get out and he couldn't. He was stuck. 'I really thought we were going to have to call the fire department.' Clint's wifeBonnie, 67, posted the two-minute clip on Facebook and it has been viewed almost 30 million times .

Manchester United have begun the search for Michael Carrick's long-term replacement, with Ilkay Gundogan a prime contender to fill the role. Manager Louis van Gaal has been hugely impressed with Carrick's contribution at Old Trafford this season. The England international's passing range and ability to dictate the pace of a match has been a key feature for United. Michael Carrick (left) has been instrumental in Manchester United's recent run of good form . United boss Louis van Gaal has been impressed with Carrick's contribution to the team . Van Gaal has identified Borussia Dortmund's Ilkay Gundogan as a long-term successor to Carrick . MICHAEL CARRICK . Age: 33 . Height: 6ft 2in . Manchester United appearances: 379 . England caps:33 . Honours: Champions League (2008), Premier League (2007, 2008, 2009, 2011, 2013), League Cup (2010), Club World Cup (2008) ILKAY GUNDOGAN . Age:24 . Height: 5ft 9in . Borussia Dortmund appearances: 86 . Germany caps:9 . Honours:Bundesliga (2012), German Cup (2012), German Supercup (2013) But at the age of 33, the Dutchman knows the midfielder is in the twilight of his career, while the amount of time Carrick has been injured this season is also a worry. United will seek to sign Carrick's successor this summer as part of another huge spending frenzy. Dortmund's ball-playing midfielder Gundogan has been watched extensively by United. Van Gaal has an intrinsic knowledge of the Bundesliga and believes the 24-year-old has the ability to take over from Carrick on a long-term basis. Carrick, who recently signed a new 12-month extension, will continue to be part of Van Gaal's plans next season - but the club are planning for life without him. The impending departure of manager Jurgen Klopp could see the excellent Dortmund squad unravel this summer. Gundogan (right) has been watched extensively by United, who could make a move in the summer . Dortmund could listen to offers to avoid losing Gundogan on a free transfer in 2016 . Jurgen Klopp's impending departure from Dortmund could see a host of players leave the club . Gundogan's existing contract expires at the end of next season and he is yet to sign a new deal. Dortmund are keen to tie the Germany international to an extension, but will listen to offers for him in the summer to avoid losing him for nothing in 2016 if he continues to stall on fresh terms.

There is limited evidence showing a direct relationship between desmoglein 2 and kallikrein 7 in the context of pancreatic cancer. Desmoglein 2 is a cadherin-type cell-cell adhesion protein primarily involved in cell adhesion and maintaining tissue integrity, while kallikrein 7 is a serine protease associated with various biological processes such as skin desquamation, inflammation, and cancer progression. Individual roles of desmoglein 2 and kallikrein 7 in pancreatic cancer have been investigated. Desmoglein 2 has been reported to be overexpressed in various cancers, including pancreatic cancer, and may be involved in cancer progression and invasion. Kallikrein 7, on the other hand, has been implicated in the degradation of the extracellular matrix and the promotion of tumor invasion and metastasis in several cancers. However, current literature does not provide sufficient evidence that directly links desmoglein 2 as a substrate of kallikrein 7 in pancreatic cancer. Further research is needed to explore this potential relationship and its implications in cancer biology and targeted therapy.

Changes in DNA cytosine methylation levels induced by hyperglycemia in mouse liver cells produced changes in the respective DNA FT-IR profiles, revealing modifications to the vibrational intensities and frequencies of several chemical markers, including as -CH3 stretching vibrations in the 5-methylcytosine methyl group. A smaller band area reflecting lower energy absorbed in the DNA was found in the hyperglycemic mice and assumed to be related to the lower levels of -CH3 groups. Other spectral differences were found at cm 1) and in the fingerprint region, and a slight change in the DNA conformation at the lower DNA methylation levels was suggested for the hyperglycemic mice. The changes that affect cytosine methylation levels certainly affect the DNA-protein interactions and, consequently, gene expression in liver cells from the hyperglycemic NOD mice.

Rappers Arrested on Charges of Drug Possession and Firearms at Georgia Southern University Three members of a popular rap group were arrested at Georgia Southern University on Saturday night after drugs and firearms were discovered in their tour van. Quavious Marshall, 24, Kirschnick Ball, 20, and Kiari Cephus, 23, were escorted off campus by university police and now face charges of drug possession, possession of firearms in a school safety zone, and during the commission of a crime. The suspects, who are best known for their 2013 hit "Versace," have found themselves in hot water after multiple guns, marijuana, and another undisclosed drug were discovered inside their vehicle. The group was visiting the university for a performance on campus when law enforcement became involved. The university police were alerted to the situation after a strong odor of marijuana was detected near the van. Upon further investigation, officers discovered the drugs and firearms. The suspects were taken into custody without incident and now await their court hearings. The university has not released an official statement regarding the situation, but safety concerns have been raised by students and faculty. Incidents like these bring attention to the need for increased security measures on campuses throughout the country. The three rappers, who have yet to release an official statement regarding their arrest, now face legal troubles that could impact their music careers. As for their young fans, this incident serves as a reminder of the dangers associated with drugs, guns, and recklessness.

I thought this would be funny, but as the minutes dragged on, I realized 'Laughing Gas' would fail to live up to its promising title. The premise, which revolves around the accidental release of a gas that makes people laugh uncontrollably, held great potential for comedic moments. And with a star-studded comedic ensemble led by Steve Carell and Melissa McCarthy, I was ready for some major chuckles. However, the humor fell flat thanks primarily to a paper-thin plot and characters that appeared more like caricatures. The screenplay offered little substance, and the gags felt recycled from better comedies of the past. As the film stumbled from one slapstick scene to another, the actors tried valiantly to bring their best to the table, even in the face of paint-by-numbers material. Unfortunately, their talent couldn't compensate for the glaring weaknesses in the script, making their efforts feel tired and repetitive. The film's few redeeming qualities were some genuine belly laughs offered by the supporting cast, particularly Kate McKinnon and Ken Jeong. Their characters were quirkier and seemed to inject a much-needed spark that the rest of the film sorely lacked. But ultimately, their scenes couldn't save 'Laughing Gas' from its utter lack of comedic oomph. In conclusion, 'Laughing Gas' proved to be a disappointing entry into the comedy genre. Despite an amazing cast and an initial premise that could have made for a hilarious comedy, the weak screenplay and overused gags left viewers overwhelmingly unsatisfied. Save your time and money, and skip this gas of a comedy.

Intestinal helminthiases are highly prevalent parasitic infections with about 1 billion people infected worldwide. In this scenario, better understanding of host-parasite relationships is needed to elucidate the factors that determine intestinal helminth rejection. The intestinal trematode Echinostoma caproni has been broadly employed in this field, with resistance against secondary homologous infections reported in mice. In this paper, new insights are provided in the regulation of tissue homeostasis after intestinal infection. The unexpected lack of an altered pattern of ileal protein production associated to resistance development suggests that this resistance depends on rapid changes, affecting the early establishment of worms, rather than the activation of later effector mechanisms. These results may contribute to the development of new control tools for the management of these parasitic infections.

Yes, large scale genome-wide association studies (GWAS) and linkage disequilibrium linkage analysis (LDLA) mapping studies can identify quantitative trait loci (QTLs) for boar taint and related sex steroids. Boar taint is an unpleasant odor and taste in pork, caused primarily by the presence of the compounds androstenone and skatole. Identifying QTLs associated with boar taint and sex steroids helps in understanding the genetic basis of these traits and can assist in breeding strategies to reduce boar taint in pork production. In recent years, several studies have used GWAS and LDLA mapping methods to identify QTLs associated with boar taint compounds and sex steroids in different pig breeds. These studies have identified significant QTLs on multiple chromosomes, which may explain the genetic variation in boar taint compounds and related sex steroids. These findings provide a basis for the development of marker-assisted selection (MAS) and genomic selection (GS) strategies to reduce the occurrence of boar taint in pig populations and improve pork quality. However, further research on the effects of the identified QTLs across different populations and breeds is necessary for the successful implementation of such strategies in pig breeding programs.

Subheading: Cao Yu, 22-year-old, was on patrol when she confronted the man who wounded her five times In a shocking yet inspiring incident, a 22-year-old policewoman, Cao Yu, was stabbed by a robber while patrolling in northeastern China. Despite being injured, she showed immense bravery and held on to the man until reinforcements arrived. She has since become the symbol of courage and has been lauded by people all over the country. Cao Yu, the brave policewoman, was on night duty when she encountered the robber. She confronted the man bravely, without knowing that he was armed with a knife. The man viciously attacked her, stabbing her five times before she could call for help. Despite her grave injuries, she waited for backup without letting the robber escape. Upon their arrival, Cao Yu's colleagues found her "bleeding all over" but still holding on to the robber. She was rushed to the hospital where she received immediate medical assistance. Fortunately, her condition is stable and she is now recuperating from her injuries. The incident quickly garnered attention on social media, where people were in awe of Cao Yu's grit and determination. The young policewoman has become a heroic figure, receiving praise and support from all corners of the country. Her bravery has not only won hearts, but has also highlighted the risks and dangers that law enforcement officers face every day while carrying out their duties. This incident serves as a reminder for the public to value and appreciate the men and women who risk their lives to maintain law and order. As Cao Yu continues to recover from her injuries, the citizens of China have commended her unyielding spirit and immense bravery. As a result of her actions, she has become an inspiration to many others and has received recognition for her fearlessness in the line of duty.

Tesco Launches Investigation after Bleach Found in Wine Bottle A family from Milton Keynes received an unwelcome surprise when they discovered bleach in a bottle of Tesco Finest Garnacha wine. Jan Jones had bought the bottle as a present, but her daughter luckily realized something was wrong after her first sip. After drinking just a mouthful of what was supposed to be wine, Jones' daughter began breaking out in painful welts. It was then the family decided to inspect the liquid and found it to be clear in color and smelling strongly of bleach. The wine was immediately discarded and Jones took to social media to share her shock and disappointment. Tesco responded to Jones' account of the incident on Twitter, stating that they were "very concerned to hear of this" and encouraged the family to return the bottle to their local store for investigation. The supermarket giant assured the public that the wine in question was not produced by Tesco, but by one of their suppliers. The company has since launched a full investigation into the matter. A Tesco spokesperson said, "We were very concerned to hear of this incident and are in contact with the customer. We will be conducting a thorough investigation into the matter." No other customers have reported similar experiences with the wine, and as of yet, there have been no recalls issued. Jan Jones' daughter is said to be recovering well after the unsettling incident, but the family is still seeking answers as to how bleach could have made its way into a seemingly harmless bottle of wine.

Antigua, West Indies - England's premier fast bowler, James Anderson, stands on the brink of history as he prepares to earn his 100th Test cap on Monday, 28th January. As England faces the West Indies at the picturesque Sir Vivian Richards Cricket Ground, Anderson needs just four wickets to surpass Sir Ian Botham's national record of 383 Test wickets. More than fifteen years since he first represented the national team, the 36-year-old Anderson has been England's leading pace spearhead, playing an instrumental role in the team's rise to the top in Test cricket. Blessed with incredible swing, sly seam movement and relentless perseverance, the Lancashire pacer's mastery over the cricket ball has earned him rave reviews from teammates, coaches and opponents alike, who deem him one of the finest fast bowlers of his era. Born and bred in Burnley, Anderson started his cricketing journey with his hometown club, Lowerhouse Cricket Club and gradually made his way through the age-group ranks before joining the Lancashire County Cricket Club. His meteoric rise through the cricketing world saw him make his England debut against Zimbabwe in 2003, where he announced his arrival by picking up a crucial five-wicket haul. Since then, Anderson has been a stalwart for the English team, playing vital roles in several key victories in Tests, ODIs, and T20s. Among his innumerable accolades, he holds the record for the most Test five-wicket hauls for England with 27 to his name. Across his illustrious career, "Jimmy," as he is fondly known, has picked up 380 wickets in Tests alone and has 269 scalps in ODIs. During this monumental Test match against the West Indies at Antigua, Anderson now has the chance to surpass the legendary Sir Ian Botham and make his mark as England's highest Test wicket-taker. Should Anderson make history and come out on top, he will surely be remembered as one of the greatest fast bowlers to ever play the game for his country.

Rome (CNN) Italy is coping with a rising wave of desperate migrants from Africa and Middle East hoping to make it to Europe. From Friday to Monday, a total of 8,480 migrants were rescued, according to the Italian coast guard, which said it received on Monday alone SOS calls from 20 boats in distress. On Tuesday, a spokesman with Save the Children told CNN the group fears 400 migrants could be missing, citing testimony from survivors who said their ship carrying 550 people capsized in the Mediterranean Sea about 80 miles off the Libyan coast. The Italian coast guard, however, told CNN that while it is taking the report seriously, it cannot confirm such an incident and has not yet found evidence at sea to indicate a migrant boat carrying approximately 550 has capsized with 145 rescued. An operation that included boats and planes did not find any survivors, nor bodies, nor any evidence to indicate a particular boat capsized, Coast Guard official Filippo Marini said. There has been a recent upsurge in migrant boats crossing the Mediterranean into Italy and an increase in rescues performed by the Italian Coast Guard to aid migrant boats. Why migrants are dying trying to reach Italy . According to the International Organization for Migration, Italy registered more than 10,000 migrants arriving in the first three months of 2015, and about 2,000 were rescued at sea during the first weekend of April in the Channel of Sicily. Most migrants recorded this year come from countries in West Africa as well as Somalia and Syria, the IOM said. They use Libya as a country of transit. At least 480 migrants have died while crossing the Mediterranean since the beginning of the year, often because of bad weather and overcrowded vessels used by smugglers, the IOM said. Sometimes the captains and crews abandon the ships, leaving passengers to fend for themselves. Last week: 978 migrants rescued in one day in Mediterranean Sea . CNN's Ralph Ellis contributed to this report.

Predictable, gory, over-gimmicky, mediocre - these are the words that come to mind after watching "Chainsaw Parade." The movie sets out to be yet another in a long line of slasher flicks, but ultimately fails to leave a mark. The film's plot has been seen time and time again - a group of attractive, clueless teenagers head to a secluded cabin for a weekend of drinking and debauchery, completely unaware of the crazed maniac lurking in the shadows. The film makes no attempt to subvert the genre or offer any original ideas, resulting in a wholly predictable and unsatisfying experience. As for the gore - there's plenty of it. Limbs are severed, innards spill, and blood sprays in a manner reminiscent of low-budget 1980s horror films. However, the overabundance of carnage feels cumbersome, senseless, and fails to elicit the fear or shock it was intended to stir. "Chainsaw Parade" relies heavily on gimmicks - not just in its special effects, but also in its reliance on a ridiculous villain straight out of a comic book. The chainsaw-wielding killer wears a garish, neon-colored outfit, and spouts cheesy one-liners after every successful slaughter. While campy humor can often elevate a horror movie, this attempt falls completely flat and renders the villain a laughable caricature rather than a threatening antagonist. The acting is mediocre across the board, and the characters are forgettable, one-dimensional, and ultimately uninteresting. It's impossible for the audience to care about their fates, and the typically suspenseful "who will survive?" question posed by many horror films is rendered moot. In conclusion, "Chainsaw Parade" is a tired rehash of worn-out tropes and excessive gore. Its over-the-top gimmicks and underdeveloped characters serve only to underscore the film's mediocrity. Though it may provide a small amount of entertainment for die-hard slasher fans, most viewers will find little to praise in this disappointing and derivative flick.

It is great to see a film starring kids whose idea of "acting adult" is not engaging in sensuality. In the charming and refreshingly wholesome movie "Little Heroes," the audience is treated to a delightful display of friendship, adventure, and teamwork as a group of youngsters takes on a seemingly insurmountable challenge in their small town. The cast of talented young actors shines in their respective roles, each exhibiting a level of depth and nuance well beyond their years. The protagonists are relatable, and their camaraderie teaches valuable lessons about friendship and collaboration. It is worth mentioning that their dialogue and actions are age-appropriate, avoiding the pitfalls of making child characters seem precocious or worldly beyond their years. Director Jane Smith has crafted a visually stunning world, capturing the innocence of childhood and making the fictional town of Sunnyville come to life. The movie is peppered with comic relief, provided by the lovable yet bumbling town sheriff and the children's hilarious antics as they try to solve their town's mystery. "Little Heroes" leaves the audience feeling inspired, uplifted, and reminded of the importance of believing in oneself and the power of collaboration. In the midst of movies where child characters are often prematurely thrust into adulthood, "Little Heroes" is a breath of fresh air and a welcome addition to the family movie genre.
