Shooter: Terry Martin, 48, pictured in this 2012 mugshot, shot his girlfriend Laurice Hampton, 48, after she asked for half of his winnings . A man who won 500 on a scratch-off lottery ticket fatally shot his girlfriend and then himself after the pair got into a heated row about sharing the winnings. Terry Martin, 48, shot his girlfriend Laurice Hampton, 48, after she asked for half of the proceeds. But Hampton, critically injured from a gunshot wound to her chest, was able to call 911 about 6:30am Saturday to report the shootings before she died. Responding officers found the couple inside their master bedroomat their home on Beaty Street in Fort Worth, Texas, where Martin was pronounced dead from a gunshot wound to the head. Hampton was taken by ambulance to John Peter Smith Hospital but died a few hours later. Homicide Sergeant Joe Loughman said the tragic couple had known each other since childhood and had lived together for several years. Loughman toldThe Fort Worth Star-Telegram:'We received information that the suspect had won 500 on a Texas lottery scratch-off ticket and that the victim wanted half of the proceeds. The suspect didn't want to share it with her.' Victim:Hampton, pictured, was taken by ambulance to John Peter Smith Hospital but died a few hours later . Home: Martin shot Hampton at their home on Beaty Street in Fort Worth, Texas, pictured here, . He added: [Hampton told police] that she had been shot and that he had shot himself after he shot her.' Records showed that there was a history of violence between the couple. According to Tarrant County court records, Martin was sentenced in July 2012 to a day in jail and fined 214 for assaulting Hampton in their home in November 2011. Gruesome discovery: Fort Worth police officers found the couple inside a bedroom where Martin was pronounced dead from a gunshot wound to the head . In happier times: Martin, right, is pictured with his girlfriend Hampton, left, before the shooting . Couple: The tragic couple, pictured here, had known each other since childhood, according to police .

Police arrest man after finding woman's body in his car; possible link to missing Canberra couple In a dramatic arrest, police apprehended a 27-year-old man after discovering a woman's body in his car in Bermagui. Officers shouted, "Show me your hands!" before the suspect gave himself up without a struggle. The man had been on the run since Wednesday night. Authorities are yet to identify the woman's body found in the vehicle, and detectives are investigating if there is a possible link to the missing Canberra couple, Daniella D'Addario, 35, and her boyfriend Josaia (Joey) Vosikata, 27. Ms. D'Addario, a former teacher at Canberra High School, was reported missing on Monday along with her boyfriend. The police are thoroughly examining the case and the suspect has been taken into custody for further investigation.

The predicted secretomes of Frankia sp. are relatively small and include few hydrolases, which could reflect adaptation to a symbiotic lifestyle. There are no well-conserved secreted polysaccharide-degrading enzymes present in all three Frankia genomes, suggesting that plant cell wall polysaccharide degradation may not be crucial to root infection, or that this degradation varies among strains. We hypothesize that the relative lack of secreted polysaccharide-degrading enzymes in Frankia reflects a strategy used by these bacteria to avoid eliciting host defense responses. The esterases, lipases, and proteases found in the core Frankia secretome might facilitate hyphal penetration through the cell wall, release carbon sources, or modify chemical signals. The core secretome also includes extracellular solute-binding proteins and Frankia-specific hypothetical proteins that may enable the actinorhizal symbiosis.

This coming from an adult who happened to come across the first one expecting a movie aimed towards children and was surprised at the adult humor that was in Emperors New Groove, I must say, the sequel manages to capture the same charm and wit as the original. "Kronk's New Groove" perfectly balances the humor to entertain both children and adults alike. The story follows the lovable character Kronk, who gets a chance to step into the spotlight, showcasing all his endearing quirks and hilarious antics. The voice acting by Patrick Warburton as Kronk is stellar, as always, and the rest of the cast does an equally commendable job. The animation is bright and colorful, it retains the clean and attractive visual style of the first film. Though the plot may not be as strong as the original, the humor and character development make up for it. Watching our beloved characters from the first movie navigate through the adventures along with Kronk brings a sense of nostalgia that is undeniably heart-warming. While "Kronk's New Groove" may not quite reach the high benchmark set by "The Emperor's New Groove," it remains a thoroughly enjoyable sequel that deserves recognition. It caters to an audience of both children and adults looking for a lighthearted and amusing movie experience. So, whether you are a longtime fan of the original or just discovering this series, "Kronk's New Groove" does not disappoint.

World No. 1 Novak Djokovic overcame a challenging start to eventually defeat Alexandr Dolgopolov and notch his 26th consecutive victory in the Masters 1000 tournament series. Djokovic was a set down before he found his rhythm and secured a 6-7 (3), 7-5, 6-0 win, remaining in contention for his fifth Miami Open title. Dolgopolov gained attention in the tennis world after defeating world No. 2 Rafael Nadal at the Indian Wells Masters earlier this month, and he proved to be a tough competitor for Djokovic as well. In a thrilling first set, Dolgopolov managed to outplay the Serbian, utilizing his accurate serves and powerful groundstrokes. However, after receiving treatment to his feet during an on-court injury time-out, Dolgopolov appeared to struggle with mobility, making it easier for Djokovic to capitalize on the situation. The world No. 1 displayed his signature skill and agility to level the match by winning the second set. Dolgopolov's form seemed to decline further in the deciding set, and Djokovic was able to exploit his opponent's weakness, securing a victory and earning a place in the quarterfinals. Djokovic will next face Spain's David Ferrer, who defeated France's Gilles Simon in straight sets with a score of 7-6 (5), 6-0. In other match results, Britain's Andy Murray advanced to the quarterfinals after defeating South Africa's Kevin Anderson 6-4, 6-3.

All hungry Leo wanted was one of his dog biscuits to chew on. Instead the Staffordshire-Boxer cross ended up nearly burning the house down and killing his owner's son. The dog caused a severe fire after managing to switch on the cooker while trying to reach his dog treats. The heat from one of the hob's rings set fire to a child's seat that had been left resting on the electric appliance. Fire starter: Hungry Leo almost burned down his owner's home as he hunted for his dog treats . The blaze was started after the Staffordshire-Boxer cross was believed to have knocked one of the cooker knobs, switching on the hob . Smoke began to fill the three storey home in Peckham, south-east London, as owner Allen Mosey's son, 21, and his daughter's boyfriend relaxed in upstairs rooms. The pair managed to flee unharmed with Leo after noticing thick black smoke billowing up the stairs. More than 10 firefighters were needed to extinguish the flames. A search of the house later revealed that the source of fire was the cooker. Firefighters believe that when Leo was hunting for food he knocked one of the cooker's knobs, turning the rings on. The blaze damaged one third of the ground floor of the property and Leo's family have been left surviving on sandwiches. 'You wouldn't think butter would melt in his mouth to look at him,' Mr Mosey, 67, told the Southwark News. 'He's the most docile dog you could think of.' The charred remains of a car seat that had been left on the hob, which caught fire . Leo's owner Allen Mosey examines the damage caused to his home by the fire in Peckham, south-east London . Allen and his wife Jean were out shopping when the blaze started. Mrs Mosey, 47, confessed that she often left things on the cooker when it was switched off. She said that despite Leo almost burning down the house the family still love him, but he will be locked out of their new kitchen. A London Fire Brigade spokesperson said: 'We're naturally extremely pleased that no one was injured in this fire and while unusual, it's not unheard of for our crews to deal with incidents like this. 'It shows just how important it is to keep pets away from naked flames or cooker controls and to make sure kitchen surfaces and cookers are clear of food and other items that can easily catch fire.'

If you haven't read Tolkien's masterpiece; prepare yourself for maybe the best movie experience ever! If you have however... After having read the books several times, over many years, I have come to love the characters and story, and feel I Know it intimately. I have my own personal vision of The Shire, Hobbiton and the character-gallery. Thus for me the movie was a disappointment. Why? It dictates the appearance of the characters (unavoidably), it changes events, it removes important storyline, it removes not-so-important storyline. Great chunks of what makes The Lord Of The Rings what it is, is simply ignored. Even 2001 special effects can't do Tolkien's (and your own) imagination justice. Peter Jackson has made an honest attempt at the impossible, and I don't think anyone else could have done it better! But the fact remains, I regret seeing the movie. The next time I read The Lord Of The Rings, Peter Jackson's limited vision will leap forward, not my own.

Risk of in-hospital ischemic stroke with MI is closely tied to the time to revascularization with both thrombolytic and percutaneous transluminal coronary angioplasty therapies. Early revascularization is independently predictive of a lower risk of ischemic stroke, but the mechanism of this does not appear to be related to improved cardiac function. The records of 45,997 subjects who received thrombolytic therapy and 47,876 patients who were treated with primary percutaneous transluminal coronary angioplasty for myocardial infarction were analyzed to determine the relationship between time to revascularization and the occurrence of ischemic stroke. A statistically significant linear relationship between time to revascularization therapy and risk of in-hospital ischemic stroke was seen on univariate analysis. A multivariate model incorporating 26 other variables showed thrombolytic therapy within 15 minutes of presentation was associated with a lower risk of ischemic stroke, and angioplasty within 90 minutes was similarly associated with a nonsignificant trend toward lower stroke risk.

Increased leptin transgene expression in the DVC suppressed the time-related increase in body weight accompanied by a transient decrease in food intake at week 1 post-injection and little effect on thermogenic energy expenditure. That suppression of weight was due to decreased adiposity is shown by the markedly suppressed white adipose tissue-derived hormones, leptin and adiponectin. Circulating concentrations of pancreatic insulin, gastric ghrelin, and glucose levels were unchanged. This segregation of the varied effects of leptin expression in hypothalamic sites vs. DVC endorses the view that among the various endocrine organs under sympathetic nervous system control, only those leptin-activated neural circuits in the hypothalamus that suppress weight and adiposity on a long-term basis transverse through DVC en route to white adipose tissue.

Ixabepilone plus sunitinib demonstrated antitumor synergy via RhoB in naive and paclitaxel-resistant cells resulting in apoptosis. This study demonstrates a novel mechanism of action leading to antitumor synergy and provides 'proof-of-principle' for combining molecular targeted agents with cytotoxic chemotherapy to improve antitumor efficacy. RhoB could be envisioned as an early biomarker of response to therapy in a planned Phase II clinical trial to assess the efficacy of ixabepilone combined with a receptor tyrosine kinase inhibitor such as sunitinib. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first demonstration of antitumor synergy between these two classes of drugs in EOC and the pivotal role of RhoB in this synergy.

I watched this movie with big expectations, and to my delight, it exceeded every single one of them. The captivating storyline, stellar performances, and outstanding cinematography drew me in from the very first scene, creating a cinematic experience that was thrilling, emotional, and utterly unforgettable. The characters were exceptionally well-developed and portrayed. The actors breathed life and depth into each role, subtly conveying the complexities of their personalities, relationships, and aspirations. I found myself deeply empathizing with their struggles and cheering for their triumphs, making for an emotionally engrossing journey that resonated with me on a personal level. Additionally, the chemistry between the lead actors was palpable, which only served to tighten the narrative's grip on my heart. Visually, the movie was a masterpiece. Each scene was artistically composed and exquisitely shot, making for a richly immersive viewing experience that was, at times, breathtaking. The director's masterful use of color, light, and shadow, as well as the top-notch special effects, further accentuated the film's potent emotional core, heightening its impact and staying power. Moreover, the musical score was exceptional and played an integral role in shaping the film's mood and atmosphere. It was a perfect blend of haunting melodies and stirring orchestral crescendos that underscored the unfolding drama and heightened anticipation. In summary, this film was a tour de force that far surpassed my lofty expectations. It ticked all the boxes in terms of storytelling, acting, and visual appeal - a testament to the talents of its cast and crew. The powerful emotions it evoked will stay with me for a long time, and I wholeheartedly recommend it to anyone seeking an unforgettable cinematic experience.

I am a huge fan of the first four Ju-on projects, so naturally, I was thrilled to see the next installment in this iconic horror franchise. The film offers the same eerie atmosphere, spine-chilling visuals, and relentless scares that I've come to expect from this series. However, the filmmakers manage to breathe new life into the familiar storyline by presenting fresh twists and unexpected turns, ensuring that even the most die-hard Ju-on fans will be on the edge of their seats. The acting in this installment is top-notch - the cast delivers emotionally resonant performances, making it easy to become invested in their characters' fates. The cinematography captures the unsettling nature of the Saeki curse brilliantly, with its dark corners and ominously creaking doors that are reminiscent of the first films. The art direction and makeup effects team has also done an outstanding job, as the ghoulish and unearthly entities that inhabit this cursed house have never looked better (or scarier). One of the most terrifying aspects of the Ju-on series has been the ability of the films to build an almost unbearable sense of dread through atmospheric tension, rather than relying solely on jump scares (though there are plenty of those). This installment doesn't disappoint in that respect, with several climactic sequences that left me holding my breath in suspense. While there are some minor pacing issues and a few slightly less effective scares in the middle section of the film, the overall experience delivers enough terror and shock value to satisfy any horror fanatic. In addition, newcomers to the Ju-on series will likely find this entry to be as genuinely frightening as longtime fans. In conclusion, this latest addition to the Ju-on franchise is a must-see for fans of the series and horror enthusiasts alike. It successfully builds on the strengths of its predecessors, effectively raising the bar for contemporary supernatural horror films. Don't be surprised if you find yourself staying away from dark rooms and attic spaces after watching this terrifying tale.

Just reading the reviews of this wonderful BBC mini series reminded me how much I enjoyed this when it was first broadcast many years ago. At the time I remember waiting with anticipation for the next installment and fell in love with John Bowe and Janet McTeer ,two talented actors that we don't see enough of on TV or cinema these days. I have tried without success to obtain several of the BBCs fantastic dramas from the past, including the 1973 version of Jane Eyre and the 1972 version of Anne of Green Gables, all wonderful timeless classic stories, which sadly the BBC seem to have no intention of releasing on video or DVD. If anyone learns otherwise I would love to hear from them.In the meantime we will have to content ourselves with our recollections of how wonderful they were.

A significant proportion of patients 80years of age with PAD develop arterial disease in the infrapopliteal pattern in the absence of the traditional risk factors of smoking and DM. Our data also showed that this pattern of disease is significantly associated with tissue loss and critical limb ischemia, particularly in patients 80years of age. Primary care providers need to be educated to suspect ischemic etiology for foot pain and ulcers in elderly patients not otherwise thought to have risk factors associated with PAD. Vascular specialists need to anticipate this pattern of disease when planning interventions. As smoking becomes less prevalent and as the population ages, octogenarians with severe infrapopliteal arterial occlusive disease will become a larger proportion of the patients treated by vascular specialists.

Blackpool striker Nile Ranger has accused the club of 'taking the mick' out of him by giving him such a low-paid contract that it left him wondering how he would fill his fridge with food. The former Newcastle forward has not featured for the Seasiders since the end of November after making 14 appearances for the club in the first months of the season. has been AWOL since December. Ranger has been AWOL since returning to London after being left out of the squad to face Birmingham in early December, and the controversial striker has spoken for the first time about his struggles at Blackpool. Former Newcastle striker Nile Ranger joined Blackpool at the start of the season on a one-year deal . Ranger has been AWOL since early in December and says the club took the mick with his contract . 'I'm not on a lot of money there to be honest, they really took the mick,' Ranger was quoted as saying in the Blackpool Gazette. 'They put me on minimum wage and pay as you play. 'I was supposed to go to Leeds but it fell through so I went to Blackpool as a platform and just took whatever deal. I wasn't getting in squads and I was asking how am I supposed to fill my fridge if I'm not playing?' 'I thought I should have been playing. People who don't know the situation will be thinking, "oh, he's AWOL again." 'There are certain situations going on which no-one knows about. It just didn't work out. With the manager and stuff things just weren't clicking. Ranger spent four years at Newcastle between 2009-2013 but his time was littered with disciplinary incidents . Ranger arrives at court to be sentenced after being charged with common assault in 2013 . 'The manager is a good guy and things and everyone was nice but it was just the way they handled the deal, it was a bit off.' The 24-year-old's career has been littered with numerous disciplinary issues that has seen his two previous clubs Swindon and Newcastle terminate his contract. But Ranger wants to start a fresh next season after his one-year deal with Blackpool ends in the summer. 'I want to start a fresh again next season,' he said. 'There will be plenty of opportunities for me, people think my chances have run out. But there will be plenty of things for me in the future.'

An app which allows users to superimpose images of gory injuries to photos of themselves has been slammed for 'making a mockery of violence'. Scar Booth, which is available from the Apple iTunes store for 79p, offers a gallery of 77 wounds - purportedly real ones - and its makers boast: 'Your friends and family will be convinced that you have suffered a painful beating.' Anti-violence charities have hit back at the disturbing app for trivialising, or 'glorifying' abuse and brutality. Scroll down for video . Disturbing: Scar Booth, which I tested out myself (pictured), offers a gallery of 77 wounds - purportedly real ones - which can be superimposes onto selfies so you can 'prank' friends and family, according to the app . BulliesOut, a Cardiff-based anti-bullying charity, hit out at Scar Booth via Facebook, stating: 'People have to live with real scars... from self-harming, and suffer cuts and bruises from being bullied. 'This app makes a mockery of their injuries and what they have beenare going through.' Adam Fouracre, founder of violence prevention charity Stand up to Violence, concurred. 'It's a very negative thing about the society we live in if people think this sort of thing is fun or funny,' he said. According to the app's description, issued by its developer Appdicated, its main purpose is to prank friends and family. 'Load any picture and add virtual wounds to the photo, adjust the transparency of the image to make it look like it is a real injury. [It] will FREAK out just about anyone who sees it.' Mr Fouracre, who launched Stand up to Violence in 2005 after his brother was beaten to death in a random, violent attack late at night, insists it 'glorifies violence'. He argues: 'When people see these pictures they are going to be heartbroken and thinking something really is wrong.' Not so hilarious: The app's description reads, 'Your friends and family will be convinced that you have suffered a painful beating' Backlash: Anti-violence charities have accused the app of 'making a mockery' of abuse and 'glorifying violence' Appdicated founder Rory Boyer defended the app, stating: 'Scars and bruises do not have to come from violence and this app was created to prank friends and not to glorify violence.' Although the app is not intended for use by those under the age of 17, photos exist on Twitter of at least one young boy posing in his pajamas with the app's injuries covering his face, captioned: 'My face has been injured. Help Me'. And one iTunes review reads: 'I had so much fun mutilating myself and the rest of my family. I sent them to fb fooled everyone.' Mr Boyer insists that his company has not been contacted by a single anti-violence charity and says any concerns over the suitability of the app are 'very surprising to hear'.

This movie starts out great, and sucks you in. The opening sequence, filled with stunning visuals and a haunting score, sets the stage for a story that promises to keep you on the edge of your seat. The world-building is rich and intricate, making you feel as if you've been transported into the alternate universe crafted by the filmmakers. The performances delivered by the lead actors are strong and riveting, holding your attention from beginning to end. They carry the emotional weight of the film, drawing you into their stories and making you care about their fates. The supporting cast adds depth and texture, complementing the leads and providing an impressive ensemble. However, somewhere around the midway point, the pace starts to slow down and the narrative begins to meander. Some of the subplots feel unnecessary, taking away from the main story and leaving the viewer wishing for more focus on the primary plotline. Additionally, the film's runtime feels slightly overstretched, with certain scenes dragging on for too long, diluting the impact they were intended to have. Despite these flaws, the film still manages to deliver on the excitement front, with well-choreographed action sequences and breathtaking visual effects. The climax, while somewhat predictable, provides a satisfying resolution, tying up loose ends and leaving the audience with a sense of catharsis. Overall, while this movie doesn't quite reach the heights it sets out to achieve, it is still an entertaining and engaging journey, worth watching for its strong lead performances, immersive world-building, and thrilling action set pieces.

Yes, a psychological approach to successful aging can predict future quality of life in older adults. This approach focuses on factors such as attitude, resilience, optimism, cognitive functioning, and emotional well-being, which play a significant role in determining how well an older individual adapts to the aging process and maintains a high quality of life. Several studies have found that older adults who maintain a positive attitude, engage in mentally stimulating activities, and effectively manage stress and emotions tend to have a better quality of life. Furthermore, both physical and mental health contribute to an older individual's ability to successfully age, and addressing psychological factors is crucial in optimizing overall well-being. The psychological approach highlights the importance of maintaining a sense of purpose, fostering strong social connections, and staying engaged in meaningful activities throughout the aging process. By adopting this approach, older adults can actively work towards enhancing their future quality of life and living a fulfilling, healthy, and independent life.

I was laughing so hard most of the time that I had people glaring at me because they couldn't hear over my laughter. But honestly, I can't blame them - "The Hilarious Throwdown" is hands-down one of the funniest movies I've seen in years! With an all-star cast, including some of the best comedians of our generation, this comedy extravaganza guarantees non-stop laughs from beginning to end. The clever writing and fantastic character dynamics make for a truly entertaining experience. The story revolves around a group of friends who enter a nationwide comedy competition, leading to hilarious situations and off-the-wall antics. Their journey to stardom, filled with unexpected twists and turns, keeps the audience engaged and curious about what might happen next. What truly struck a chord with me was the brilliant comedic timing and chemistry between the actors. Their improvisational skills were on full display, making every scene feel fresh and genuinely funny. It was refreshing to see a comedy that didn't rely on cheap gags or offensive humor but instead focused on the strengths of the actors and the absurdity of the situations. "The Hilarious Throwdown" also does a great job of mixing physical comedy with witty dialogue. Every character has their own unique style and brand of humor, making the film appealing to a wide range of audience members. The movie is also visually appealing with vibrant colors, interesting sets, and creative costumes that add to the overall comedic experience. In conclusion, "The Hilarious Throwdown" is a must-see comedy for anyone looking to have a good laugh at the movies. With a talented cast, hilarious writing, and excellent comedic timing, it's a rollercoaster of laughter from start to finish. Just be prepared for some dirty looks from fellow moviegoers who might not be able to hear over your laughter!

(CNN) The leader of Yemen's Houthi rebels vowed not to back down on Sunday as a top Saudi military official claimed weeks of airstrikes had significantly weakened the Shiite group. "Our fighters will not evacuate from the main cities or the government institutions," rebel leader Abdul-Malik al-Houthi said in a televised address. "Anyone who thinks we will surrender is dreaming." His comments came after more than three weeks of Saudi-led coalition bombings aimed at pushing back the Houthis, who surged into the capital of Sanaa in January and ousted President Abdu Rabu Mansour Hadi from power. Hadi still claims he's Yemen's legitimate leader and is working with the Saudis and other allies to return to his country. Since mid-March, more than 700 people have been killed in violence that shows no sign of slowing, according to figures from the World Health Organization. The Houthis say they have the support of the country's people behind them. "It's the right of the Yemeni people to stand against the attacks in all possible means as long as the attacks continue," Al-Houthi said Sunday. "After our people move and react against the attacks and killing of children and women, we do not want to hear any voices and cries." But there are signs of some fracturing among forces loyal to former Yemeni President Ali Abdullah Saleh, many of whom have fought alongside the rebels. Gen. AbdulRahman AlHalili, who leads more than 10,000 troops, has now allied himself with Hadi, military sources said Sunday. Meanwhile, Saudi Brig. Gen. Ahmed Asiri said Sunday that airstrikes had decimated the Houthis' central command by targeting their communications. The rebels, he said, are now holding a defensive stance in besieged areas. Since it began the campaign known as Operation Decisive Storm on March 26, the Saudi-led coalition has launched 2,300 airstrikes, Asiri said. After hours at sea, chaos and desperation in Yemeni city . CNN's Don Melvin and Christine Theodorou contributed to this report.

THE CHAMPIONSHIP . Steve McClaren's Derby side will make sure of a play-off place with victory at Huddersfield provided Wolves and Brentford are both beaten. Just two years on from winning the FA Cup, Wigan will be relegated if they fail to win at home to Brighton - although Rotherham's FA hearing for fielding an ineligible player could change things were they to be docked points. Derby County can make sure of a play-off place with victory against Huddersfield if other results go their way . LEAGUE ONE . Bristol City boss Steve Cotterill said after his side sealed promotion: 'That's great, but we haven't won the league yet and that is what I want.' Victory at home to Coventry will give him the trophy he craves. Sheffield United and Chesterfield can both make sure of play-off places with wins over Bradford and Oldham respectively, as long as Rochdale lose away to Gillingham. Bristol City boss Steve Cotterill will get his hands on the League One trophy with victory against Coventry . LEAGUE TWO . Burton will be promoted with a win at Morecambe if Wycombe fail to win at AFC Wimbledon or Bury lose at Portsmouth. Shrewsbury will be up if they win at home to York, Bury lose and Southend fail to win at Exeter. Stevenage will seal a play-off place if they win at Accrington and both Luton and Newport fail to win against Hartlepool and Dagenham respectively. Burton will be promoted with a win at Morecambe if Wycombe fail to win at AFC Wimbledon . ...AND IN THE CONFERENCE . Martin Allen's Barnet side will be promoted as champions if they win at Kidderminster and Bristol Rovers lose at Dover. Eastleigh and Forest Green Rovers can make sure of a play-off place with victory over Lincoln and Gateshead respectively, as long as Macclesfield lose at home to Dartford, or, in Eastleigh's case, fail to win.

Person1: Good coming. What can I do for you? Person2: I'm in Room 309. I'm checking out today. Can I have my bill now? Person1: Certainly. Please wait a moment. Here you are. Person2: Thanks. Wait... What's this? The 30 dollar for? Person1: Excuse me... The charge for your laundry service on Nov. 20th. Person2: But I did't take any laundry service during my stay here. I think you have added someone else's. Person1: Ummmm...Sorry, would you mind waiting a moment? We check it with the department concerned. Person2: No. As long as we get this straightened out. Person1: I'm very sorry. There has been a mistake. We'll correct the bill. Please take a look. Person2: Okay, here you are. Person1: Goodbye.

Intrasexual competition can facilitate the evolution of alternative mating strategies in a colour polymorphic fish. In many cases, male fish exhibit different colour morphs that are linked to alternative mating strategies. These strategies could include territorial defense, female mimicry, or sneaking to increase their success in mate acquisition. The presence of intrasexual competition, particularly for limited mating opportunities, can drive the evolution of these alternative mating strategies as different colour morphs may be associated with different levels of success in finding mates and reproducing. For example, in some species, brightly coloured males may have a higher success rate in attracting females compared to less colourful males, while less colourful males may need to rely on deception or sneak tactics. In such cases, competition within the species can drive the maintenance and evolution of colour polymorphisms and associated mating strategies. One well-studied example of this phenomenon is the side-blotched lizard (Uta stansburiana). Males of this species occur in three different throat colours (orange, blue, and yellow), and each colour morph is associated with a different mating strategy. Orange males are territorial and aggressive, blue males form pairs and guard females, and yellow males mimic female appearance to sneak copulations. Intrasexual competition among males drives the existence and frequency of these different strategies, as each colour morph may have different fitness advantages depending on the local competitive environment. While this example is from lizards, similar principles can also apply to fish species that exhibit colour polymorphism. Therefore, intrasexual competition can indeed facilitate the evolution of alternative mating strategies in a colour polymorphic fish.

Bradley Dew has been jailed for mugging his deaf friend to steal his mobile phone and a 10 note . A thug has been jailed after he mugged his deaf friend to steal his mobile phone and a 10 note. Bradley Dew, 26, had been drinking with his friend at a pub in Faversham in Kent earlier that day and had borrowed his mobile. But later in the evening Dew returned to his friend's home, claiming he had lost the mobile on a train after returning from Herne Bay. As the friend said he was about to go out with his girlfriend, Dew pushed him back into a wall before striking him across the face. He then stole 10 out of his wallet. Dew, of Faversham, then fled the scene, and was found by police hiding in the toilets of a pub close to his friend's home hours later on March 29 last year. Officers said he was likely to have been left feeling vulnerable after being mugged in his own home. Dew denied stealing from his friend, and told officers it would have been 'like robbing my brother.' However he was found guilty of robbery and assault, following a trial held at Maidstone Crown Court. Detective Constable Kathryn Lumsden-Earle, of Kent Police, said: 'Dew took advantage of a so-called friend's generosity, taking his phone and then never returning it. 'He then acted like a bully by pushing and hitting his vulnerable victim before stealing money from his wallet. 'He did all of this in the victim's own home, which no doubt left him very frightened and scared for his safety. 'Time behind bars just might give him that opportunity to reflect on what he did that day, but more so the impact it had on someone he knew was vulnerable and who viewed him as a friend.' Dew, 26, was found guilty of robbery and assault by a jury at Maidstone Crown Court (pictured)

Yes, hydrogen bond networks play a significant role in determining the emergent mechanical and thermodynamic properties across a protein family. Hydrogen bonds are crucial for protein folding, stability, and function. They contribute to the formation and stabilization of secondary structures, such as alpha-helices and beta-sheets, and are also involved in tertiary and quaternary structures. Proteins within a family often have similar sequences and structures, and share common functions. The hydrogen bond networks are an essential aspect of these structural and functional similarities. The presence, absence, or alteration of hydrogen bonds can influence the properties of a protein, affecting its stability, flexibility, and interactions with other molecules. In some cases, subtle changes in hydrogen bond networks can lead to functional diversity within a protein family. These networks are also crucial to the folding process of proteins, as they help to guide and stabilize the formation of the final folded structure. Proper folding is critical for protein function, and disruption of hydrogen bond networks can lead to misfolding and aggregation, which are implicated in various diseases, such as Alzheimer's, Parkinson's, and prion-related diseases. In summary, hydrogen bond networks play a significant role in determining the mechanical and thermodynamic properties of proteins in a protein family. They are critical for proper protein folding, stability, and function, and their alteration can lead to variations in properties or even dysfunction and disease.

Phosphodiesterase type 5 (PDE5) inhibitors are a class of drugs commonly used for the treatment of erectile dysfunction (ED). Since the introduction of the first PDE5 inhibitor, sildenafil (Viagra), in 1998, several other drugs have been developed and approved for use in treating ED. These include vardenafil (Levitra), tadalafil (Cialis), and avanafil (Stendra). Mechanism of Action: PDE5 inhibitors work by promoting relaxation of the smooth muscle tissues of the corpus cavernosum, resulting in increased blood flow to the penile shaft and erection. They achieve this by selectively inhibiting the phosphodiesterase enzyme type 5, which is responsible for the degradation of cyclic guanosine monophosphate (cGMP) in the penile smooth muscle cells. With PDE5 inhibition, cGMP levels increase, leading to smooth muscle relaxation and enhanced blood flow. Efficacy and Safety: Numerous clinical trials and analyses have demonstrated the efficacy of PDE5 inhibitors in improving erectile function in men with ED of varying etiologies, including organic, psychogenic, and mixed causes. PDE5 inhibitors have been found to be effective in treating ED in men with comorbid conditions such as diabetes, hypertension, and cardiovascular disease. In general, PDE5 inhibitors are well-tolerated by most patients. Common side effects include headache, facial flushing, nasal congestion, dyspepsia, and back pain. These side effects are typically mild and transient. However, more severe side effects such as the risk of priapism, sudden hearing loss, and vision disturbances have been reported, although they are rare. Contraindications to the use of PDE5 inhibitors include concurrent use of nitrates and hypersensitivity to the drug or any of its components. Comparisons and Patient Preference: While all PDE5 inhibitors share a similar mechanism of action, there are several differences among them that may affect patients' preferences and treatment outcomes. Sildenafil and vardenafil have a shorter half-life (approximately 4-5 hours) and onset of action within 1 hour, whereas tadalafil has a longer half-life (approximately 17.5 hours) and onset of action within 30-45 minutes. Avanafil has the shortest onset of action (15-30 minutes) and a half-life of approximately 5 hours. These pharmacokinetic differences may translate into differences in duration of action and flexibility in the timing of sexual activity. Several studies have compared patients' preferences for different PDE5 inhibitors. Factors influencing preferences may include a drug's efficacy, side effect profile, cost, and ease of use. While some patients may prefer the faster onset of action and shorter duration of sildenafil or vardenafil, others may prefer the longer duration of action and flexibility provided by tadalafil. Conclusion: PDE5 inhibitors remain a mainstay of pharmacological treatment for ED, with a variety of options available to suit patients' individual needs and preferences. Ongoing research continues to explore novel PDE5 inhibitors and other pharmacological approaches for ED, as well as strategies to optimize patient outcomes. Product development, biotechnological innovations, combination therapies, and personalized medicine approaches are likely to shape the future landscape of ED treatment.

Median tumor size was 3.4 cm (range: 0.7-18.0 cm), and median ischemia time was 21 min (range: 4-55 min). Postoperative acute renal failure (ARF) occurred in 70 patients (19) including 58 (16) who had a glomerular filtration rate (GFR) 15 mlmin per 1.73 m (2) within 30 d of surgery. Among the 226 patients with a preoperative GFR or30 mlmin per 1.73 m (2) and followed or30 d, 38 (17) developed new-onset stage IV chronic kidney disease during follow-up. As a continuous variable, longer warm ischemia time was associated with ARF (odds ratio: 1.05 for each 1-min increase; p0.001) and a GFR15 (odds ratio: 1.06; p0.001) in the postoperative period, and it was associated with new-onset stage IV chronic kidney disease (hazard ratio: 1.06; p0.001) during follow-up. Similar results were obtained adjusting for preoperative GFR, tumor size, and type of partial nephrectomy in a multivariable analysis. Evaluating warm ischemia in 5-min increments, a cut point of 25 min provided the best distinction between patients with and without all three of the previously mentioned end points. Limitations include the retrospective nature of the study.

Person1: Great choice! Would you like to have a particular dish or would you like some recommendations? Person2: I'm not very familiar with Chinese cuisine. Can you please recommend some dishes? Person1: Of course! Some popular options include Kung Pao Chicken, Mapo Tofu, and Beijing Roast Duck. We also have a variety of rice and noodle dishes to choose from. Person2: All of those sound delicious. I'll have the Kung Pao Chicken with a side of white rice, please. Person1: Excellent choice! Would you like to add any appetizers or drinks to your order? Person2: Yes, I'll have an order of vegetable spring rolls and a pot of jasmine tea, please. Person1: Wonderful! Your order will be ready shortly. Enjoy your meal!

In normal knees, the distal femoral condyle is typically more externally rotated to the patellar tendon at 90 of flexion. This external rotation helps maintain proper patellar tracking as the knee moves through its range of motion. However, individual variations in anatomy and alignment can impact this relationship, so it is possible to see variations in the rotation of the distal femoral condyle relative to the patellar tendon in different individuals.

We're living in sad times today, in which it seems like every comedy movie and TV show is painfully unfunny and inflicted with cheap, crude, or poor humor. Most people don't know what it means to really laugh at a comedy, and these people desperately need to watch "Throw Momma From the Train." I say with little hesitation that this is one of the funniest movies I've ever seen, from beginning to end. The comedy is so unpredictable and twisted just enough to make us laugh out loud many times throughout. Don't be fooled by the murder plot. The plot is not serious enough to make us care or worry about what's going to happen. The story involves a young man (Danny DeVito) who wants to get rid of his annoying, grouchy mother (Anne Ramsey, nominated for an Oscar in a role that was completely flawless, in my opinion) and does so by killing off Billy Crystal's wife, whom Crystal wanted dead for stealing his novel. I don't want to spoil the jokes and gags in this film, but all I can say is that you must see this film if you want to laugh. Fast-paced and genuinely, a real treat to comedy lovers, and the type of film you just do not see today.12 out of

Earlier this week, Brazilian commuter Nelson Felippe was deeply offended by a scene he witnessed on a train platform. He proceeded to take a photo, and express his disapproval on Facebook, after which the image was shared more than 100,000 times in 24 hours. In the picture, taken on a train platform in Rio de Janeiro, two women hug and gaze into each others' eyes, but the source of his outrage soon becomes clear in a post that cleverly spoofs conservative attitudes. Brazilian man, Nelson Felippe posted this image, expressing his disapproval at the 'scene'. The viewer believes he is conducting a homophobic rant, as he mentions: 'They are challenging social conventions, and this can be dangerous' In his Facebook post, Felippe stated: 'I am not prejudiced, I think everyone does what they want out of your life. But I find it absurd that I should be forced to witness a scene like this. 'What one does in private is your business, but what you do in public concerns me yes. And I refuse to see a scene like this and consider it normal.' A man breaks safety regulations by standing with his foot on the yellow line . 'I do not wish ill of anyone, but people should be preserved. [They] are challenging social conventions, and this can be dangerous. Continuing with what the unknowing reader assumes at this point is a homophobic rant, the next part of the post starts to become confusing. 'If after a tragedy strikes, or worse, if someone dies, who will put the blame on who? On me? Worst of all is the example for children. Suddenly it becomes clear what Felippe, who works at the Catholic University of Rio de Janeiro, is really warning against - with his tongue firmly in this cheek. 'What would happen to a child who sees this scene every day? 'Kids will think it's normal to wait for the subway on the yellow line. So, don't act like that guy over there. 'Follow the example of the girls.' It seems the Brazilian commuter was in fact observing a public transport safety regulation, which the man in the far top-right is clearly breaking. Felippe warns others not to follow in the delinquent man's footsteps. The post has received thousands of comments with users applauding his witty way of exposing homophobia. Leando Da Silver wrote: 'Great text. Shows that do not need to be boring to combat homophobia.' Celia Rodrigues added: 'There are people that judge before concluding the reading.'

Carwyn Scott-Howell's death was a tragic accident, accordingto state prosecutor Pierre Yves Michau . The family of tragic ski boy Carwyn Scott-Howell were expected to bring his body home this weekend as an investigation into his death ruled out negligence as a factor. Carwyn, seven, plunged 160ft to his death in Flaine, France, while skiing with his mother Ceri and siblings Gerwyn and Antonia, after becoming separated from them. According to state prosecutor Pierre Yves Michau, the schoolboy's death earlier this month was 'a tragic accident' with no one to blame. The family, from Talybont-on-Usk, Wales, were enjoying their last run of the holiday when Antonia fell and her mother stopped to help. Carwyn carried on skiing and then ventured into a wooded area. His mother thought he had continued to their accommodation but raised the alarm when he did not return. Mr Michau said: 'The inquiry has found the piste was well signposted. The boy would have been aware that he was leaving the piste. The reason why is not known but it was by error. 'Had he been with someone bigger or older, the accident wouldn't have happened but it remains a dramatic and tragic accident.' In a statement released to the Foreign Office, his family described Carwyn as a 'daring, outgoing, determined little boy' and a 'very competent skier and snowboarder'. They said they were enjoying their last ski run together when Carwyn's sister 'lost her ski on a jump and at this point Carwyn skied ahead'. 'He was a very daring outgoing determined little boy whose handsome smile lit up any room and made life full of laughter with never a dull moment. Seven years is too short a time to be an angel in the sky. 'Carwyn was a very competent skier and snowboarder who had started skiing at the age of three and spent several weeks each year skiing. We had spent the most happy ski holiday together in the French ski resort of Flaine.' The statement went on to explain how the family became separated on their last run of the day. 'The family were all enjoying their last ski run over the small jumps and bumps at the side of the slope together, when Carwyn's sister lost her ski on a jump and at this point Carwyn skied ahead,' it said. 'The family cannot explain their feeling of utter devastation with a vast void in their hearts. ' Carwyn, seven, from Talybont-on-Usk, Wales, plunged 160ft to his death in Flaine, France .

Former Tottenham footballer Gary Mabbutt has urged people to better understand the perils of diabetes after nearly losing his left leg due to complications associated with the condition. The 57-year-old, who was diagnosed with diabetes at the age of 17, recognized that something was not right when he woke in the middle of the night to find that his leg was extremely cold. Speaking to BBC Radio 5 live, Mabbutt recounted how he was forced to rush to the hospital at 5 AM after realizing that his leg had stopped working. Medical professionals informed the ex-Spurs star that the main artery had become completely blocked. As a result, he underwent an operation to replace the damaged artery, which saved his leg. If left untreated, this blockage could have led to the amputation of his limb. Mabbutt, who played over 600 games for Tottenham across a 16-year career, said the experience gave him a new perspective on the potential dangers of diabetes. "Ever since I was 17, I've been having up to seven injections a day, and always watching my blood sugar levels and doing my blood tests," he recalled. However, the incident highlighted that the complications of diabetes can develop even for those who diligently manage their condition. More than four million people in the United Kingdom have diabetes, with the number expected to rise to five million within the next 20 years. Mabbutt hopes that sharing his story will help raise awareness about this widespread, yet often misunderstood, condition. He emphasized the importance of regular checkups, stating, "Make sure you get checked out if you're feeling a bit sleepy, you're losing a bit of weight, and you're going to the toilet every five minutes - these are the signs of diabetes." The ex-footballer is dedicated to using his platform to promote education on diabetes and its potential dangers. By spotlighting his own experiences, he aims to show that vulnerability to complications does not diminish, even if one has been living with diabetes for a long time.

Cocky medical students play chicken with process that simulates death, in attempt to get a (hopefully temporary) view of the afterlife. Certain plot twists and themes are a little off the mark, and the acting occasionally goes over the top. But the underlying message - about God's and others' forgiveness for our real or perceived sins - is positive and unique in cinema, and the cast is very very good. The last sequence between Julia Roberts and her father is so effectively done that, years after having seen it, I still get chills thinking about it. Highly recommended.

The results implicate correlated activity between the cortex and the striatum, especially the nucleus accumbens core and the basolateral amygdala, in the generation of a conditioned motivated state that may promote excessive food intake. The upregulation of a number of genes in unique patterns within corticostriatal, thalamic, and hypothalamic networks suggests that food cues are capable of powerfully altering neuronal processing in areas mediating the integration of emotion, cognition, arousal, and the regulation of energy balance. As many of these genes play a role in plasticity, their upregulation within these circuits may also indicate the neuroanatomic and transcriptional correlates of extinction learning.

A massive sandstorm engulfed the city of Golmud in China's northwestern region, leaving behind apocalyptic scenes resembling the surface of Mars. Incredible pictures captured by local residents show the entire city covered in brightly-colored sand, with the skies turning red during the 30-minute long event. Golmud, situated between the Kunlun and Tanggula mountains in the Qinghai province, experienced the intense sandstorm yesterday that forced its inhabitants to flee the streets. The region's sandy deserts and harsh climate makes it highly vulnerable to such weather-related incidents. This unusual phenomenon saw the swirling dust transform the city into a red hellscape, with visibility severely reduced. Several residents took to social media to share dramatic images of the surreal Mars-like environment, expressing fear and awe over the event. Sandstorms are common in China's northwestern regions during spring, usually occurring between April and June. The country has been grappling with increased desertification, particularly in its northern areas, as a consequence of climate change and human activities such as deforestation. Chinese authorities have adopted reforestation and desertification control measures to combat the rising issue of sandstorms plaguing various regions. In March 2021, Beijing was hit by its worst sandstorm in a decade, prompting the country to set a target planting of over 100,000 square kilometers of forests by the end of this year. Fortunately, the Golmud sandstorm did not last long, with no severe damage or casualties reported. However, it serves as a reminder of the increasing volatility of weather patterns worldwide and the necessity for sustainable management and conservation of natural resources.

Viral marker data comparing confirmed seroprevalence in 1 (st) time volunteer non-remunerated donors (VNRD) and familyreplacement donors (FRD) corrected for gender and age, show no significant difference between the two groups. Evidence has been provided that for both VNRD and FAD benevolence is more appropriate than altruism. The two groups merge for psychological attitude to donation for which knowing someone needing transfusion is a powerful incentive to give blood. Excluding a life or death situation found in areas where severe blood shortage justifies replacement donation, pressures are exerted on both VNRD and FRD. There is no evidence of coercion of FRD. FRDs therefore meet all criteria for VNRD and are willing to become VNRD and to repeat donation. Ostracising FRD is illegitimate and damaging to the blood supply in resource poor areas. In some countries no difference is made between the two groups of donors representing similar populations asked to give blood in different circumstances.

Person1: Are you going anywhere for your vacation? Person2: Yes, we're making plans for a tour. Person1: That'll be lovely. Where are you going? Person1: Well, you've got to prepare a lot of food and enough sleeping bags then. Person2: Oh, we'll spend the nights in hotels and enjoy local food as we pass by. How does it sound, David? Person1: It sounds good. You can do a lot of sightseeing, too. Person2: Yes, we'll take our time. And we'll go to Five Lake Strict and the Wall Street. Person1: So, you're going to have a really nice vacation. Person2: You can say that again.

(CNN) Anthony Doerr's "All the Light We Cannot See," a novel centered on the World War II bombing of St.-Malo, France, and two characters on opposite sides of the war, won the Pulitzer Prize for fiction Monday. Doerr's novel had received rave reviews upon its release last spring. "I must blame Anthony Doerr for lost sleep, because once I started reading his new novel, 'All the Light We Cannot See,' there was no putting it down," wrote William T. Vollmann in The New York Times Book Review. Doerr's work was also a finalist for the National Book Award. It's his second novel and fourth work of fiction, including two short story collections. 2015 Pulitzer Prize winners in journalism named . "Between Riverside and Crazy," a play by Stephen Adly Guirgis, won the Pulitzer for drama. An earlier Guirgis work, "The Motherf with the Hat," ran on Broadway in 2011. Elizabeth Kolbert's "The Sixth Extinction: An Unnatural History" won the Pulitzer for general nonfiction. Kolbert, a New Yorker staff writer, tackles the idea that we're at the beginning of another mass die-off. "As the planet warms up, and carbon dioxide acidifies the oceans, all bets are off except the ones hinging on mass extinctions," wrote Nicholas Lazard in The Guardian. Despite that prospect, he added, "Kolbert's book is not, thankfully, as depressing as you might think. She has a good grip on her subject and uses a light touch when it is most needed." Other winners in arts and letters categories include "Encounters at the Heart of the World: A History of the Mandan People" by Elizabeth A. Fenn (history); "The Pope and Mussolini: The Secret History of Pius XI and the Rise of Fascism in Europe" by David I. Kertzer (biographyautobiography); "Anthracite Fields" by Julia Wolfe (music); and "Digest" by Gregory Pardlo (poetry). The Pulitzer Prizes are administered by Columbia University and are considered some of the most prestigious honors in journalism and literature.

Restoration of tumor suppressor miR-34 has been shown to inhibit human p53-mutant gastric cancer tumorspheres in certain experimental settings. In a study by Song et al., it was demonstrated that restoring the miR-34 tumor suppressor could significantly inhibit the growth of p53-mutant gastric cancer tumorspheres, enhance cell cycle arrest, and promote apoptosis. Additionally, the restoration of miR-34 expression could suppress cancer stem cell properties and inhibit tumorsphere formation. Overall, these findings suggest that restoration of miR-34 has potential therapeutic implications for treating p53-mutant gastric cancer. However, more research is needed to confirm and better understand these findings.

Yes, preclinical evidence does support the idea that activation of mesolimbic alpha 6 subunit containing nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (6-nAChRs) is involved in the development of nicotine addiction phenotype. Studies using rodent models have demonstrated that activation of these receptors is critical for the reinforcing effects of nicotine and the development of addiction-like behaviors. Specifically, 6-nAChRs are highly expressed in the mesolimbic dopamine system, which plays a vital role in mediating the rewarding effects of drugs of abuse, including nicotine. Activation of 6-nAChRs on dopaminergic neurons can increase dopamine release in the nucleus accumbens, a brain region associated with reward and motivation. This increase in dopamine release is thought to underlie the reinforcing properties of nicotine, contributing to the development of addiction. Further, genetic manipulation studies in rodents have shown that deletion or reduction in 6-nAChR function can decrease the reinforcing effects of nicotine and reduce addiction-related behaviors, such as self-administration and reinstatement. In summary, preclinical evidence indicates that activation of mesolimbic 6-nAChRs plays a crucial role in supporting the nicotine addiction phenotype. However, it is important to note that these findings are from animal models, and further research is needed to fully understand the role of these receptors in human nicotine addiction.

Ander Herrera: The Rising Star of Manchester United Manchester United's midfield maestro Ander Herrera has been in sensational form this season, scoring seven goals since joining from Athletic Bilbao and drawing comparisons to club legend Paul Scholes. However, the humble Spaniard insists that such comparisons are premature, labeling Scholes as a "one off." Herrera has been an influential figure at Old Trafford since his arrival in 2014, helping the team to secure a top-four finish in the 201415 season and adding vital goals and creativity to manager Louis van Gaal's side. Recent performances have seen fans and pundits alike highlight the similarities between Herrera and the ginger-haired genius who ruled the United midfield for almost 20 years. But Herrera is determined not to get carried away, paying tribute to the man who won 11 Premier League titles, three FA Cups, and two UEFA Champions League trophies with the Red Devils. In a recent interview, Herrera said, "I feel very proud when somebody says I can play like him, but I think it's almost impossible to be like him. He's a one off. There's only one Paul Scholes, but I try to learn from other players, and I'm always trying to improve." Adding to his comments on Scholes, Herrera continued: "Being compared to a player like Paul Scholes is extremely flattering, but I still have a long way to go to attain the level of mastery and consistency that he displayed for Manchester United." While his exploits for Manchester United have featured numerous moments of brilliance, Herrera revealed that his favorite goal for the club came against Yeovil Town in the FA Cup third round in January 2015. The midfielder's sweetly struck volley from outside the box secured United's place in the fourth round as they went on to lift the trophy at the end of that season. Herrera's growing stature at Old Trafford has seen him become a fan favorite and a key player under new manager Jose Mourinho. If he can continue to display his current form, both creatively and in front of goal, it may not be long before the comparisons to Paul Scholes become more frequent and deserved. For now, Ander Herrera remains focused on the task at hand, as Manchester United continue their push for another Premier League title and European success in the coming years. United supporters worldwide will be hoping that the Spaniard continues to shine in the heart of the team's midfield, helping to propel the iconic football club back to the pinnacle of the sport.

Central venous catheter (CVC) -related infections are a significant cause of morbidity and mortality in burn patients. These infections can lead to extended hospitalizations, increased healthcare costs, and negative outcomes for the patient. Identifying risk factors and understanding the prevalence of CVC-related infections in burn patients is crucial for developing effective prevention strategies. Prevalence of CVC-related infection in burn patients: Several studies have highlighted the prevalence of CVC-related infections in burn patients. The rates of CVC-related infection in burn patients ranges between 5 and 41. This variation in prevalence could be attributed to factors such as differences in patient populations, types of burn injuries, CVC insertion sites, and management protocols. Risk factors for CVC-related infection in burn patients: 1. Severity of burn injury: Patients with severe burns are at a higher risk of developing CVC-related infections due to the disruption of the skin barrier, compromised immune response, and the need for prolonged CVC use. 2. Catheter duration: The risk of infection increases with the duration of catheterization. Studies have found that CVCs used for more than seven days are associated with a higher risk of infection compared to those used for a shorter period. 3. CVC insertion site: The subclavian and internal jugular venous sites are associated with a lower risk of infection than the femoral site. 4. Catheter care: Poor adherence to catheter care protocols, such as aseptic technique during insertion and maintenance, increases the risk of CVC-related infections. 5. Age and comorbidities: Older patients and those with underlying medical comorbidities are at a higher risk of developing CVC-related infections. Prevention strategies to reduce the prevalence of CVC-related infection in burn patients: 1. Educating healthcare personnel about proper aseptic technique during CVC insertion and maintenance, as well as the importance of adhering to infection control guidelines. 2. Implementing a CVC bundle, which includes a combination of evidence-based practices, such as hand hygiene, maximal sterile barrier precautions during insertion, chlorhexidine skin antisepsis, and timely removal of the CVC when no longer needed. 3. Utilizing antimicrobial-impregnated catheters, which have been shown to reduce the risk of catheter-related bloodstream infections. 4. Regular assessment of the patient's clinical status and need for the CVC, and prompt removal when it is no longer necessary. In summary, the prevalence of CVC-related infection in burn patients remains a significant issue. Understanding the risk factors and implementing evidence-based prevention strategies are crucial to reduce the rate of these infections and improve patient outcomes. Further research is essential to better understand the risk factors and develop more targeted interventions for this vulnerable patient population.

The average Briton enjoys 884 cups of tea each year - or enough to fill two bathtubs, a survey has found. The YouGov poll of more than 2,000 Britons revealed that we consume an average of 17 cups of tea each week. The research showed that our tea-drinking habits increase as we get older, with those aged 55 and over typically enjoying 21 cups of tea a week compared with 18 to 24-year-olds, who only drink eight cups a week. The average Briton enjoys 884 cups of tea each year - or enough to fill two bathtubs, a survey has found . The poll also found that almost a third of women turn to a cuppa to make them feel better when they are unwell - in comparison with only 16 per cent of men. Youngsters are more likely to turn to a cuppa when they are sad, with nearly a quarter of 18 to 25s saying they put the kettle on when they are feeling down, compared with just 11 per cent of 55 and overs. And more than half of adults associated a cup of tea with 'comfort and relaxation' - confirming the results of a separate survey which yesterday revealed that sweet tea promotes relaxation and relieves stress. Mary Rance, chief executive of charity Contact The Elderly - which commissioned the poll and organises tea parties for older people - said: 'This confirms that tea really is part of our national identity. We know from our parties and our research that a cup of tea brings Britain together.' The poll found that almost a third of women turn to a cuppa to make them feel better when they are unwell . 'At Contact The Elderly, we know first hand that a monthly tea party makes a huge difference to the lives of our older guests, many of whom do not have regular face-to-face contact with anyone other than their carer or the postman. 'The number of isolated over-75s is growing, and there are still one million lonely older people in England, Scotland and Wales who are completely cut off from society and in need of our help. 'We know from our parties and our research that a cup of tea brings Britain together, so as we celebrate our Golden Jubilee, we urge people to support us by volunteering to put the kettle on for lonely older people.'

My best guess is this piece of work will come out on DVD sometime before Christmas.This movie was terrible. The time line jumps all over the place. This wouldn't be so bad if it left some suspense for the end. It was entirely predictable. Bitch girls pick on outcast, outcast wants to know why they hate her so much, bitch girls die a terrible death, outcast girl goes home and looks crazy. Outcast girl brought evil spirits with her, makes neighbors go crazy and kill each other. Creepy kid understands what's going on. US and Canadian forces seize over 28 tons of cocaine in the eastern Pacific Ocean A colossal 28 tons of cocaine valued at 848 million has been seized by U.S. Navy and Coast Guard and Royal Canadian Navy ships operating in the eastern Pacific Ocean near Central and South America. The seizures, described as the most successful run for drug seizures since 2009, took place in 19 separate incidents, including a 10-ton bust from a coastal freighter, marking the largest maritime drug interdiction in the area over the last decade. Authorities have praised the work of the joint US and Canadian forces, citing the arrests and seizures as a significant step in their ongoing fight against drug trafficking. "Crews operating these ships are out there day and night working to take drugs out of circulation and dismantle the criminal networks that profit from the suffering these drugs cause," said Admiral Craig Faller, commander of US Southern Command, which oversees US military operations in the Western Hemisphere. The increase in seizures also highlights the ongoing challenge of drug trafficking in the region. Many drug cartels have turned to maritime routes to smuggle their contraband, benefiting from the vast and remote nature of the oceans, as well as minimal law enforcement presence in the area. The joint effort between the US and Canadian navies has been hailed as a successful collaboration in the fight against international drug trafficking. The latest blows to the criminal networks involved in the cartel operations in Central and South America are a significant step forward for the authorities, but with the demand for narcotics remaining high in North America, the battle to disrupt the supply chain continues.

"Don't Torture a Duckling" is one of the coolest Italian horror films I've ever seen, and I've seen my share. Released in 1972 and directed by the maestro of giallo, Lucio Fulci, this film offers that delightful blend of mystery, gore and social criticism that made Italian classics of the time stand out. Set in a small, rural village in southern Italy, the film follows the horrific serial murders of young children. The local community is riddled with superstition, religious fervor, and palpable tension. It's a slow burn but that's what makes it even more exciting. Unlike other giallo films, Fulci focused on creating a dark atmosphere, exquisite cinematography, and well-developed characters. The acting is on point, especially from Florinda Bolkan who plays the mysterious Maciara, a woman accused of witchcraft. Her performance is as intense as it is delicate, and you can't help but feel a connection with her. The soundtrack by Riz Ortolani is hauntingly beautiful, perfectly encapsulating the eerie atmosphere of the film. What sets "Don't Torture a Duckling" apart from other Italian horror films of the time is its social commentary. Fulci explores themes of religious fanaticism, paranoia, and mob mentality in a way that makes you question the true nature of evil. While "Don't Torture a Duckling" may lack some of the more over-the-top scenes of its gory contemporaries, it compensates with a compelling story, interesting characters, and a chilling atmosphere. It's a hidden gem worthy of discovery for fans of classic Italian horror and a testament to the genius of Lucio Fulci. If you haven't seen this masterpiece yet, do yourself a favor and dive into this twisted tale of mystery, religion and murder.

The film is a great watch, very thoughtful. I believe it is a film about how your life would be if you lived in a world created by catalogues. This unique concept was executed brilliantly, with visually stunning and often surreal scenes that transport the viewer into a picture-perfect world. The protagonist's journey is both relatable and profound, as we witness their struggles and growth with the realization that reality is often more complex than the glossy images we see in catalogues. The acting was superb, with each character being well-rounded and genuine, adding a sense of authenticity to the story. The cinematography was mesmerizing, with each frame resembling a carefully crafted piece of art. The use of colors and lighting was breathtaking, emphasizing the contrast between the protagonist's ideal catalogue world and the realities of their everyday struggles. Moreover, the soundtrack was thoughtfully curated, blending harmoniously with the visual narrative to create an immersive cinematic experience. The film delivers a poignant message about the importance of acknowledging our imperfections and embracing the world's imperfections, promoting a more authentic and fulfilling life. In conclusion, this film is a must-watch for those seeking a unique and thought-provoking cinematic experience. Its unconventional storytelling, outstanding visuals, and masterful performances make it an unforgettable film that will leave a lasting impression on its viewers.

Norman Wisdom's final starring vehicle was a departure from his previous outings - bringing his accident-prone milquetoast up-to-date, this being a product of the Swinging Sixties! "The Groovy Misadventures of Norman" delivered a delightful blend of physical comedy, romance, and plenty of groovy dance numbers that encapsulated the spirit of the era. Wisdom was in top form as Norman, a clumsy and endearing protagonist who finds himself entangled in the glamorous world of sixties fashion and pop culture. The film masterfully showcased Wisdom's talents, and his impeccable comedic timing had the audiences in stitches. The supporting cast, including the brilliant Carol White as the love interest, perfectly complemented Wisdom's performance, creating memorable characters and adding depth to the chaotic world of his character. The film's vibrant colours, and mod-inspired wardrobe ensured that every scene was visually engaging. The energetic musical score composed by Tony Hatch perfectly captured the spirit of 1960s London, providing a surreal backdrop for Norman's many misadventures. Notable musical numbers include the iconic "Groovy Night" and "Bumbling in the Rain," which showcased Wisdom's singing and dancing abilities. "The Groovy Misadventures of Norman" was a fun, nostalgic romp that encapsulated the spirit of its time while highlighting Norman Wisdom's evolution as a performer. The film stands out as a fitting conclusion to Wisdom's illustrious career, leaving audiences with lingering good vibes and a longing for more of his comedic genius.

Everton Boss Roberto Martinez Hits Back at Critics Over Tactics Everton manager, Roberto Martinez, has hit out at critics suggesting that he is tactically stubborn. The Spaniard has faced criticism for persisting with the same style of play, moving the ball on the ground out from defence. Martinez insists that he is 'innovative' in his tactics and points to the adjustments he made during Everton's win over Southampton on Saturday. In that game, the Toffee's coach shifted from his preferred 4-2-3-1 to an unorthodox 3-4-3 formation, showcasing his ability to adapt and change his tactics when necessary. "I know that it has been said that I am stubborn with my tactics, but I think that we have shown we can be innovative and adaptable when necessary," Martinez said. "Against Southampton, we made a few changes and got the result that we wanted." Everton's 3-0 win over Southampton was a much-needed boost after a disappointing end to last season, and Martinez believes that the team is heading in the right direction. "I believe that we have a strong team and that we will continue to get better as the season progresses," Martinez continued. "We have a great blend of experienced players and young talent, and I am confident that we can achieve our goals this season." Further defending his tactics, Martinez added that his possession-based style has been successful in the past, particularly during his time at Swansea City and Wigan Athletic. "I've always believed in playing a brand of football that focuses on moving the ball out from the defensive areas and retaining possession," he said. "It's worked well for my teams in the past and I believe that it can work for Everton, too." The Everton boss has also received support from his players, with midfielder Gareth Barry commenting that the team is fully behind their manager's tactics. "We all have belief in the style of play and the tactics that the manager wants us to employ," Barry said. "We know that if we stick to the game plan and execute it properly, we can get the results that we desire." Ultimately, Martinez is adamant that his tactical approach can bring success to Everton this season. As the team continues to adapt and improve, he will be hoping that the results will silence his critics once and for all.

Medial smooth muscle cell loss in arterial allografts has been suggested to occur through various mechanisms, one of which is cytolytic cell-induced apoptosis. Research has shown that infiltrating cytotoxic T cells and natural killer cells can contribute to smooth muscle cell apoptosis in allograft arteries. This, however, is just one possible mechanism among others, such as chronic rejection, immune-mediated injury, and ischemia-reperfusion injury, that could cause medial smooth muscle cell loss in arterial allografts.

Patients had generalized weakening of the affected lower extremity and numerically the largest asymmetry was evident for leg extensor power. In contrast, healthy peers had no asymmetry in leg extensor power. These results indicate that exercise interventions focusing on improving leg extensor power of the symptomatic lower extremity and reducing asymmetry may be beneficial for patients with hip osteoarthritis. Implications for Rehabilitation Even in patients with mild symptoms not awaiting hip replacement a generalized muscle weakening of the symptomatic lower extremity seems to be present. Between-leg differences in leg extensor power (forcevelocity) appears to be relatively large (19) in patients with unilateral hip osteoarthritis in contrast to healthy peers who show no asymmetry. Compared to muscle strength the relationship between functional performance and leg extensor power seems to be stronger, and more strongly related to power of the symptomatic lower extremity. Our results indicate that exercise interventions focusing on improving leg extensor power of the symptomatic lower extremity and reducing asymmetry may be beneficial for patients with mild symptoms not awaiting hip replacement.
