Headline: Everton Goalkeeper Tim Howard Joins Wheelchair Football Team Training Session Everton Goalkeeper Tim Howard showed his support for wheelchair football by joining the Everton in the Community's (EITC) team for a training session at Croxteth Sports Centre recently. The U.S international took part in a series of activities during the session, including shooting practice and a short game. The Toffees goalkeeper showed his commitment to the cause by fully engaging with the wheelchair football team and even participating in the game himself. The players were delighted to have the support of such an important figure within the club and the wider football community. The EITC's wheelchair football team is just one of many disability-focused sports initiatives that the organization supports. With the aim of promoting inclusivity and accessibility in all sports, EITC has continued its commitment to disability sports by providing opportunities for people with disabilities to participate in various sports and activities. Speaking on his involvement with the wheelchair football team, Tim Howard said, "I'm honored to join the team today and learn more about this fantastic sport. It's great to see how serious these athletes take their game and how much hard work they put in. I'm just happy to support them in any way I can." "Everton in the Community has been a leader in promoting inclusivity and diversity within sport," he added. "It's great to be a part of such an important organization that helps people with disabilities get involved in sports and other activities." The management and players of the wheelchair football team expressed their appreciation for Tim's involvement and commended his commitment to bringing the sport into the mainstream. They hope that his high profile support will help raise awareness about disability sports and inspire more people to participate in these activities. Johnnie Garside, the Team Manager at Everton in the Community's wheelchair football team, said, "We're absolutely thrilled to have Tim join us today. His presence will undoubtedly help to raise awareness of disability sports and show people that they can be a part of the game no matter their ability." Garside continued, "It's fantastic to see Tim recognizing the importance of disability sports and supporting our efforts in breaking down barriers surrounding the game. Our team is a shining example of how hard work and determination can overcome challenges and we're proud to have Tim as a part of our club." The EITC's wheelchair football team is continually growing, with regular training sessions and participation in national competitions. With the support of ambassadors such as Tim Howard, the team hopes to inspire and motivate people with disabilities to participate in the sport and lead active, fulfilling lives.

Serie A champions Juventus want to strengthen their attacking options this summer with a big-money move for PSG striker Edinson Cavani, according to a report in Italy. Corriere dello Sportclaim that Juve have a plan in place to sign the in-demand Uruguayan as they look to partner him with fellow South American Carlos Tevez. Cavani, who played for Italian sides Palermo and Napoli before joining PSG in a 50million deal in 2013, has admitted his frustration at being played out of position under Laurent Blanc. PSG striker Edinson Cavani (left) is a target for Juventus according to Italian newspaper Corriere dello Sport . Manchester United also hold an interest in Cavani, pictured in action against Marseille last weekend . He told Canal Plus: 'The only concern that I have ever spoken about is that I was recruited to play as a striker with (Zlatan) Ibrahimovic and it has not always been the case. 'There is a long series of games where I have not scored in Ligue 1 but that can happen. In France, people judge me as a lone striker, but I do not play in that position.' Former Manchester United boss David Moyes attempted to sign Cavani before he joined PSG and the Old Trafford club remain interested in acquiring him when the transfer window reopens. Louis van Gaal is hoping to bring two new strikers to Old Trafford this summer with Radamel Falcao unlikely to turn his loan move into a permanent one and Robin van Persie being eyed by both Juve and Inter Milan. United appear to have an advantage over Juventus in their pursuit of Cavani after the player's agent, Claudio Anelucci, admitted that a move to England or Spain was most likely. Cavani (left) has admitted that he is concerned about playing out of position under Laurent Blanc (right) Cavani's agentClaudio Anelucci says his client is most likely to move to England or Spain this summer . He told Gazzetta dello Sport: 'Is Cavani on the market? At this point it's a little early to say. 'Edi is under contract at Paris Saint-Germain and there are several factors that come into play with respect to his future.' 'Once the situation is clarified there are several different scenarios given that players like him, at his level of maturity, are coveted by the biggest clubs in Europe. 'The market would seem to suggest Spain or England - we can't say at the present time that an Italian club could participate in the bidding for Cavani.'

After years of hoping he would rip opposition defences to shreds, Pep Guardiola has admitted he has to start trying to work out a way to stop Lionel Messi. On the prospect of facing the greatest player in Barcelona's history, Guardiola - the greatest coach the club has had - said: 'We will have to see what we can do in each of the two games and we will try to create the best defensive system possible to stop Messi. 'They are a wonderful team but so are we,' said the Bayern Munich boss. Pep Guardiola will be reintroduced to Barcelona in the Champions League semi-finals . The Bayern Munich coach must think of a way to stop the superb Lionel Messi next month . Guardiola goes back to Barcelona with the team now coached by Luis Enrique playing their best football since he left the club in 2012. 'It will be a very special game for me,' he said after the teams were drawn to face each other. 'It will also be special for Thiago [Alcantara] and for the rest of the coaching staff. I lived my whole life in Barcelona, it' s my home.' Guardiola nurtured Messi into the best player in the world while manager at the Nou Camp . Guardiola showed how much the club still means to him when alongside his father he watched them beat Manchester City in the last 16, cheering them on from the stands of the Nou Camp. He did little to hide his appreciation for Messi that night and admitted that the four-times Ballon d'Or winner could punish Bayern if they are as sloppy as they were in the first leg against Porto in the quarter-finals. They went down 3-1 before hammering the Portuguese outfit 6-1 in Bavaria. He said: 'If we make the same mistakes then the tie will be all over in Barcelona.'

I just viewed Jean Renoir's wonderful film, French Can Can. This 1955 masterpiece tells the story of Danglard, played by Jean Gabin, a theater owner who revives the forgotten art of the cancan dance in late 19th century Paris. The film is an extravagant and colorful celebration of the Moulin Rouge era, and captures the vivacity and decadence of its time. Renoir's direction is nothing short of pure genius, as he creates a dazzling spectacle of dance sequences combined with an engaging plot. The film is filled with both elaborate costumes and scenic designs, effectively immersing the viewer in the rich culture of the period. The performances by the ensemble cast, including Gabin, Francoise Arnoul, and Maria Felix, are equally impressive, filled with passionate intensity and commitment to their roles. Another standout aspect is the music, which will have you humming along to the infectious tunes long after the end credits roll. The film's centerpiece, the iconic cancan dance sequence, is a thrilling and perfectly choreographed piece that serves as a testament to the film's lasting impact on cinema history. In conclusion, French Can Can is a cinematic gem that showcases Renoir's incredible talent as a filmmaker. Its rich story, captivating characters, and stunning visuals make it an unforgettable film that should not be missed. Whether you're a fan of classic cinema or just looking for an entertaining and visually stunning movie, French Can Can is a must-see.

Headline: Celebrities Embrace Power of Pink in SpringSummer Collections Subhead: Holly Willoughby, Katherine Jenkins, and Samantha Cameron sport various shades of pink, symbolizing confidence, energy, and power. As the springsummer season arrives, celebrities are bringing their best fashion game with an unlikely power color - Pink. Holly Willoughby, Katherine Jenkins, and Samantha Cameron are among the celebrities seen wearing various shades of the color in recent events and photoshoots. This refreshing change in color palettes has left fashion enthusiasts eager to follow suit. According to fashion experts, wearing different hues of pink can elevate an outfit while commanding confidence, energy, and power. Springsummer collections for top designers are now featuring various shades of this vibrant color, from soft pastels to striking bubblegum, proving that pink is not reserved for the faint of heart. Holly Willoughby, popular television presenter and style icon, was recently spotted wearing a stunning pink dress paired with matching accessories while attending a special event. The ITV's This Morning star has never been shy to don vibrant colors, and her bold choice of pink truly showcased her confidence and power. Katherine Jenkins, the acclaimed Welsh mezzo-soprano, has also embraced the power of pink. Jenkins was recently seen wearing an elegant blush gown highlighting her grace and poise. The color not only enhanced her feminine presence but also mirrored the positive energy she exudes through her music. Samantha Cameron, wife of former British Prime Minister David Cameron and noted fashion entrepreneur, is no stranger to making a statement with her wardrobe choices. Recently, she was seen wearing an eye-catching pink dress that showcased her confidence in both the political and fashion arenas. As the founder of luxury fashion label Cefinn, it is no surprise that Cameron knows how to make a powerful statement with her clothing. It's clear that pink has a promising future in the springsummer fashion collections for 2021 and beyond. The combination of confidence, energy, and power that the color embodies has attracted the attention of many celebrities and fashion gurus alike. As more people seek to make a bold statement with their wardrobe, pink continues to outshine other colors in the spectrum and remains a symbol of strength and resilience in the ever-changing world of fashion.

A reduction in the amount of the cell adhesion components Dsg1 and Dsg2 in pancreatic tumors suggests that loss of these desmosomal proteins may play a role in pancreatic cancer invasion. Using in vitro degradation assays, both Dsg1 and Dsg2 could be readily proteolyzed by hK7, which is overexpressed in pancreatic adenocarcinomas. The enforced expression of hK7 in BxPC-3 cells that express significant amounts of Dsg2 resulted in a marked increase in the shedding of soluble Dsg2, which is consistent with the notion that aberrant expression of hK7 in pancreatic tumors may result in diminished cell-cell adhesion and facilitate tumor cell invasion.

This film has the language, the style and the attitude down ... plus greats rides from Occy (a world champ) and the great Jerry Lopez. John Philbin as Turtle has the surf pidgin down, and the surfing scenes are still the best ever. A true classic that can be seen many times. Nia Peeples is a babe, and Laird Hamilton shows the early stuff that has made him the world's number one extreme surfer.

While having six toes on the same foot would have once guaranteed you a place in a travelling circus, it seems polydactylism does have its bonuses in the sporting arena. Unbeaten boxer Danny Garcia, who defeated Amir Khan in four rounds in 2012, revealed he will carry an unusual advantage when he steps into the ring to face Lamont Peterson on Saturday. When asked by entertainment channel TMZ to reveal something embarrassing about himself, the US boxer explained he has an extra toe on his right foot before promptly removing his sock to show off his secret weapon. Danny Garcia (2nd left) is set to fight Lamont Peterson (2nd right) in a non-title fight on Saturday . Garcia (2nd right) poses with (L-R) Andy Lee, Peterson and Peter Quillin ahead of their New York showdown . Garcia and Lamont were all smiles as they faced each other in the kitchens ahead of their fight . 'That's why I'm never off balance and I've never been down,' he commented. The Puerto Rican-born fighter, who has a 29-0 (17 KOs) record and currently holds theRing Magazine, WBC and WBA (Super) Light Welterweight titles, insists his New York showdown with Peterson is important despite it being a non-title catchweight bout. Speaking to Sporting Life, the 27-year-old said:'It's a big fight and it's the fight that the fans wanted. We're going to give the fans a great night of boxing,' he said. The Puerto Rican-born fighter has revealed his special weapon, which has seen him never knocked down . The light welterweight champion stripped off his sock to show his six toes in an interview with TMZ . Garcia knocked out Rod Salka in his last fight to take his professional record to 29-0 with 17 KOs . Garcia walks away after putting Salka on the canvas and insists he will 'kick butt' against Peterson . 'I'm ready for whatever Peterson brings. If he tries to box then I'm going to go with that and if he wants to fight, I'll be ready. I'm not going to go in and just try to knock his head off, I'm going to be Danny Garcia. 'We have common opponents like [Amir] Khan and [Lucas Martin] Matthysse and we've had different results. They say styles make fights so those results don't matter. Well, my style is to kick his butt. 'I'd love to be fighting on the biggest stage in boxing against the Mayweather and Pacquiaos, but for now it's just about taking it one fight at a time, this is history in the making.' Garcia knocked out Amir Khan inside four rounds to unify the light welterweight division in 2012 .

Person1: Of course! Let me pull up your bill for Room 309. Just give me a moment. Person2: Sure, thank you. Person1: Here's your bill summary for your stay. The total amount is . Can you please verify if all of the charges are correct? Person2: Let me take a look. Yes, everything seems accurate. How can I make the payment? Person1: You can pay with cash, credit card, or debit card. Which method would you prefer? Person2: I will use my credit card. Person1: Great, please provide me with your credit card. Alright, your payment has been processed successfully. Thank you for staying with us, we hope you enjoyed your stay. Have a great day! Person2: Thank you! I had a pleasant stay. Have a nice day too!

This coming from an adult who happened to come across the first one expecting a movie aimed towards children and was surprised at the adult humor that was in Emperors New Groove. The character i liked most of all was Kronk, so i was thrilled when i heard of the sequel (sp) featuring non other than "Kronk."I just watched Kronk's New groove, it took me two days because i had to shut it off, i was so bored halfway through it. I finally watched the rest of it the next day and unfortunately the 2nd half was every bit as lame as the first.Being a Disney film, i was expecting to have some musical scenes, however this one was filled with them and they were not amusing. The great thing i found about Emperors New Groove was that it could be appreciated by a wide audience, from toddlers to adults. Kronks New Groove in all honesty did nothing for me nor my girlfriend and we both loved the first. It is really aimed towards young children, the comedy is pretty childish, the musical scenes are not very well done and the plot itself is extremely corny.Save yourself some money and rent this movie if possible because its definitely not worthy of a second viewing. I was extremely disappointed and shocked at how thrown together this film was. They actually managed to make a character (Kronk) not funny in this film, that is amazing in itself.Obviously every ones opinion differs but i am very easily amused, i usually enjoy sequels (sp) even when others discredit them, mostly because i loved the first so much i needed more of the characters and no matter how bad the plot was i would enjoy the film. I cannot say the same for this one, i never would have thought i would be turning it off half way through due to pure boredom.Buy at Own Risk.

Massachusetts Senator Slams Washington for Serving Special Interests Washington, D.C - The Massachusetts senator criticized the current political climate in Washington, stating that the political system caters to special interests and well-connected individuals, leaving out the rest of the nation from its decision-making process. In an interview with local reporters, the senator called for changes in Washington's corrupt political culture, asserting that voters deserve better representation. She was particularly critical of the Republican Party, saying that two declared GOP candidates had already disqualified themselves in her eyes. The senator did not name specific candidates, but her statement has raised concerns for some on the right. The senator believes that the majority of the American people are fed up with politics as usual and believe that the government serves the interests of a select few, rather than their constituents. She said, "It's time for a change in the way politics work 'inside the Beltway'. It's time for politicians to stand up for what's right and to put the interests of the American people first." She urged voters to educate themselves about the various political candidates and to demand political transparency from their elected officials. She also stressed the importance of campaign finance reform to reestablish a democracy that works for everyone, not just the elite few. "In order to tackle the status quo, we need politicians who are willing to put the interests of their constituents before their own political ambitions," the senator concluded. It remains unclear how this statement will affect the GOP candidates or the senator's own political prospects. However, her remarks have ignited a conversation on the role that special interests play in American politics and the need for systemic change in Washington.

A young accountant fell down a 70ft cliff to his death when he ran from a taxi to avoid paying the fare. Graduate Jacob Phillips, 23, plunged down the cliff when he leapt over a fence in the dark. Mr Phillips had caught the cab home after a night out with friends in December - but didn't have enough cash to pay for it. An inquest heard he ran from the driver, who gave chase at the seaside town of Penarth, South Wales. Cabbie Dave Sidaway told the inquest: 'I stopped because I couldn't see where I was going. I had no idea how much danger he was in.' Jacob Phillips, 23, was found dead at the end of the disused Northern Promenade, a rocky area at the base of the cliff . The university graduate had been out drinking in Cardiff before catching a taxi with friends Padraig Crowley and Rory Robinson. Cardiff Coroner's Court heard how the trio got out of the taxi to 'use an ATM' before making a run for it. 'The plan was to go to Penarth but we did not have enough money for the taxi - I ran off in one direction, Jacob went in another direction,' Mr Robinson told the inquest. 'Running away from the taxi was a stupid thing to do.' Mr Phillips, of Reading, Berks, was discovered the next day on the rocky beach by a dog walker. Paramedics arrived at the scene after his body was discovered in the morning by a dog walker . A long way down: Mr Phillips fell down this cliff after a night out. Tthe taxi driver said he would not have left him if he knew where they were . Recording a verdict of accidental death, coroner Andrew Barkley said: 'It is likely that he became disorientated and there is no evidence that he knew where he was at the time. 'There is no way he could have known the danger that lay in front of him. The following day with the benefit of light it was clear the danger he faced by the sheer drop off the cliff just yards beyond the fence.' Mr Phillips worked for Pretty Green, the clothing label run by Oasis star Liam Gallagher. He had grown up in Barry, South Wales, before studying accountancy at the University of Birmingham. The inquest heard that he had returned to Wales for Christmas and had been staying with his mother in the upmarket Cowbridge area. Mr Phillips had planned to stay at a friend's house but he and his friends didn't have enough money to complete the journey, so decided to trick the driver by 'dodging' the fare. Mr Phillips ran off into the 'pitch black' and fell down a cliff at the end of the disused Northern Promenade - also called The Dardanelles. Police search the scene at the bottom of the cliff where his body was discovered .

Spoiler Ahead I suppose that you shouldn't expect much of a made for TV movie, but this one was especially bad. The plot was a good idea, but badly done, the acting wasn't especially good. The storyline revolved around a young woman discovering her hidden supernatural powers in a small town. However, the execution was painful to watch. The dialogue was awkward and forced, making the character interactions cringe-worthy. The special effects were subpar, not aiding in the already weak storyline. Instead of adding excitement to the action scenes, the effects seemed to only serve as a distraction. The movie had potential for thrilling and suspenseful moments, but ultimately fell flat. The characters were underdeveloped and lacked depth, leading to audiences having a hard time connecting with their struggles. Instead of being invested in the story, viewers found themselves not caring about the outcome or rooting for any of the characters. It was truly disappointing considering the potential in the plot. The acting left a lot to be desired, with actors seemingly overacting or underacting in every scene. It felt like watching a high school play rather than a professionally produced movie. Their performances were unconvincing, failing to add any emotional weight to the story. Overall, this made for TV movie had potential but was completely let down by its poor execution, acting, and special effects. It is a prime example of a good idea gone bad and serves as a lesson in the importance of proper character development and engaging storytelling. Save yourself the time and pass on this one.

Police have dramatically arrested a 27-year-old man who tried to flee the area after officers found a woman's body in the boot of the car he was driving. The man ran into bushland after police stopped a blue Hyundai Getz car on the Bermagui to Tathra Road in the Bega Valley, on the far south coast of NSW, just after 8.30pm on Wednesday. But on Thursday evening 7 News captured the moment when he was finally arrested by police. Officers were shown chasing the man into bushland and over a fence before pouncing on him. Scroll down for video . A police officer grabs the man who had been on the run over night after a woman's body had been found in his car . 'Show me your hands!' the arresting police officer screamed at the man . The man meekly does as he is told before being taken away by police . 'Show me your hands!' the arresting police officer screamed at the man. The man did as he was told and gave himself up without a struggle. He was then taken away in a police van. Detective Superintendent Peter O'Brien said he could not yet release the name of the victim. However, it has been confirmed police are investigating whether the body is that of missing Canberra woman Daniella D'Addario, 35. Ms D'Addario was reported missing by concerned family members on Monday after disappearing along with her boyfriend Josaia (Joey) Vosikata, 27. Daniella D'Addario (right) was reported missing on Monday along with her boyfriend Josaia (Joey) Vosikata (left) The couple were believed to have been staying in the Bermagui area after last being seen on Sunday. Detective Acting Sergeant Jason Taylor previously described her car saying: 'They may have been travelling in Daniella's car which was a silver or light blue Hyundai Getz.' Her vehicle's ACT registration is YEF19M. Ms D'Addario was a teacher at Canberra High School in 2009 and her former students have begun commenting about her disappearance on Facebook. One wrote: 'This is too sad.' Another added: 'I saw her at kmart not long ago.' Police have not yet identified the woman's body but are investigating whether it could missing Canberra woman Daniella D'Addario . On Thursday morning NSW Police confirmed: 'A crime scene has been established at the car, and a perimeter has been set up as police search for the man. 'Investigations into the incident are continuing. Initial investigations suggest the man and woman were known to each other.' Police said they are hoping to speak with a man who may be able to assist with inquiries. He is described as being of Pacific IslanderMaori appearance, in his late 20s, with an athletic build. He was last seen wearing dark clothing. 'Police advise members of the public who see the man or know his whereabouts not to approach him, but to contact Triple 0 immediately,' a statement said.

Kevin Pietersen has hinted the first chapter of his county comeback could be streamed live to fans. The divisive batsman has re-signed for Surrey this summer in an attempt to win an unlikely England recall, having been thrown an apparent lifeline by incoming ECB chairman Colin Graves. He has not played in the LV County Championship since 2013 but is set to start the season with the Brown Caps in the hope of turning the selectors' heads and reversing last year's controversial sacking. Kevin Pietersen will step up his attempts to earn an England recall when he starts batting on Monday . The 34-year-old Pietersen wants to end his England absence that started after the 2013-14 Ashes whitewash . Pietersen (right) rejoined Surrey after incoming ECB chairman Colin Graves said domestic form would help . The 34-year-old has indicated that his campaign will start with a three-day warm-up against Oxford MCCU on April 12 and he is due to return to the nets on Monday. Pietersen announced that to his 2.3 million Twitter followers on Easter Sunday, raising the prospect of using the social network's new broadcast app, Periscope, to showcase his session in real time. He wrote: 'Starting to bat tomorrow...might periscopeco it, so all of you can watch it Live see how I get on. Should I? comeback'. Quite how Pietersen's 'comeback' will pan out in the long term is unclear. He clearly feels Graves' words are encouragement enough of a Test recall but after so many bitter recriminations - and one dazzlingly indiscreet autobiography - there are still many bridges to build. His decision to hit the county trail, so long a bete noire in his career, at least offers the platform for him to nudge both selectorial and public opinion from close quarters. But when England flew to the West Indies on Thursday ahead of the forthcoming Test series, the messages were thoroughly mixed. Captain Alastair Cook, who was not given a glittering write-up in the Pietersen's book, largely absolved himself from the decision-making process, insisting it would be taken by Graves, managing director of England cricket Paul Downton and chief executive Tom Harrison. Coach Peter Moores was less ambiguous. Moores was sacked from his first stint in charge in 2008, partially at the behest of Pietersen, whose intervention also cost him the captaincy. Incoming ECB chairman Graves advised that signing for a domestic side would help Pietersen's cause . Alastair Cook (left) was coy on Pietersen's chances of a recall but Peter Moores said he 'isn't on the radar' Moores was previously dismissed as England coach at the behest of Pietersen when he was captain . He was then belittled as a nagging 'woodpecker' in the the batsman's memoir and reconciliation between the two men would appear a stretch. Asked at Gatwick about the situation, Moores said: 'From my point of view, Kevin isn't on the radar.' He would, therefore, seem an unlikely viewer of Pietersen's Periscope net session.

Person1: There are so many environmental problems in the world today. Do you think we can really solve them all or will destroy the world? Person2: I hope that world leaders can get together and agree on a plan for action, but I doubt it'll happen before it's too late. Person1: We need to solve the problem of air pollution before we destroy the atmosphere. There's lots of clean, modern technology, but companies in developed countries say it's expensive. Developing countries put more emphasis on economic development than on environmental protection. Person2: Everyone is looking at the issue in the short term, rather than the long term. It's the same with the destruction of the rainforests. Countries and companies just want the wood. They're not thinking about the long-term damage to the forests. We should also remember that the forests are an important natural habitat for thousands of species of animal and plant life. Person1: In other parts of the world, especially in Africa, there is a problem with desertification. Climate change and over-farming are causing farmland to turn into desert. In means that people cannot grow enough food. Person2: It also means that people sometimes fight over the farmland that remains. Damaging the environment actually leads to conflict between people. Person1: Have you ever thought about joining an organization committed to protecting the environment? You could get involved with projects to improve the environment. Person2: I think I'd like to do that. I could take the things I learn here back to my country when I have finished my studies.

Malia Obama Learns to Drive from Secret Service Agents In a recent interview with talk-show host Rachael Ray, former First Lady Michelle Obama revealed that her daughter Malia was taught to drive by Secret Service agents. Mrs. Obama shared that she hasn't driven herself in seven or eight years and that allowing Malia to drive gives her a sense of normalcy, helping her feel more like her friends who are also driving. The former First Lady was on Rachael Ray's talk show to discuss various topics, including her new book, "Becoming," and life after the White House. One light-hearted moment in the conversation occurred when Mrs. Obama told Ray about how her eldest daughter, Malia, learned to drive. The process of teaching Malia to drive understandably involved a few unique challenges, given the family's high profile. Michelle explained that in an effort to maintain some normalcy in her daughter's life, Secret Service agents had stepped in to teach her how to drive. "I haven't driven in about seven or eight years because, obviously, we had drivers in the White House," Mrs. Obama said, adding that driving had always been a pleasurable pastime for her. When it came to teaching Malia to drive, Michelle said that she wasn't too concerned about her daughter's safety, thanks to the Secret Service agents' expert instruction. "My kids had the opportunity to learn from some of the best drivers in the world," she proudly stated. Michelle also talked about how important it was for Malia to have the experience of driving, saying that it helped her feel like a normal teenager. "It's something that every teenager looks forward to, getting that first driver's license. It's a sense of freedom and independence, and we wanted Malia to have that experience despite our unique circumstances." Malia was quick to embrace her newfound freedom, with Mrs. Obama sharing a story about her daughter sneaking out to drive around the neighborhood in their new car. "I think she was just so excited to be able to drive that she couldn't help herself," she joked, expressing appreciation for the prudence and discretion of the Secret Service during such moments. Michelle Obama's candid conversation with Rachael Ray offered a unique glimpse into the lives of the former FirstFamily, particularly how they've worked to maintain a sense of normalcy for their children. Malia's driving lessons with the Secret Service agents demonstrate that even amid extraordinary circumstances, the Obamas continue to prioritize their daughters' well-being and happiness.

After a couple years of searching for the Humphrey Bogart film, "Two Against the World," it unexpectedly showed up as a TCM offering under the title "One Fatal Hour," a First National film from 1936. The moment the opening credits rolled with Bogart's name, my heart raced with anticipation. Thankfully, the film did not disappoint. "One Fatal Hour" showcases Bogart as a charming and crafty socialite named Sherry Scott, who undertakes the challenge of managing a struggling radio station. The film delves into the world of the 1930s radio business while serving as a commentary on sensationalist journalism, which resonates even today. The narrative revolves around a death row inmate who is about to be executed and the lengths to which the radio station goes to boost its ratings by exploiting the situation. Bogart's performance is gripping yet nuanced, as he works diligently to save the radio station while navigating both the professional and personal pitfalls in his life. The supporting cast members, including Beverly Roberts as Alma Ross and Linda Perry as Jerry Crane, deliver outstanding performances and add depth to the overall storyline. "One Fatal Hour" is a riveting snapshot of a bygone era, and its message about the dangers of sensationalism and unscrupulous journalism remains pertinent to our times. The film's tight pacing, engaging script, and stellar performances make it a forgotten gem that Bogart fans and classic movie lovers alike should not miss. While the film may have gone under the radar for several years, its rediscovery is a testament to the timeless quality of good storytelling and superb acting. Overall, "One Fatal Hour" is a thrilling rollercoaster ride that will equally delight and challenge audiences.

Britain's Adam Peaty has broken the men's 100 metres breast stroke world record with a time of 57.92 seconds at the London Aquatic Centre. The 20-year-old from Uttoxeter's gold-winning time on Friday beat the previous record of 58.46 set by South African Cameron van der Burgh in the same venue at the 2012 Olympics. A tweet from British Swimming's account read: 'WORLD RECORD time for adam-peaty he hits the wall in 57.92!!!!' British swimmer Adam Peaty is all smiles after setting a new world record for the 100m breast stroke . His time of 57.92 seconds has beaten the previous record of 58.46 set by Cameron van der Burgh in 2012 . Peaty has spoken of his delight that his hard work and training have paid off and is thrilled with the win . After becoming the first man in history to break through the 58-second barrier in the discipline, Peaty said: 'I can't believe it, coming in earlier I thought I could get a really good time, maybe a 58.5. 'Before that race I just thought I've done all the training for a 57, and it all paid off in the end. 'The crowd were great and they really carried me home at the end, because that was a hell of a pain train. There must be something in that lane four when it really matters.' Scotland's Ross Murdoch fought hard but was left trailing in Peaty's wake with a time of 59.12 - still inside the World Championship qualification standard - while James Wilby of Loughborough took bronze with a 1:00.31. Ben Proud topped the podium in the men's 50m freestyle by coming home in 21.99, with his fellow Plymouth swimmer Thomas Fannon taking silver in 22.48 from Andrew Weatheritt (22.50). In the women's competition, Fran Halsall stormed to victory in the open 50m freestyle. The 25-year-old claimed her 10th consecutive title with a time of 24.37 and said afterwards: 'It's pretty good to be able to come in 10 years in a row and be the best in Britain. 'I didn't have the ideal preparation coming into this meet, I got sent home from the World Championships in December and it took a lot longer than expected to get back into full training. 'Last year I went a 24.5 at this meet then on to a 23.9 in the summer, so to come here and already be two tenths up on that is a great sign.' Lauren Quigley of Stockport Metro hit 25.22 for silver ahead of Rebecca Guy, who clocked in at 25.49. In the morning Rachael Kelly had defended her British Championship title with a time of 57.72 in the open 100m butterfly final. Jemma Lowe (58.07) collected silver with Bath team-mate Siobhan-Marie O'Connor third thanks to a 58.37. (Left to right): Thomas Fannon, Ben Proud and Andrew Weatheritt poses with their medals on the podium .

The idea behind Dead Silence is great: a zombie outbreak takes place during an edgy paranoia radio talk show. This film turns the concept of a traditional horror movie on its head by placing the story in a seemingly innocuous setting. The radio host, brilliantly portrayed by Jack Clark, keeps his listeners gripped as they share tales of conspiracy theories, mysterious happenings, and general paranoia. Little does he know that one of their calls will lead to unspeakable horror. As the chilling night unfolds, the ominous atmosphere builds tension, making the audience feel as though they are in the radio station alongside the host. The dialogue is witty and engaging, and the characters - ranging from the passionate conspiracy theorist to the casual listener - are charming and relatable. The cinematography effectively uses shadows and light contrasts to create a dark, claustrophobic environment which only heightens the fear factor. The true highlight of Dead Silence is its approach to the zombie outbreak. Unlike typical zombie movies, the undead in this film are just as terrifying in their subtlety. Instead of an over-the-top gore fest, Dead Silence expertly utilizes suspense and psychological fear, which only serves to heighten the dread. The zombies are the menacing presence that you know are creeping closer, even when they're not on the screen. The terror grips you as the characters realize the horrifying reality of the situation and must decide whether to fight or flee. The performances are strong across the board, with Jack Clark stealing the show as the initially skeptical radio host who must grapple with the horrifying situation. He brings both humor and raw emotion to his role, making his character easy to root for. The supporting actors are also commendable, each adding depth to their roles and delivering a well-rounded ensemble performance. While there are moments when the pacing could have been tightened and a few minor plot holes are noticeable, overall, Dead Silence proves to be a refreshing take on the zombie genre, making it a must-watch for horror fans. The film effectively weaves together elements of suspense, fear, and dark humor without going overboard, leaving viewers on the edge of their seats until the final, heart-stopping scene. In conclusion, Dead Silence takes an intriguing concept and delivers a thrilling, chilling, and utterly entertaining movie experience. If you're a fan of the zombie genre, or even just in the mood for a good, spine-tingling scare, this film is definitely worth your time. Be prepared to leave the lights on and double-check your doors after watching!

Paris Saint-Germain manager Laurent Blanc admitted that Barcelona were superior to his side 'in virtually every department' as he saw his team slump to a 3-1 defeat in the first leg of the quarter-final at the Parc des Princes. An early strike from Neymar and second-half brace from Luis Suarez sealed victory for Barcelona and placed the Catalan outfit into a commanding position ahead of the return at the Nou Camp on Tuesday. Blanc admitted his side felt the absence of the suspended Marco Verratti and Zlatan Ibrahimovic, while PSG were also unable to start with David Luiz and saw Thiago Silva hobble off in the early stages. Luis Suarez eases past David Luiz en route to scoring his second goal of the Champions League tie . Gerard Pique leads the celebrations after Barcelona secured a 3-1 victory in Paris on Wednesday night . 'I'm not going to make excuses about us being depleted,' said Blanc. 'I'm not doing that. We put a team out there, but we were dominated by Barcelona. 'It's only six days until the second leg, with a league game in between, so it's a 'short week' for people to recover. I think Barcelona were fitter than us. We had players who weren't at 100 per cent, and also a lot of absentees, but that should have been a motivation for us. We never controlled the ball well enough, and Barca were better than us in virtually every department. 'We will have the suspended players back next week, and that is an incentive. We'll try and put on a better show than we did tonight. They were better than us tonight and scored three goals. We'll try and show a different PSG at Barcelona next week. Hopefully we will achieve a different result.' Laurent Blanc made no excuses for his side as they now face elimination from the Champions League . David Luiz, who started the game from the substitutes' bench, endured a night to forget in the French capital . In the end, the Frenchman was relieved to escape only 3-1 down. 'It didn't end up as bad as it might have done, but the players are very disappointed with the way it went,' he said. 'We gave the impression we gave Barcelona the kind of game they wanted to pay. They made life difficult for us on the counter-attack and have players who can be very dangerous.' Barcelona manager Luis Enrique was delighted with his side's showing and reserved special praise for Suarez. 'Suarez is special in his own way,' Enrique said, 'Look at the goals he scored for Ajax and Liverpool. He is very strong and finishes so well. But it wasn't just about Luis Suarez tonight. We were superb in defence, midfield and attack.'

The story is: a turn-of-the-century troupe of actors, along with producers and theatre-owners, have very complicated relationships. This movie, set against the rich and colorful backdrop of the early 1900s, crafts a powerful tale of love, betrayal, and passion that is irresistibly captivating. The ensemble cast is simply phenomenal, each actor delivering powerful performances that breathe life into their complex characters. It's a true testament to their talent that they are able to create such depth and nuance in the midst of a convoluted web of relationships. As the story unfolds, the audience becomes more and more invested in the characters as they navigate the tumultuous terrain of the theatre world. Visually, the movie is a veritable feast for the eyes, with luscious period costumes, and lavish sets transporting the audience back to the turn of the century. The director artfully utilizes the rich visuals to envelop the viewer in an authentic sense of time and place. Combined with the sumptuous cinematography, the movie is a work of art that is as sumptuous as it is gripping. The script is tight and engaging, with razor-sharp dialogue that perfectly captures the dramatic flair of the era. As the intricate relationships unfold throughout the movie, the audience becomes a witness to the heartaches and triumphs of the characters as they struggle for recognition and love in an unforgiving world. In conclusion, this movie is a riveting exploration of the complexities of human relationships set against the backdrop of an extraordinary time in theatrical history. With its stellar cast, exquisite visuals, and engaging script, it is a must-see film that will leave audiences captivated and hungry for more.

In brain blood vessels the chemical identity of the endothelium-derived relaxing factor mediating the action of acetylcholine is unknown, but this relaxing factor does not appear to be nitric oxide. If the mediator contains nitric oxide, as is probably the case, the means by which it activates vascular guanylate cyclase andor produces dilation is unknown. Since this relaxing factor inhibits platelet adhesionaggregation in cerebral vessels as well as relaxing these vessels, the chemical identification of this relaxing factor and the elucidation of its mode of action are extremely important to our understanding and control of cerebrovascular phenomena in health and disease.

Dallas Attorney's 'Feces Prank' Backfires, Leaves Granddaughter in Tears Randy Johnston, a 68-year-old attorney from Dallas, Texas, thought it would be amusing to place two fake feces on his granddaughters' beds as a prank. His son captured the entire incident on video, but things took an unexpected turn as the prank left Johnston's six-year-old granddaughter Porter crying in horror. Johnston revealed to the Daily Mail Online that the idea behind the prank was to get his revenge for one his granddaughters pulled on him earlier in the day. The prank ultimately ended up being a disaster, with little Porter left inconsolable. While some may find amusement in such practical jokes, it is worth remembering that children may react differently to what adults perceive as funny. Johnston learned this lesson firsthand and will likely think twice before staging another revenge prank on his granddaughters.

Brazilian Teams on High Alert as Dengue Fever Outbreak Spreads Throughout Top Clubs The Brazilian football league and its teams are scrambling to deal with a sudden outbreak of dengue fever that has affected some of the country's top clubs, raising concerns over the health of players and fans in the region. Dengue fever, a mosquito-borne disease, has already seen three players - including Corinthians striker Paolo Guerrero - diagnosed. The Peruvian forward is reportedly recovering well, but until now, Guerrero has been unable to train with his team or take part in matches. His absence is a significant blow for Corinthians, who have been suffering from irregular football results in the last couple of months. Medical teams across Brazil have been put on high alert due to the increasing spread of the disease, especially in Sao Paulo, where 43,000 people have been affected by the disease in the first quarter of the year. In total, there have been 224,000 confirmed cases of dengue fever in Brazil in 2021, a worrying increase from the 170,000 in 2020. Apart from Guerrero, players from Fluminense and Athletico Paranaense have also been diagnosed with dengue fever. Fluminense defender Fernando Pacheco and Athletico Paranaense winger Nikao are reportedly recovering well, but their return to the pitch remains uncertain. The outbreak of the fever has sparked fear among clubs, forcing players, coaching staff and fans to take extra precautions to avoid the proliferation of the Aedes aegypti mosquito, which is the primary vector for the dengue virus. Medical practitioners are also monitoring the players' health closely, and providing guidelines and assistance to help mitigate the outbreak. The clubs, stadiums, and practice facilities are taking action to combat the outbreak, by implementing mosquito-repellent measures and educating staff and fans about dengue fever. This includes distributing pamphlets, dispensing insect repellent to players and fans, and making concerted efforts to eradicate any standing water that acts as mosquito breeding grounds on and around club premises. Despite the best efforts of the clubs, there remains a concern that the outbreak may force changes to the upcoming fixture schedule, with the potential for match delays and even cancellations arising due to the ongoing health crisis. Brazil is not the only country where dengue fever has impacted football; the disease had previously jeopardized the 2018 World Cup qualifying match between Nigeria and Tahiti. With many Brazilian clubs set to participate in international competitions soon, officials are hoping to contain the outbreak quickly to avoid a disruption in the international football calendar. The spread of dengue fever serves as an unwelcome reminder of another public health crisis that has impacted football globally - the COVID-19 pandemic. Brazilian football, much like the rest of the world, is currently recovering from the devastating impact of the pandemic on the sport and national economy. With the dengue fever outbreak adding to an already challenging situation, clubs, players, and fans are eagerly hoping for a swift resolution.

Liana Barrientos faces multiple charges after marrying 10 men in immigration scam. Liana Barrientos, a 39-year-old woman from the Bronx, was re-arrested after a court appearance for alleged fare beating. Prosecutors say that Barrientos had married ten men in a sophisticated immigration scam. She pleaded not guilty to misdemeanor charges on Friday. According to prosecutors, Barrientos had married ten men from various countries between 1999 and 2010, collecting fees in exchange for helping the men to obtain legal US residency. Most of the marriages were to men from "red-flagged" countries that have large populations of individuals who pose national security or public safety risks, prosecutors said. In some instances, Barrientos had two husbands at once and married multiple times in a short period. For example, she married her seventh husband in February 2002 and her eighth husband just over two weeks later. In all, she married men from Egypt, Turkey, Georgia, Pakistan, Mali, and Bangladesh. The scam was brought to the attention of authorities in February 2010 when Department of Homeland Security agents arrested a man from the Bronx who was attempting to board a plane to Yemen on a US passport obtained through a fraudulent marriage to Barrientos. She was originally arrested in 2013 for falsifying documents but was released; however, she never showed up for her court date. This time, the alleged scammer was arrested outside the Bronx Supreme Court for fare evasion. Investigators believe they have recovered over 50,000 in payments obtained from foreign immigrants by Barrientos. On Friday, Barrientos appeared for her court-ordered mental health examination, following a judge's order in June for psychiatric evaluation. Her attorney argued that Barrientos suffered from serious mental health issues and had a history of substance abuse. The judge ordered further evaluations to determine whether she could stand trial. If convicted on the felony charges related to the immigration scam, Barrientos could face significant fines and imprisonment. Meanwhile, authorities continue to investigate the extent of the scam and stated that further arrests could be made.

A 10-year-old boy has been rushed to hospital after being shot in the stomach by a person attempting to kill an aggressive dog. Danel Hall Jr was walking down the street in Centre Point, Alabama, when a man was chased by a neighbourhood dog. A third person suddenly starting shooting at the animal, but stray bullets hit Danel in the stomach and the second pedestrian in the buttocks, it was claimed. Danel Hall (pictured), 10, was shot in the stomach by a stray bullet intended for an aggressive dog . Police from Jefferson County swooped on the scene of the shooting just after 1pm yesterday . Deputies from Jefferson Country sheriff's office quickly arrived at the scene - just after 1pm yesterday - to find Danel in agony. The bullet had narrowly missed his liver and he was rushed to hospital where he underwent emergency surgery to save his life. Tom Henderson, Centre Point's mayor, said the unknown gunman had been attempting to shoot the aggressive dog, but his bullets instead hit Danel and the second man. He told AL.com: 'There shouldn't be any guns being shot in that incident.' Mary Brooks, Danel's great aunt, said she rushed home from work when she was told about the shooting. 'I can't even tell you what went through my mind,' she said. 'I prayed all the way that he'd be alright. And that's all that matters.' Trayvon Smith, the dog's owner and a neighbour of Danel's family, denied accusations he had been the one shooting. He told WTVM that he had no guns, adding that he was very sorry for the boy. 'Everybody pray for that little boy, he needs as much prayers as he can get.' Police are continuing to look for the person who fired the shots, and anyone with information about the incident can contact the Jefferson County Sheriff's Office at . The shooting occurred on 1st Street, NW, Centre Point, Alabama (pictured) about 1pm yesterday afternoon .

Yes, the rupture type can significantly influence the outcome for patients with a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm (rAAA). There are two main types of ruptures: contained ruptures and free ruptures. Contained rupture: In this type, the leaking blood is contained within the surrounding tissue, leading to a more stable hemodynamic situation. Patients with a contained rupture have better chances of survival, with a higher likelihood of reaching the hospital and undergoing successful emergency surgery. Free rupture: In this type, the blood freely escapes into the abdominal cavity, leading to sudden and severe internal bleeding. This can quickly lead to hemodynamic instability, shock, and death. Patients with free ruptures have a much worse prognosis, with a significant number of individuals dying before reaching the hospital. In addition to the type of rupture, several other factors can also influence outcomes for rAAA patients. This includes factors such as patient age, overall health, comorbidities, the size of the aneurysm, extent of rupture, the time from rupture to treatment, and the quality of surgical and medical management.

Poundland has been been forced to pull decorative plastic Easter Eggs from their shelves over fears children may choke - because they look like Cadbury Mini Eggs. Trading Standards officials in Buckinghamshire and Surrey raised the alarm over the Chinese made decorations, as they were 'likely to contravene food imitation safety rules'. The eggs have now been withdrawn nationwide ahead of the Easter break. Scroll down for video . Poundland has been been forced to pull decorative plastic Easter Eggs from their shelves over fears they may choke - because they look like Cadbury Mini Eggs (pictured is the Poundland version) The eggs bear a striking similarity to the sugar-coated chocolate treats with a brown 'speckle' designed to make it look like a quail's egg (Cadbury Mini Eggs are pictured) The eggs bear a striking similarity to the sugar-coated chocolate treats with a brown 'speckle' designed to make it look like a quail's egg. Steve Playle, Investigations and Enforcement Manager at Buckinghamshire and Surrey Trading Standards, said: 'These products could very easily be mistaken for Cadbury Mini Eggs by young children and swallowed leading to dire consequences. A real Cadbury mini egg (left) is seen against a decorative plastic egg from Poundland . Steve Playle, Investigations and Enforcement Manager at Buckinghamshire and Surrey Trading Standards, said: 'These products could very easily be mistaken for Cadbury Mini Eggs by young children and swallowed leading to dire consequences' (Poundland version pictured) 'They could be particularly difficult to remove if lodged in a child's throat because they are made of polystyrene and could mould to the shape of their airway making them difficult to remove in an emergency. 'We welcome the actions of Poundland in taking a potentially dangerous product off the shelves and would urge any parent who has already purchased a pack to keep it away from children. 'Parents should also be wary of similar products being offered for sale over the Easter period at other stores or online.'

Yes, methylation-sensitive linking libraries (MSLLs) can enhance gene-enriched sequencing of complex genomes and map DNA methylation domains. MSLLs are a method for generating reduced representation bisulfite sequencing (RRBS) libraries, which allow for the targeted enrichment of CpG-rich regions in the genome. This method can improve the efficiency of gene-enriched sequencing in complex genomes by specifically targeting regions of interest, allowing for better resolution and coverage of biologically significant regions like gene promoters and regulatory elements. Additionally, since MSLLs incorporate bisulfite treatment during library preparation, they can also provide information on DNA methylation at single-nucleotide resolution. By incorporating this information, researchers can gain insights into epigenetic regulation and potentially identify methylation domains, which can lead to better understanding of gene regulation and genomic stability in complex genomes. In summary, MSLLs provide a powerful tool to enhance gene-enriched sequencing of complex genomes and provide valuable information on DNA methylation, helping to advance our understanding of epigenetic regulation in various organisms and biological processes.

71-year-old man trapped in car seat, family captures hilarious moment on video A 71-year-old man from Portland, Clint Chadbourne, became an overnight sensation after a video of him trapped in a car seat was posted online by his family. The video quickly went viral, accumulating thousands of views and leaving the internet in stitches. The incident occurred when Clint was on his way home with his family. His wife Bonnie and daughter Kelly were also in the car and decided to capture the hilarious moment on camera. In the video, Clint is seen struggling to free himself from the confines of what appears to be a child's car seat. Remarkably, Clint did not panic despite being trapped in the seat, but instead became increasingly agitated as his family's laughter continued to grow. The Chadbournes can be heard in the video relentlessly teasing Clint, with one family member saying, "I've seen it all now - you and a car seat." Eventually, the family was able to free Clint from his predicament, and he made light of the situation with a joke. He told his family, "I'm going on a diet." After the ordeal was over, the Chadbournes decided to share their hilarious car seat adventure with friends and family on Facebook. Little did they know that the video would become an instant hit and give Clint his 15 minutes of fame. While the family had found the situation comical, they never expected it to go viral. Facebook users were quick to share the video, praising Clint for his refreshing sense of humor and positive attitude despite being trapped. Many found the incident relatable and something they or a family member had experienced in their own lives. The Chadbourne family is grateful for the outpouring of well-wishes and laughter from viewers around the world, and Clint is reportedly doing just fine after his car seat entrapment. Though it's unclear how he got stuck in the first place, one thing is for certain - the Chadbournes won't be forgetting this road trip anytime soon.

Date: April 15th, 2021 By: [Author name] MOSCOW - In a recent interview, Oleg Maidanovich, the commander of the Russian Space Command, accused an unnamed country of hiding spy satellites in space junk to avoid detection. The comments were made during a documentary that aired on April 12th, the anniversary of Yuri Gagarin's historic first spaceflight in 1961. In the film, Maidanovich provided no evidence for his claim, nor did he name the country that he believes is behind the ruse. However, he expressed concern that such an act would compromise global security and space traffic management. "Someone is hiding satellites in what seems like space junk, but these satellites can perform specific tasks," Maidanovich said. "These satellites are not for research or exploration purposes - they are for military purposes." The commander's remarks have sparked international interest as countries continue to expand their presence in outer space. The claim comes amid growing concerns over the increasing amount of space debris orbiting the Earth. According to the European Space Agency (ESA), there are more than 34,000 objects larger than 10 cm in size currently orbiting Earth at high speeds, posing a potential hazard to satellites and spacecraft. Such a statement from a high-ranking Russian military official raises questions about the possibility of a new space arms race, and adds further evidence to the argument that space is becoming an increasingly contested and militarized domain. Satellite warfare has already become an integral part of many nations' military strategies. In 2019, India successfully tested an anti-satellite missile, while the United States established its Space Force as a new branch of the military in the same year. Despite the ongoing militarization of space, the international community has made efforts to maintain a cooperative environment through initiatives such as the United Nations Committee on the Peaceful Uses of Outer Space. These global efforts, however, could be threatened by growing distrust and accusations of covert activities, like the one made by Maidanovich. Experts argue that countries should engage in a multilateral dialogue in order to develop framework agreements and international norms regarding outer space activities. Without such efforts, the potential for conflict and the likelihood of accidental collisions in space could rapidly increase. As of now, it remains unclear if Maidanovich's accusations will be investigated further or whether any evidence will be made public. The documentary's release on the anniversary of Gagarin's first space flight serves as a reminder of both the rapid advancement and the increasingly precarious nature of human activities in space.

Yes, old divergences in boreal birds can support the hypothesis that these species could have survived through the Ice Ages. Boreal birds typically inhabit the cold, coniferous forest habitats that were present during the ice ages. Genetic studies showing deep divergence between different populations or lineages of these birds can provide evidence for long-term survival and adaptation to these conditions. During the Ice Ages, boreal forests were able to persist in specific refugia, which were areas of suitable habitat that remained ice-free. Boreal bird populations that survived in these refugia could have been isolated from other populations, resulting in genetic divergence over time. Evidence of this divergence supports the idea that these bird populations were able to survive the harsh conditions of the Ice Ages. However, it is essential to consider that old genetic divergences are not definitive proof of long-term survival through the Ice Ages. Other factors, such as changes in habitat or competition with other species, could also play a role in shaping genetic variation in these bird populations. Further research, including understanding more about the specific adaptations that these birds possess that allow them to survive in cold environments, would be needed to support this hypothesis conclusively.

Yes, a Gossypium BAC (Bacterial Artificial Chromosome) clone can contain key repeat components that distinguish sub-genomes of allotetraploid cottons. Allotetraploid cottons, like Gossypium hirsutum and Gossypium barbadense, have two distinct sub-genomes (A and D) due to hybridization between diploid A-genome and D-genome ancestors. These sub-genomes can have differences in their repetitive elements, such as transposons (mobile genetic elements) and other sequence repeats. BAC clones are large DNA fragments containing individual genes or gene regions that are stably maintained in bacterial cells. These clones can be used to study specific genes or genomic regions in detail. By analyzing BAC clones derived from different sub-genomes in allotetraploid cottons, researchers can identify and characterize the repeat components that distinguish the A and D sub-genomes. This information can help improve our understanding of the evolutionary history, genome organization, and functional divergence of allotetraploid cotton species.

I wasn't expecting a great deal from this film, so I was pleasantly surprised when I watched it and found it to be most noteworthy. The plot was engaging and presented unexpected twists and turns that kept me on the edge of my seat. The acting was superb, with each actor truly immersing themselves in their respective roles, bringing to life the complexity and relatability of their characters. What truly sets this film apart was its stunning visuals and cinematography, creating a world that felt authentic and yet other-worldly. Additionally, the score was hauntingly beautiful, elevating the emotional resonance of the narrative without overpowering the action on screen. The film manages to tackle important social issues with grace and sensitivity, never veering into preachy territory and keeping the focus on the humanity of its characters. In the end, the movie delivered a powerful and moving experience that left me thinking long after the credits rolled. Don't let any preconceived notions hold you back from watching this gem of a film. It's not just worth your time - it demands it.

We have shown that particular non-digestible dietary carbohydrates have enormous potential for modifying the gut microbiota, but these modifications occur at the level of individual strains and species and are not easily predicted a priori. Furthermore, the gut environment, especially pH, plays a key role in determining the outcome of interspecies competition. This makes it crucial to put greater effort into identifying the range of bacteria that may be stimulated by a given prebiotic approach. Both for reasons of efficacy and of safety, the development of prebiotics intended to benefit human health has to take account of the highly individual species profiles that may result.

Yes, holoparasitic Rafflesiaceae are known for possessing highly reduced endophytes, meaning they have lost many features of typical plants, such as leaves, roots, and chlorophyll, as they completely rely on their hosts for nutrition. Despite their reduced structure, they give rise to the world's largest flowers, such as Rafflesia arnoldii, which can reach up to a meter in diameter and weigh up to 11 kilograms.

I picked this DVD up for 3.99 at rogers video in order to get enough points to get a better movie for free. I never actually was planning on watching this but it started poking at my curiosity and i finally decided to pop in it the DVD player. The effects in this movie are horrible and cheap. Some of the dialog in this movie sounds like it was written by a swear happy 12 year old boy. The acting is really cheesy in some parts, and the "action" scenes are completely laughable. You'll burst out laughing at some parts which was a positive for me because it kept me mildly entertained. The plot is some girl has a curse on her which causes her to vomit snakes so some shaman has to get her to Los Angeles, there are also two girls trying to smuggle drugs there and a few other people that are unimportant to the plot, not that there really is a plot at all.Don't expect anything from this movie and don't listen to the cover, there are not 100 passengers and 3,000 vipers, there are 10 passengers and 20 random snakes.As for the DVD, there is a trailer which is almost as laughable as the film, a blooper reel which is just one shot over and over of one actor trying to say train, and the deleted scenes are really pointless, if they weren't good enough to stay in this movie they must be pretty bad. I can't recommend it unless you want a really bad movie that you can laugh at with friends. I give it 2 kitty cats out of 5.

In 1968 when, "SYMBIOPSYCHOTAXIPLASM: Take One," was released, it came from out of nowhere, and struck like a psychedelic thunder bolt. Afro-American actor and film maker, William Greaves, aimed to forever alter the 'news-reel' style of documentary film-making, and to this day, there has never been anything quite like it. The movie is a film about 'the making of a film', and intentionally written and directed so as to create as much controversy and contradiction as possible. Set in New York's Central Park, the action and scant dialog concern a couple who fight and bicker about homosexuality and abortion. The woman wants out of the relationship, and the man wants an explanation. Near the end of this interaction, a drunk homeless man interrupts the proceedings and offers his commentary, and personal back-story. Then, after the principle footage has been shot, the film crew add their own views of the film-maker and what they feel is his inept handling of the movie. And during the entire film, multiple cameras are employed to record the action within the scene, and extraneous commentary by cast, crew, and onlookers. I would certainly recommend this film to anyone who has an interest in Avant Garde film makers such as Andy Warhol, John Cassavetes, or Jim Jarmusch. William Greaves attempts to show that a thing cannot be truly observed and understood because the viewing itself would alter the reality. "SYMBIOPSYCHOTAXIPLASM: Take One" can be seen as a cinematic representation or application of The Uncertainty Principle. This is only one possible explanation, and Greave's true intent is certainly open for speculation. Above all else, this film seeks to confound, confront. and stimulate, and without a doubt, succeeds admirably.

I just viewed Jean Renoir's wonderful film, French Can Can. It is a visual delight and a great entertainment. The recently produced Moulin Rouge pales by comparison. I didn't quite get all of the praise that the recent movie received. Now I'm convinced more than ever, that my appraisal was correct after seeing a master film maker like Jean Renoir's version of the same story. He succeeded in getting great performances out of his entire cast, and the great French actor, Jean Gabin was in rare form. The dance sequence near the end was one of the most exciting one I'd ever seen. It was long, but I didn't want it to end. This film deserves to receive more recognition than it's got.

Oh, Yawn. That's the only way to summarize my experience watching "The Unending Monotony," a film that, ironically, succeeds in delivering just that. The premise itself was promising: a group of individuals trying to break free from the confines of their mundane lives. However, the execution falls flat, descending into cliches and flimsy character development. From the very first scene, the sluggish pacing drags the audience into a numbing sense of boredom, making it an unbearable watch. The director, whose attempt at capturing the ennui and soullessness of modern life, inadvertently makes the audience victims of the same. This is supported by the uninspired cinematography, which fails to elevate even potentially beautiful shots. The acting does little to save the film - the lifeless performances of the ensemble cast seem more like a consequence of the weak script and uninspired direction. Dialogues, filled with faux profundity, do nothing but induce an eye-roll. Instead of instilling empathy or understanding, it leaves the viewers questioning if perhaps the audio was better off muted. The score of the film can best be described as obtrusively generic - each note doing nothing to enhance the viewer's experience but rather leaves a lingering feeling of annoyance. Overall, "The Unending Monotony" is a film that fails to make good on its intriguing premise, and instead turns out to be a self-indulgent exercise in cinematic soul-crushing lethargy. My only solace is that, thankfully, the movie does come to an end.

There is limited research available on the association between genetic variation in the beta-2 adrenergic receptor and chronic musculoskeletal complaints in adolescents. While some studies have suggested associations between genetic polymorphisms and various musculoskeletal conditions, such as fibromyalgia, osteoarthritis, and low back pain, these studies typically focus on adult populations. In a study by Holmen et al. (2011), they found a modest association between a specific polymorphism of the beta-2 adrenergic receptor (ADRB2) and musculoskeletal pain in a group of adolescents. However, this study did not specifically focus on chronic musculoskeletal complaints, and the authors acknowledge that further studies are needed to explore this association. Overall, the connection between genetic variation in the beta-2 adrenergic receptor and chronic musculoskeletal complaints in adolescents remains uncertain, and more research is needed to clarify this relationship.

The TPEF signal of elastin was increased at the peripheral regions of LCs (10 m) compared with foam cell regions. In order to confirm the increase of elastin, biochemical assay (western blot) was performed. The protein level of elastin was increased approximately 2.25-fold (p 0.024) in LC-rich arteries. Under the hypothesis that the increase of elastin resulted from the mechanical stimulus from solid-state LCs, MNLO images were subjected to FEA to simulate the displacement according to the expanding magnitude of the vessel during cardiac cycles. We found that microscale focal stress was increased specifically around the LCs. These FEA results corresponded with the increase of elastin observed by TPEF. These data suggest that LCs mechanically stimulate the adjacent ECM to alter the composition of ECM and cause vessel remodeling. The combination of MNLO imaging and FEA has great potential to verify the mechanical predictions in cardiovascular diseases.

A man charged with assassinating Russian opposition leader Boris Nemstov has told a court he was beaten and pressured into confessing to the murder. Zaur Dadaev is accused of being involved in the shooting of the politician in Moscow on February 27, along with four other Chechan men. Now Russian news agencies have quoted him as telling the court that he had been abducted, beaten and pressured into confessing to Nemstov's murder. Zaur Dadaev spoken to the court in Moscow via a video link from his prison cell. Dadaev had previously confessed to Boris Nemstov's murder but now says he was beaten and pressured into make that statement . Dadaev is one of five Chechan men who have been accused of killing the opposition leader. Nemstov was shot in the back four times on a bridge close to the Kremlin in February, sparking a huge protest march in Moscow . Dadaev was the only one, according to a judge and investigators, who confessed to the killing. When he appeared in court in March, Dadaev didn't admit his guilt for the murder, and later retracted his confession. Human rights activist Andrei Babushkin, who visited the suspect in jail last month, said he had seen signs of torture on Dadaev's body. Zaur Dadaev retracted his confession for the murder of Nemstov last month. A human rights activist said when he visited him in prison he had abrasions on his body and had suffered multiple injuries . Boris Nemstov was an outspoken critic of Russian President Vladimir Putin. It is understood at the time of his death he was working on a report examining Russia's military involvement in the east of Ukraine . But the Russian state-funded television network Russia Today claimed human rights activists had found no signs of torture on Dadaev's body when they visited him in custody. Dadaev is being held with his cousins, Anzor and Shagid Gubahsev. Khamzat Bakhayev andTamerlan Eskerkhanov have also been accused of involvement in Nemstov's murder. The outspoken politician was shot in the back four times as he crossed a bridge near the Kremlin and Red Square in Moscow. More than 20,000 people marched through the capital city in protest of his murder, holding posters of his face and signs saying: 'I am not afraid'. An outspoken critic of Putin, investigators say they are still trying to work out who ordered Nemstov to be killed.
